A film of ordinary ambitions and of limited but sometimes stunning success.
It manages at once to be unfair to blacks, vicious towards whites and insulting to anyone who feels that race relations might consist of something better than improvised genocide.
Realism without much reality, enormous care for the wrong details, historical accuracy and spineless dramaturgy.
Funny, uncomfortable and without an ounce of benevolence.

Not only does the use of the song impose a sense of emotional fulfillment upon a conclusion that does not ask for it, but also the use of the song's title for the movie suggests a meaning that is less interesting.
movie_title: Sympathy for the Devil (One Plus One) (1968)

movie_review_blurb: I value Makavejev's extraordinary insights into ordinary affairs and his gentle juggling act with Acrobat Aleksic.
Under the splendid direction of Robert Zemeckis, who also co-authored the screenplay with Bob Gale, Back to the Future is a joyous flight into the domain of a teen-ager`s fantasy.

It is a fright film that takes elements from classics that evoked the screamin' meemies and reinvents melodramatic applications offering a new spin to slice-and-dice antics. Gallows humor runs rampant, too.
Brian DePalma`s The Bonfire of the Vanities is a perfect example of how a best-selling book can be carefully altered, perceptively pruned and converted into an intriguing motion picture.
Motion pictures may never be the same again, now that the fascinating and utterly miraculous Who Framed Roger Rabbit has come to the screen.

The result is a film that not only answers many questions raised by the original story, but also expands production values, amplifies special effects and weaves a new plot that is even more exciting than the first.

A Fish Called Wanda is vintage black comedy, British-style -- a cruel, dastardly, down-and-dirty jewel-robbery romp that pits thief against thief, while entangling an innocent bystander in the web of greed, romance and decidedly cockeyed high jinks.
The Freshman is like no other comedy. Just when you think you've figured it out, it ambles away.
Face/Off is a masterpiece equal to the action classics Seven Samurai, The Wild Bunch and The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly.
An otherwise-hackneyed story of personality transmigration takes on new meaning -- accompanied by plenty of laughs -- all because of the film`s gregarious and clever star, Tom Hanks.
The City of Lost Children showcases dazzling art direction that takes cinematic expressionism to new heights.
movie_title: The City of Lost Children (La Cit√© des Enfants Perdus) (1995)

movie_review_blurb: From the opening frames of the this underwater fantasy, you`ll agree that the magic is back at Disney. Perhaps it never left.
Superbly photographed and marvelously lighted, this remarkable set piece of art direction and stunning decor cures many of its own ills, including a screenplay that meanders grandly.

A truly sinister fairy story laced with bizarre characters -- both live-action and animated -- James and the Giant Peach from Walt Disney Pictures is a stunning, if not markedly macabre, adaptation of author Roald Dahl's best-selling 1961 book.
A must see, Delicatessen is an absolute delight and a bizarrely madcap experience.
A funny, warm and inventive Christmas film that proves seeing is not believing -- believing is seeing.
The Lost Boys is heady, cutting-edge vampire stuff. Mind you, it's also very tongue-in-cheek. So watch out for those fangs, gang.
Cher is simply wonderful, and the teaming with Cage an inspiration. The rest of the cast couldn't be better.
Chasing Amy often is convulsively funny.
Brian De Palma's version blends style, violence and a host of fine character portrayals into a rousing, point-blank period film.

Mostly, My Fellow Americans is solidly written, offbeat entertainment well-served by the fine leads, clever casting of supporting roles and a script that holds together, even through a less-than-stellar finale.
Well-made but uneven, Braveheart has some grand moments -- but few pertain to Gibson's less than charismatic performance as the resourceful hero.
Cruise's name on the marquee is plenty to insure the success of the film, even if it is lopsided, shallow, and slips the audience a Mickey Finn at the outset.
Gone Fishin' is a slapdash, slapstick waste of time -- hook, line and stinker.

Within minutes, youngsters and adults alike will feel the magic and high-wheeling fun of this offbeat and entertaining film. Billingsley steals the picture, with his winning energy and great delivery.

Sheen, as an ace fireball pitcher called Wild Thing by the adoring fans, is excellent; so is Bernsen as a star-struck third baseman, whose portfolio is more important that a hard grounder in the hole.
[Stone] is the very best thing about this often disappointing, frantically sexy and, ultimately, unpalatable thriller.
A disjointed yet generally enjoyable stint at the movies, even for those who don't know an infobahn from a nanosecond.

The movie exudes an inescapable realism. Unlike a pastiche of newsreel footage, however, Spielberg craftily imbues Steven Zaillian's masterful screenplay with an emotionally charged examination of calculated brutality.
Nothing, however, can really prepare audiences for the generally good, though offbeat, performances, gritty action and serio-comic exploits of the Good Guys vs. the Bad Guys.
In this dull film, poignant characters caught up in histrionics flail with one glove, while much emotional shadowboxing is done with the other.
Mac and Me simply is an uninspired, fast-food version of E.T., The Extraterrestrial.

In an attempt to find the origins of infamous gangsters Charlie "Lucky" Luciano, Meyer Lansky, Frank Costello and Benny "Bugsy" Siegel, Karbelnikoff has rendered lame caricatures instead of meaty characters.
Move over Madonna; you'd do well to take some acting lessons from fellow- rocker and screen newcomer, Cyndi Lauper.
Ah, the charm, inquisitiveness and imagination of pre-pubescent adolescence, as seen by a Hollywood screenwriter.
For this they needed three screenwriters?
Although a comedy rife in lively characters, Wagons East! affords star John Candy one of the poorest, drabest, and thoroughly unfunniest roles of his career.
It may not be as glossy as Top Gun, but Fire Birds is still an above average B movie.
Between the laughs beats a serious theme about the real victims in families pulled apart by lack of intimacy and the threat of divorce.
While wrestling fans surely will queue up to see their boy win the day, No Holds Barred is just a sweaty headlock of a film, with dreary, gory scenes and a bunch of slope-headed hokum to propel it.
Bizarre, replete in often stunning special effects and verrrry strange from the outset, Super Mario Bros. is curiously entertaining, even though it often makes little sense.
This is a new low in movies. Miss it at all costs.
If you take the family to see this deplorable excuse for a good time at the movies, then parents deserve what the kids will learn.
The most attuned devotee of crime mystery will be hard-pressed to guess the outcome of this stylish thriller. It is riddled with machine-gun dialogue and kinky implications at every turn.

From its opening scene of shocking brutality through its remaining 150 minutes of electrifying, relentless drama, violence, humor and horror, Martin Scorsese`s spellbinding Mafia saga GoodFellas is a film audiences will long remember.
Full Metal Jacket is a great motion picture. Be warned, however, that it is harsh and explicit.
Number Five is the real star of this energetic film. Sheedy, Guttenberg and company are just supporting players.
While Michelangelo, Raphael, Leonardo and Donatello are the spunky, upstaging stars of the film, they also have a better cast and story to work with.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles II - The Secret of the Ooze (1991)

movie_review_blurb: Cameron`s superb action direction and stunning visual effects -- plus Schwarzenegger`s ultimately endearing (yes, endearing) performance -- will blast every other summer film to kingdom come.
Despite its frequently maddening lapses in logic and time frame, Jacob`s Ladder transcends most script ills to become a haunting and truly chilling thriller-melodrama.
The incorporated tale of large-craniumed alien scientists, bug-headed mutants and a heavily mascaraed heroine in a pointy-brassiered jumpsuit proves fine fodder for the MST3K writers and performers.
On Deadly Ground is a pip. Beautifully photographed by Ric Waite and handsomely produced, it surely is the most ambitious and the best Seagal movie to date.
As Siegel, Warren Beatty hones the finest characterization of his career.
Blue Velvet is a film for the aficionado. Pity the viewer who wanders into the movie unprepared.
While charming in conception and beautifully photographed in the dead of a Midwestern winter, Prancer is marred by a principal role.
Not without humor, Apartment Zero is a titillating foray into the dangerous, the unexpected and the macabre.
The effect is like an ermine violin: It is beautiful to look at, but it doesn't play.
Based on Tom Clancy`s phenomenally successful techno-thriller novel, The Hunt for Red October proves that a film can equal, if not surpass, the intrigue and excitement of the story it is based on.
Just how far can Barry go? That`s what stupified audiences will begin to wonder at the outset of this riveting drama.
One of the best self-conscious black comedies to come along in a long time, Martin Scorsese`s After Hours is a film that delivers humor and anxiety like a smack in the face with an amphetamine pie.
The cast of international players is excellent, with Serbedzija delivering an especially fine performance as Aleksandar, a humanistic photographer.
Good news is, Tomorrow Never Dies is highly entertaining. It will thrill novices and delight old-guard Bondphiles.

In Bill & Ted`s Bogus Journey, the laugh is on moviegoers. Teens may call it triumphant, but most folks will find the insipid film a totally non-non-non- non-heinous (i.e. egregiously bad) trip to nowhere... and beyond.
Once Were Warriors is a savage and dismaying tale of a venerable culture in decay and a film difficult to recommend.
Tom Hanks should forfeit his Academy Award nomination for Big, now that preview audiences have gotten a look at The `Burbs.
The Lawnmower Man is a visually stunning and innovative sojourn into a world of computer science gone haywire.
Despite brisk direction by Steve Barron, plus unbridled energy and fine special effects, an overt glorification of violence is still at the crux of this stunt film.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: The Movie (1990)

movie_review_blurb: The zany, campy, creature-filled fantasy Mom and Dad Save the World makes for unexpected family fun at the movies.
movie_title: Mom and Dad Save the World (1992)

movie_review_blurb: Old-hand Craven delivers a delectably gruesome, well-crafted horror yarn that is crisply edited, inventively photographed and devilishly cast.

Each routine was done better -- and funnier -- long ago by Sellers. Gags about getting drunk, mispronouncing words, dressing up in disguises, executing pratfalls and other inane physical bits have become old and tired.

McDormand is brilliant, Macy terrific, Presnell perfect, Buscemi fabulous. And Stormare is fascinating as one of the deadliest and most horrid big-screen killers in recent memory. Fargo is a down-and-dirty doozy.
Fortunately, Gordy turns to fun whenever it wallows in too much goofiness.
Jaws the Revenge, the fourth in a series of monster shark epics, is dead in the water.
Despite its "family comedy" packaging, parents may balk at taking kids to Carpool, where kidnapping at gunpoint is intended to trigger humor.
Cool World is a major disappointment -- a repellent oddity with unsavory overtones.
It is an unnecessarily cruel little film that attempts to evoke humor from the afflictions of old age, while using the bungling of an elderly parent to thrash a younger man into submission.

Every time the film makes some sense, the sweaty and sleepless face of Belushi invades in close-up and we know it`s only a matter of time before director Peerce will make us privy to the comic`s needless death.
The Naked Gun is destined to become a cult comedy classic. If the holiday run doesn`t make a bundle, the returns on the video cassette will.
movie_title: The Naked Gun: From the Files of Police Squad! (1988)

movie_review_blurb: Made in less than three months using a hand-held camera, director/writer Wong Kar-Wai's Chungking Express is a tale that only a diehard film buff might enjoy.
A Stranger Among Us is an unwieldy yarn that plays passion against faith and tradition in a most unconvincing manner.
The Professional is intriguing, but misses the mark as a potential cult favorite.

This form of self-conscious action filmmaking is smeared over both Stallone and Russell. They mug mercilessly (none too well) and, of course, they rely on plenty of bang and firepower to disguise a sour and often nasty script.
Dacascos and Prieto are fine athletes, to be sure. But that is not enough to make Only the Strong more than a passing fancy destined for cable TV.

A story of mixed messages that focuses on contempt for the law, legal authority and public safety, it attempts to garner sympathy -- and, unfortunately, laughs -- during a violent cross-country pursuit.
Released smack-dab in the middle of so-called Woodstock Week, the comedy Rude Awakening is an often well-intentioned, yet mostly misguided comedic flashback into the drug culture of the 1960s.
A Smile Like Yours makes no one smile or cry, just wince. The script is unwieldy, and Kinnear and Holly stuggle in every frame to make characters likable.
If not for the superb villainy of Frank Langella, who plays the evil Skeletor, Masters of the Universe would be as barren as an asteroid.
A rather vicious melodrama and morality play that will bore most kids silly.
The editing is relegated to a series of quick (often mercifully so) blackouts. Time shifts occur at random and often confuse.
Could somebody please tell me why four scriptwriters were needed for Mannequin Two: On the Move?
Both ambitious and clumsy.
Box-office commodity Adam Sandler is repositioned as kid-friendly in Bedtime Stories, a Disney movie that plays better on a balance sheet than a screen.

Pitt is quite good in the lead even if it does take close to two hours for him to show up in a matinee idol form we've all come to know. It's an underplayed performance, nicely pitched against great actresses.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Thanks to a nearly perfect cast, this provocative glimpse into the Catholic priest child-molestation scandal manages to be deeply disturbing on several levels.
The Reader, distant though it can be, touches and provokes a mulling over of the Holocaust like few films on the subject in recent memory.
It's a picture that never comes to life before the "death do us part."
In a profession that routinely casts aside leading ladies when they hit 40, it's a shame a great one had to take her act to France to remind us that actors, like wines, only improve with age.

Gran Torino grinds through its gears in an efficient if generally graceless manner, with occasional blasts of violence interrupting a film that is content to be the cutest movie Clint's done since his days of co-starring with an orangutan.
The movie's not very good, but there are ideas, good and bad, in its execution that are worth mulling over.

A laughless, gadget-geared and poop-obsessed kid comedy based on a Lois Duncan book, it will sorely test any parent hoping to have a few laughs with the kids and make it home without a side trip to the Humane Society.
As corny and downright flirtatious as this 'Holocaust drama' gets, it's still a vivid and heroic look at a side of that tragedy that we haven't seen before.
This is what Sin City would have looked like without the restraining hand of co-director Robert Rodriguez behind the camera.
The chance to play that poignant confusion is the real prize that Rourke and Tomei earn in The Wrestler.
Not Easily Broken is a marriage-in-crisis melodrama baked from the Tyler Perry recipe.
The book has been known to make grown men weep. But seeing the movie, you can't help but feel had.
If you know Van Damme's work in the least, if you have any sympathy for the plight of the third-rate action screen hero whose days come to an end, JCVD will amuse and touch you.
There's precious little space in Despereaux's tale for heroism (save for the third act) and humor.
This is as tepid as two-hours-in-the-cup old tea.
This comedy about a happy couple made miserable by having to visit four divorced parents begins with a bang but settles into sentiment so maudlin that even this cast can't save it.
It's messy and overwrought. But ambition this grand is worth two hours and 40 minutes of Aussie scenery, history (fudged), romance and war.
Lacking the polish and coherence worthy of its cast, Nobel Son is no prize winner.
Bodily fluids and the sounds they generate are a big part of this gory and wholly unsatisfying slasher film.

Any student of rock history would have to be concerned that Hollywood might have only one chance to get this right. Cadillac Records doesn't manage that, but with this cast doing its own singing, and history this rich, it's close enough for rock 'n' roll.
In Cruise's hands, von Stauffenberg comes off as a very human window into this history and this engrossing and involving movie.
This Earth could have moved if they had embraced the heart of Starman. Too bad they settled for a half-hearted Independence Day.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: There's nothing new under the mistletoe in this warm but generic family-stressing-for-the-holidays dramedy.
Nixon lands his blows, Frost counters. And Ron Howard? He gets the decision, but it's just a decision on points.
[A] taut, tense and witty tale of human tragedy and triumphant humanity set against the sweep of modern India.
Perhaps it is simply an accident of timing that puts Milk in theaters at this moment. But fate or simple fortunate timing, Milk arrives as one of the best films of 2008.
An emotional movie at the most emotional time of the year, it works to keep its secrets. But more importantly, when the tears do come, it has earned them.
It's an often engaging romance shot through with sweetness, a movie that hangs on a handful of simple, magical scenes.

The animation's not bad. But the staggeringly complicated Tolkien-C.S. Lewis setting, the reptilian leads and the faded fairy-tale plot skewer poor Delgo before we have a chance to figure out what's going on here and why.
The thin comic appeal of Kevin James is laid on a bit thicker in Paul Blart: Mall Cop, his first solo star vehicle for the big screen.
A work that's easier to ponder than enjoy.

George Tillman Jr.'s film may follow the well-worn path of many a musical biography. But spot-on casting, a light touch around the edges and affection for its subject makes this warts-and-all look at the big man with the big hits a winner.
Very cool.
Williams and Patton and the folks of this corner of Oregon serve up a slice of "indie" that, if it doesn't reach the level of "inspires," at least feels timely and true.
Director Tony Gilroy deftly mixes comedy with suspense as we see the extreme measures corporations take to steal one another's secrets and protect their own from theft.
Unlike Apatow opuses, Hamburg knows not to overstay his welcome. I Love You, Man is a the biff-bam/thank-you-man of "boys need boyfriends" comedies.
The dizziness of it all might not have been so obvious had we not had a long prologue and a finale that climaxes with two or three anti-climaxes, a couple of them laugh-out-loud silly.
Quote not available.
This Playboy fantasy farce is one of those painful comedies in which the strain to be funny shows -- always.
This is a horror movie that illustrates the difference between cringing and feeling.
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Phoenix's performance overwhelms the slight story.
The Class, an Oscar-nominated French film about a Paris middle school, should be required viewing for anybody considering a career in teaching.
If you aren't a teenage girl or can't channel your inner groupie for 76 minutes, you have no business at Jonas Brothers: The 3D Concert Experience.
The director of the third Transporter movie has given himself the name 'Olivier Megaton.' Too easy, you say? Very well. Make your own 'bomb' joke.
I'd say this is roughly 20 times better than the first Street Fighter movie. It's still a waste of time, but unlike the game, it's over in 95 minutes.
movie_title: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li (2009)

movie_review_blurb: In releasing this reverent, meticulous, fascinating but flaccid history in two lengthy parts, Soderbergh committed perhaps the greatest sin of all. He made Che boring.
There simply isn't enough Indian spice to make this ancient Chinese recipe fresh.
A mesmerizing survey of a family caught up in personal psychodrama, a Running With Scissors without the laughs.
It may be as dumb as you'd expect from this team, but Fired Up is still the best 'dumb cheerleader' comedy since Bring It On.
For all its attempted jolts, it's not all that scary. The genre is reduced to 'Who gets it next and how?' and never for a second makes us care.
It's a film that, mad as it sometimes seems, gives you things to chew on.
A dizzy and chic chick picture for our times, this hit-or-miss comedy is about the perils of conspicuous consumption, the void that shopping fills in some souls.
It's an ambitious attempt to shove the whole of a fairly complex comic book universe into a single messy and garish movie.
...somewhat less of a desecration of the memory of Peter Sellers than Martin's first outing as the bumbling French detective.

For all the polished electrons of the latest works from Pixar, Blue Sky or DreamWorks, Selick and Co. show that stop-motion animation still looks, moves and feels like nothing at all the computer animator's terrabytes can mimic.
There isn't much chemistry, thanks to the limited screen time the couples have to share with many other couples.
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Zellweger and Connick make a believable couple and one with real oil-and-water-don't-mix sparks. This is what romantic chemistry looks like.
Besson's espresso-jag thrillers are all the caffeine an action fan needs until the summer thrill rides arrive.
The film would all be a complete bore if it weren't for the odd sparks of wit, and the sparks set off by Sheen and B-picture queen Mitra.
movie_title: Underworld: The Rise of the Lycans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: One of the more outlandish B-pictures to come out of the Great Movie Mash-up Machine known as The Weinstein Co.

While we can appreciate the decent effects, the bang-up settings and a good cast, we can only hope they got some sight-seeing in on their days off. Whatever magic there was on this shoot is probably in their home movies.
The plot staggers from absurd to ridiculous, and the dialogue is strictly of the 'Look we don't have to go down there' variety.
A few laughs here and there and a couple of moments of emotionally stunted sweetness add up to a Fanboys that only a fanboy would love.
Disney animation takes a tentative step out of the shadows of Pixar with Bolt, a winning 3D-animated action-comedy that marries the best Disney traditions with Pixar polish.
Is the sweetness worth the stickiness in this maudlin American Sisterhood of the Traveling Green Tomatoes?

Wong Kar Wai seems considerably more out of his depth than other Chinese filmmakers who have slummed in the martial arts genre. This can't compare to Chen Kaige's The Emperor and the Assassin or Yimou Zhang's House of Flying Daggers.

Nick and Norah's Infinite Playlist is one of those magical, near-perfect youth romances, a film that so vividly reminds you of the glories of young love that you wish you were 18 again, full of hope, not jaded by life and love lost.
Fearless as a fatwa and subtle as a Second Coming, Religulous is a revelation.
[Director] Gregg makes the movie work as a sordid sex satire, but falls short in rising above that. And the many loathsome-turned-pathetic characters make Choke, in the end, a bit hard to swallow.
The most deeply disturbing, downright discomfiting movie about teen sexuality since Thirteen.
[A] sloppy, absurdly long mashup of combat film cliches.
It's something of a well-intentioned mess.
A stumbling satire of a malpractice-marred medical profession, Robodoc has a sitcom-trained cast that should be able to land the one-liners. What's missing are the one-liners.
The movie version of Nights begins with such promise before it drowns in the romance novelist's syrupy sentimentality.

The whole package here is warmed-over mush from a hundred other sports movies, a tale padded out with game footage, training sequences, absurd coincidences, life lessons that teach nothing and wasted casting.
The fever-pitch paranoia of this terrorist thriller, the seizure-inducing editing, the dense layers slapped on a fairly simple plot all point to a kind of overkill that only Hollywood money can buy.
Isolated bits don't add up to much here.
Well acted and tautly directed, it's a movie whose juice is its realism, the easily recognizable situation, the paranoia that any homeowner can identify with.
There's enough good stuff here that a better 'toon could have been stitched together from the many promising funny parts.

The Family that Preys shows grand advances in the filmmaking education of playwright-turned-filmmaker Tyler Perry. It's also his soapiest film yet, an overwrought melodrama of sibling rivalry, infidelity, family business power plays and terminal illness.
Fascinating as sci-fi, paltry as a parable, Blindness is one of the movie year's most daring failures.
A raunchy comedy that plays like a Superbad without the smarts, the heart, the originality or the laughs.
Everybody involved has earned a more righteous, movie and righteous director, than this.

This is as stale as Tuesday's Phad Thai, from its exhausted mythos of the surgically efficient, omnipotent hit man to the training scenes in which Joe explains the trade to the new guy, to the inevitable betrayals of the third act.

With a wealth of lip-smacking character turns and a plot that keeps us off our guard, Burn After Reading takes its entertaining place among the better lesser Coen brothers films, even if it doesn't burn itself into our memory.
James Marsh tells Petit's story, the most inspiring 'heist' in modern history, a Frenchman's stroll between two 110 story buildings in lower Manhattan.

Transsiberian is a paranoid, chilling train trek that borrows freely from the best Hitchcock pictures to give us that rare adult summer thriller -- 'adult' as in not based on a comic book or video game.

Ripped-from-the-headlines realism, top-drawer performances by Don Cheadle and Guy Pearce, a dandy 'ticking clock' story structure and a vast catalog of terrorist modus operandi make this as harrowing as it is timely.
Occasionally touching, always interesting.
This film from the Adam Sandler fun factory starts with a series of obnoxious, dated stereotypes, and never quite flips them into something positive.
Of all the Z-movies in the Roger Corman catalog, they had to remake Death Race 2000.
Durst and Cube and Co. have done a decent job with a movie that never set out to be more than an average crowd pleaser.
Courtney Hunt's Frozen River is the first great film of the fall. It has great actors playing vivid characters in a setting that makes for a clash of cultures.

Dead Poets Society, Dangerous Minds, Mr. Holland's Opus, all 'great' movies about 'great' teachers inspiring their students to achieve great things -- all movies referenced lovingly by Steve Coogan's 'inspiring' teacher in Hamlet 2.
The Rocker feels safe, a long way from the cutting edge, a PG guy in a PG-13 movie, a comedy with too much 'parental guidance' to be rock 'n' roll.
Bottle Shock is... utterly charming.
It's a movie of one-shots, with the ladies staying in their flattering light, delivering their lines to someone who reacts to that clever line in the next one-shot.
There's a playfulness that seems just so right in Catherine Hardwicke's Twilight.
Ed Harris, working from a Robert Parker novel, has crafted a meticulously detailed, newfangled old-fashioned morality tale of hard men who go soft when a woman comes between them.
If Chihuahua is no Babe or Charlotte's Web, at least it's in the Alvin and the Chipmunks ballpark. Just remember nobody went to the pet store and grabbed a chipmunk on the way home after that one.

Hawkins wears her grin in almost every scene, but she gives us hints that this dizzy 30-year-old is deep, as are the disappointments that might have caused Poppy to don this mask. It's a performance of sustained, childlike wonder and adult wit.
It fairly races by, a sexy, sadistic, cruel and crackling thriller that is the shortest Bond film since Goldfinger, and certainly the most brisk.
As funny as some bits are, the best you can say about Role Models is that it's imitation Apatow. It lacks the master's crude touch.

Jackson and Mac click. They're perfectly believable as 'funk comrades' from back in the day, polyester princes reduced to asking for the AARP discount when they hit hotels they once trashed in the best rock-star tradition.

The animation shows glossy improvement from the original Madagascar, with nature and the neo-natural animals even more detailed than ever. But the knock on Dreamworks' animation style -- that it's entirely too talky -- rings true here.
The Haunting of Molly Hartley isn't the least bit haunting. It's just cheap.
If the film is too long and a little unwieldy in its later acts, the consummate craftsman in Eastwood glosses over that with detail and righteous rage.

Movies about Hollywood are as common as Jolie babies, and there have been broader, funnier, meaner takes on the business than this one. But this Barry Levinson version of real-life producer Art Linson's memoir is more movie-savvy than any of them.
Just when you think you've seen pretty much everything that can be done with that exhausted horror genre, the vampire picture, somebody comes along with a new twist.
RocknRolla reminds us of how cool Ritchie was before Madonna doused his fire. Pity he makes us wait so long.
It's a slow-footed film that confirms that Smith may never be able to lift his game to that 40 Year Old Virgin level of heart and romance. He's just too juvenile to pull it off.
movie_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Rachel Getting Married is a magical wallow in excess, a too-happy, too-sad, too-indulgent plunge into an over-planned wedding.
Saw V utterly mimics the original film's formula -- that awful basement, those cops chasing clues in what we assume to be the same time-frame, those awful devices of death.

If you aren't between the ages of six and 14 or don't have kids, you may have trouble getting into that Wildcat spirit. But don't be shocked if Senior Year takes you back, just a bit, and makes you wish every high school was a little like East High.

[Pegg is] a goof, and he's funny enough to warrant the price of admission. But after this and Run Fatboy Run, he really needs to deliver something sillier before he loses fans and alienates his audience.
movie_title: How to Lose Friends & Alienate People (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The high points are few and far between in Judge's second Animation Show.
It's not quite a Grapes of Wrath for our times, but Trouble the Water does give a voice to people America didn't see or listen to before Katrina.

A good IMAX film usually combines eye-popping visuals with a 'teachable moment', a little history, geology, biology or what not, tucked in between the pretty pictures. Grand Canyon Adventure more than fills that bill.
movie_title: Grand Canyon Adventure: River at Risk (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Actor-turned writer-director Stuart Townsend makes great use of the documentary footage of the '99 Seattle WTO riots. And he gets across his talking points about this shadowy outfit, too. It's a shame his script and all his actor friends get in the way.
The writers, "true story" or not, were plainly recycling Amityville story structure. So credit editor Tom Elkins with the scares that work.
Sex Drive is a Sure Thing for the Superbad generation. But if it lacks much of The Sure Thing's warmth and romance, Sex Drive makes up for that in goofy, no holds-barred raunch.
As good as a couple of its action beats are, Max still suffers from the heartlessness that makes games emotionally inferior to movies. Nobody ever shed a tear over a video-game character's death.

If it doesn't measure up to the label "epic," it's still an engaging account of one man's journey through war and those circumstances that give meaning to the saying, "Heroes are made, not born."

Screenwriter Dana Fox (the dreadful Wedding Date was hers) and director Tom Vaughan can't find much fun or romance in this. What Happens in Vegas ... offers none of the surprises that screen comedy so desperately needs.
The Visitor is a tiny treasure of a movie. This is a wistful comedy that quickly finds its rhythm, but never lets that groove become a rut.

Made of Honor earns enough goodwill in a long, clever and sexy opening act to carry it through to an ending that we don't necessarily guess because it seems to lack enough of that last word in the title: 'honor.'
Everything a summer movie should be, and more.
It's a movie that keeps its distance from the characters, so much that we can shudder at what we fear is to come but aren't really allowed to mourn the innocent trapped in this downward spiral.
In all its mock outrage and its daring shots at hypocrisy, bigotry and the government, Harold & Kumar, the characters and the movie, lose their subversive innocence.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Never less than watchable.

This dark, absorbing thriller is not just a moral exercise in the awful choices faced by those determined to survive history's worst genocide. It invites us to imagine ourselves in the shoes of a not-quite-lovable rogue.
There are a couple of minor surprises and enough laughs and truisms floating around the supporting cast to make this an easy comedy to watch.
The director of Super Size Me shows something else -- guts -- in his sober-minded but comical, skeptical but never cynical documentary, Where in the World is Osama Bin Laden?
movie_title: Where in the World Is Osama Bin Laden? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Markedly un-thrilling.
Every fight is more spectacular than the one before, and there's just enough of the playfulness of Chan's best brawls (this is more violent) to keep The Forbidden Kingdom laugh-out-loud light.
It's sentimental and shocking, and it has more laughs than any non-Apatow-produced comedy out there. And it's absurdly overlong.
A cynical attempt to sucker Christian conservatives into thinking they're losing the 'intelligent design' debate because of academic 'prejudice.'

Prom night is a night you're supposed to treasure, or at least remember 'forever.' This one is forgotten by the time you throw your empty popcorn bucket into the trash cans conveniently located near the exits on your way out.

It's not the pie that is meant to make this watchable, it is Wai's greatest gift, observing people, little slices of life in New York, Memphis or Nevada. Unfortunately in this case, those slices don't add up to a meal, or even dessert.
China has a lot to answer for these days -- unsafe food exports, unsafe toys, Tibet. And now CJ7.
The Promotion has more work-life truth in it than a month of The Office or Dilbert.
Marvel is so busy setting up the next sale that they can't see the mediocrity built into their own formula.
Actually better than expected.
Stiller rounded up a cast of A-listers, took them to Hawaii and blew up $90 million worth of stuff. He made a movie about making a movie that no movie-maker should ever have made. And it's a riot.

Filmmaker Alex Gibney had access to those who knew the guy, the famous, the infamous and the obscure, and he paints a picture of a serious journalist who saw himself documenting 'the death of the American Dream.'
movie_title: Gonzo: The Life and Work of Hunter S. Thompson (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The whirl of hormones, high hopes and hysterical drama that is high school earns its close-up in American Teen, a smart and revealing look at the Class of 2006 in Warsaw, Indiana.
Does it count against you when you actually set out to make an awful movie? It should.
This one takes the action comedy to places -- irresponsible, violent, and funny -- that it has never been before.
A sequel that actually improves, slightly, on the boy-crazy original.
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants 2 (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Tell No One is a classic modern-Hollywood thriller, a movie with a layered murder mystery, a frame-up, gangsters, conspiracies and one dazzling chase.
movie_title: Ne le Dis √† Personne (Tell No One) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: That first sight of Ben Kingsley sucking down a bowl will burn into your memory. You may be watching The Wackness but it's hard to forget that this is Gandhi putting Bic to bong in Jonathan Levine's silly, sappy and sympathetic coming-of-age memoir.
The action beats are the same as the earlier Mummys -- with planes, guns, digital creatures and vast armies of the risen-dead having at it. The missing ingredient here seems to be the fun.
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Swing Vote nicely boils down America's political malaise to one man's awakening from a Budweiser stupor and seeing the only thing that matters when you don't pay attention and exercise the franchise on Election Day: You're letting your kid down.

It's not subtle, not the cleverest thing Apatow has put his name on. But for lowdown, cheap and dirty laughs, it's pretty hard to beat Reilly and Ferrell, riffing, trashing and trash-talking each other for 94 mostly mean, sometimes manic minutes.
A movie that benefits from -- but doesn't make very good use of -- the history and the chemistry between its stars, David Duchovny and Gillian Anderson.
movie_title: The X-Files: I Want to Believe (The X Files 2) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Chicago 10 is that nearly perfect marriage of style -- edgy, different -- to documentary subject: 1968, that seminal year so celebrated in 2008 for changing the America that came after it.
The plot is absurdly preachy and illogical, and the dialogue uneven, with stinging lines followed by stinkers.
One of those cartoons parents at least won't mind sitting through while little Miss or Mister Eight-and-younger gets his or her chuckles at the cute talking primates.
It's still too long, especially for a comic-book movie. But with Ledger's last performance director Nolan was blessed with the gift of light.
This blend of computer-animation and live actors-as-paleontologists recreations makes for an educating and kid-pleasing trip back to the age of the dinosaurs.
Stuck lost me the moment it started going for cheap laughs. Are we really meant to snicker at his suffering and at this awful, awful woman?

As big, mindlessly fantastical summer entertainment goes, this falls comfortably between Iron Man (the gold standard) and the not-quite Incredible Hulk. It's a visually striking, mildly amusing way to kill a couple of hours.
It's old-fashioned family-friendly B-movie cheese, served up in this Brendan Fraser/Jules Verne action epic for kids.
movie_title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: For what it is and for whom it's intended (young children), Kit Kittredge works and works wonderfully.
Passable if profane, Hancock chugs along right up to that when this comic superhero engine goes off the tracks, and pretty much off a cliff.
Mongol, from its thrilling battles to its intimate romance, has the look, scale, story and feel of an old-fashioned epic in the best and biggest sense of the word.
Wanted hurtles past our eyes and ears too fast to register as much more than a video game.
The idea that an ancient Hollywood musical, with its love duets and foot-tapping dance numbers, would be the thing that awakens emotions in both humans and robots, is pure genius.
If I had my way, every indie comedy would be done The Foot Fist Way.
Julien Temple's film is an energizing work of art, a visually striking and inspiring look at a band that never 'sold out' and the leader who saw to it that they didn't.
movie_title: Joe Strummer: The Future Is Unwritten (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It's vintage Myers, with an outrageous, broadly played character borrowed from Peter Sellers, silly makeup, bad puns, innuendo, the occasional pause for song and dance and Myers' ongoing obsession with little people.
Surely after the Speed Racer fiasco, Warner Brothers was ready to say 'sayonara' to lame 1960s TV adaptations. But plainly there wasn't time for the studio to, ahem, Get Smart about that.
It gets by on the featherweight golden oldies of ABBA, and the treat of seeing and hearing some golden oldies of the cinema break character and belt out a song.

Like no fish-out-of-water film in recent memory, it leaves you with the hope that these fish will find their way back to water, and maybe learn to share that puddle before the desert dries it up entirely.
When you toss this many balls in the air, several are bound to be forgotten.
Keanu Reeves tries his best to channel Denzel and Clint in Street Kings, a wild and woolly if also slack and silly bad-cops-kill-other-bad-cops thriller.
Technical tricks can't hide a tired time-travel story dressed down with an almost humorless script.

[Adam] Brooks' movie has romantic ambition, something lacking in Hollywood romantic comedies of late. But he has made a slow-footed, long-winded comedy with more grins than laughs, an arm's-length romance with a real eye-roller of an ending.

A top-drawer cast, sympathetic script, a director known for delicious teen edge and one of the great cinematographers of our time have conjured up a topical, whimsical and occasionally magical action-romp through a world we know, but don't fully see.
Animated by hand, often in glorious black and white, this French classic has the pathos, wit and intellectual sting of great political filmmaking.
The movie winds up as a lot of pretty people sitting around a movie set waiting for a director and writers to strike comic or romantic gold. At least their tans were 24 karat.
A revealing and often hilarious look at the life of a stand-up.
movie_title: Vince Vaughn's Wild West Comedy Show: 30 Days & 30 Nights - Hollywood to the Heartland (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Hollywood, which spent most of the last century ignoring the black family, seems determined to spend most of this one showing the same black family. Over and over.
$15 is a bargain compared to what scalpers were asking us to fork over so our little darlings could see their teen idol.
movie_title: Hannah Montana/Miley Cyrus: Best of Both Worlds Concert Tour (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Seeing isn't believing.
A gutsy and startlingly balanced take on the events of that day in February 1996.
A wan, sad-eyed romantic comedy.
Speaking of YouTube, let me save you 65 minutes. Go to the website, type in United 300, and see a far funnier, far more clever 300 spoof that's only five minutes long. From last spring.
A brutish, brutal and simplistic orgy of violence.
From its obvious foreshadowing to Marsh's big PowerPoint presentation of the killer's cause-and-effect, Untraceable is a mite too traceable to get under the skin.
The dance has to be good because the rest of the movie is one long cliche.
Even if the setting is novel and the leads seem authentic, How She Move is all too content to step down a well-worn path.
If all [Woody Allen] is going to do is grind out weak, Brit-accented genre pieces that pay homage to 1940s and '50s melodramas, he shouldn't waste the frequent-flier miles.
It's oil, and a West that was just discovering it, that makes There Will Be Blood intriguing. But it's Day-Lewis who draws us in.
It's just a lot more sane and tame than its 'mad' title would have you believe.
A jolt to the genre. The camera tumbles, the smoke billows, gigantic footsteps thunk, women shriek and the car alarms blare. And we are there.
It's not one for the ages, but this comedy about the 'perpetual bridesmaid' suggests a romantic marriage between star and audience that could last and last.
There are big laughs and minor moments of grace in The Bucket List. It's also fun to watch these two swap lines, Nicholson angry and antic, Freeman laid back and serene.
It's a subject and a film that perfectly blends the tragic with the triumphant.
movie_title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The Orphanage is a classically creepy Spanish horror film and a joltingly modern one. It turns down the thermostat on its chill slowly, deliberately. That just makes the big frights all the more heart-stopping.

It won't utterly rewrite Carter's history, and it won't convert anybody in this divided country, but Man from Plains will remind us that principle, humility and intelligence have a place in image-is-everything American politics.

Shrug off the recycled script and the movie's trite if uplifting, message and recognize the signs of stardom to come. It won't be too many Sundays before David E. Talbert finds his funny film niche and Katt Williams becomes a top billed star.
Pity this most mysterious 'Can you hear me now?' of all is spoiled by too many answers to too many questions.
We're pretty much left waiting in this drifting melodrama about living the artistic life in New York and the ambition it takes to do that.
Maybe the best thing about this cute pet movie is that the kids won't be able to talk you into picking one up on the way home from the theater.
movie_title: The Water Horse: Legend of the Deep (2007)

movie_review_blurb: [It's] is history at its most entertaining, and a vivid reminder that we're all living in a country built and then rebuilt by people who turned their passion into logical, rational arguments that moved us, step by step, down the road to justice.
Transforms a great rock spectacle into something intimate, is a cultural artifact of an era when we could label a rock group 'the only band that matters' and have it mean something.
Even a legend's got to make a living, sure. But Diary, for all its core audience appeal, feels like a filmmaker lurching slowly down a path he's already worn out.
If it isn't up to his Oscar-winning Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind, it at least has Jack Black and Mos Def around for laughs.
An overplotted, gimmicky presidential-assassination thriller, its interlocking pieces have to fit just so for it to stay coherent and ratchet up the tension.
It's a warm drama that humanizes Americas current illegal immigration debate even as it sentimentally stacks the deck in favor of the undocumented.

With Scott Smith's rep and a best-selling horror novel, a sexy location and solid young cast, you'd have hoped the studio would find a director with a little more than a Tommy Hilfiger commercial under his belt.
It's as dry as the martinis these well-dressed stiffs keep ordering at that perfectly preserved oak, leather and velvet bar before hopping into their vintage convertibles.

Scorsese captures the Stones at their ancient, un-ironic best, bluesy showmen who leave it all on the stage every night, never for a moment letting on that they're playing, for the 10,000th time, 40-year-old hits.
It's worth spending 90 minutes on Nim's Island. You just wouldn't want to get stranded there.
If the real NFL had started off this tired, we'd be spending our Sundays watching jai alai.
It's a sweet, ingenious, twisted and surreal comedy, kind of Samuel Beckett by way of Adam Sandler.
It's a movie for the inner 9 year old in us all. That's the age that most people move on from flatulence jokes, and sniggering whenever they hear the 's' or 'f' words.
It has meaning and sentiment and a nice pay-off for its finale. But without more laughs, Run Fatboy Run is awfully winded by the time it crosses the finish line.
The new blackjack dramedy 21 stands when it should hit, never doubles down and wimps out to the point that it turns a pretty compelling tale into a bust.

Brilliantly observed and vividly shot, built on a career-making performance by Ryan Phillippe, its an Iraq War movie for Americans whove been avoiding Iraq movies, even the good ones such as In the Valley of Elah.
Whatever progress the man was making, Browns is a Madea-sized big fat step backward.
Shutter is seriously short on shudders.
The film's charming look at island life away from the tourist beaches makes it more than the sum of its laughs.
Movies such as this remind us that Owen Wilson is nothing less than a national treasure.
Imagine the first serious competition to the Deutsche dummkopf Uwe Boll as "worst director" working today, thanks to this mad and maddening mash-up genre picture.
Circle of life lesson for A simple story, eloquently told, with lovely and humongous pictures.
Imagine an R-rated Ferris Bueller with only the most annoying parts of the younger Matthew Broderick's screen persona emphasized and you'll draw a bead on Bartlett.
This dark comedy shifts effortlessly between silly and sobering, and it finally gives Colin Farrell the chance to be as funny as we've long suspected he could be.

What Penelope offers is a terrific cast willing to emphasize the charming, a decent fake nose and a message that any parent would love to pass on to a child -- love yourself and the world will love you back.

Whatever its virtues, this is entirely too much melodrama to cram into a feature film. Characters are lost, too much happens off camera, and the whole compacted thing feels like Reader's Digest history.
The actors make us happy to be along for the ride.
Semi-Pro tries for semi-sweet when bittersweet would have been better, semi-silly when full-bore absurd was called for. And the final score? Semi-funny.
It's wonderful how much real history they sandwich into this ham and cheese on wry.
As enchanting as all this alpine footage can be, as a movie, Steep is flat.
The players, especially Adams, overwhelm [director] Nalluri's early uncertainty and make sure that Miss Pettigrew does indeed live for a day, and for one pretty delightful night at the movies.
movie_title: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Where's Raquel Welch in that fur bikini?
Even though it's as predictable as a pro-wrestling match, what it lacks in originality it makes up for in the nervous energy of youth and testosterone.
It's a pity the movie is so smug, gimmicky and heartless.
This new Horton 'toon may be state of the art. But it's great virtue isn't the 3-D animation. It's the good Doctor, whose writing about Whos never goes out of style.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' Horton Hears a Who! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It plays like a Western, and the violence, while plentiful and visceral, rarely has the kind of raw impact you want in a movie such as this. Morelli keeps most of the blood off-camera.
The Bank Job is a solidly built and entertaining Brit B-movie about a heist that goes wrong. And right.
Murphy's goofy, bug-eyed hysterics seem played out and overly familiar.
An improvised pseudo-farce that tumbles into melodrama -- in between all the long, LOOOOoonng heart-to-heart talks.
Terrific performances rescue it, from Adams' wounded exhaustion to Pais's comical confusion and Walker's furious defiance, all hurled against Morton's patient 'listening' and advice.
Frankel is blessed with this cast and a subject that seems ripe for mockery, or at least gentle lampooning. But he never lands big laughs, just grins and giggles.
In most regards (We still miss Kevin Bacon), this is a "new and improved" "Footloose," funnier, sunnier and funkier. Simply put, it works.
A decent cast and a pristine glacial setting are wasted on a movie of alien transmutations and alien dissections that lacks urgency, or even a sense that's its very cold in Antarctica.
A first-rate one-woman-against-the-system drama, a film benefiting from grim recreations of an ugly reality and a stellar cast determined to expose it.
A toy tie-in, an overlong movie that takes on some of the grimy veneer and colorful characters of a "boxing picture," sanitizing it for children.
"Restless" is far more precious than profound. But that takes little away from this soulful teenage exploration of love, life and death.
There's a taste of "Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind," "Something Wild" "Forces of Nature" and even "Bringing Up Baby," perhaps the best of the wild child-seduces-straight arrow romances.
movie_title: Le nom des gens (The Names of Love) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It's a plucky film that covers a lot of ground and uncovers this wonderful, ancient ritual that people of many faiths and from all walks of life take on.
Anna Faris and Chris Evans don't have enough scenes together, don't have enough funny lines and aren't surrounded by enough funny people to give this "Bridesmaids-lite" a shot.

Like a pastor so caught up in the moment that he can't see that the air conditioning has given out and the congregation wants to go home, the film travels far beyond its dramatic climax, aiming for an altar call finale.
Odds are you'll find something of substance, a few life lessons in between the laughs in "50/50."
"Evil" fails to triumph. Utterly.
An uplifting and entertaining film...
"Abduction" falls in the same corner of the youth market as the "Twilight" movies. Some moments and many lines feel cribbed from that series.

This tiny Catholic school for women dominated the sport at a turning point in history, and this plucky, old-fashioned sports drama sets the scene and tells the tale with a lot of heart and a dash of wit.
Adorable...
Smug, savage...and infuriating.

The idea that working moms feel the strain of achieving some balance more than working dads is nothing new. And that's true of most everything in the movie. We've been here and done that, repeatedly, over the past 25 years or more.
movie_title: I Don't Know How She Does It (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Pulsating...very cool. Could have used a little more "driving," though.
Lawyer-turned-screenwriter Dylan Schaffer's script is an unhappy combination of genres, tones, too many dead stretches of people in cars and inept dialogue.
Director David R. Ellis has delivered a heartless, suspense-free 100 minutes of sharks dining out on kids stuck on an island in a Louisiana lake.
The new version of "Don't Be Afraid of the Dark" is entirely too literal, but it still manages to be a literally hair-raising piece of modern-style old school Gothic horror.
movie_title: Don't Be Afraid Of The Dark (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Rodriguez only needs the script to take us from one gimmick to the next, and his lack of attention to it shows.
movie_title: Spy Kids: All the Time in the World in 4D (2011)

movie_review_blurb: "Arabia" makes a pleasantly watered-down primer on Saudi Arabia, then and now.
It's a frustrating film, never light enough on its feet to be cute, never heartfelt enough to achieve "You had me at 'Hello.'"
The sweet, the comic and the tragic blend together most agreeably in the winsome French romance "The Hedgehog."
It's a slack but competently executed film of a script with butterknife-dull dialogue and actors cast because of their "type."
Haters, head for the door. But Gleeks? Get your "Glee" on.
Rapaport gets at the dynamics of a group that struggles even now to get along well enough to get paid - again.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Even by the standards of some of the more cultish corners anime, this is a confusing mash-up of story and subtitling.
A decent yarn, decently told, a tough guy film built around veteran screen tough guys.

Lee Tamahori's film, freely adapted from Yahia's life story, captures the temptations of a life without rules and without limits, and the horrors of the trap a life lived at the whim of a psychopath truly is.
A split personality action comedy that fails to please either impulse. The action is wan, the laughs hard to come by.
"Paranormal" reveals itself for what it has become, the "Saw" of found video thrillers.

Man on a Ledge isn't a caper comedy. It's a heist picture, a thriller -- and a not-that-thrilling one at that. But the folks who made it have enough of a sense of humor to get how silly it is and run with that on occasion.
Remember all the big talk from Joe Carnahan about bringing this back to theaters for Oscar consideration in the fall? Seems pretty stupid now, doesn't it?

Not much better than the dreck Nic Cage has been shoveling at us in recent years - a tad smarter, perhaps. But as in life, he keeps getting up off the mat and coming back for more, even if much of his audience isn't returning the favor.

Best picture? Best director? It's certainly better than some of the nominated films. But Fincher & Co. lose points every time this movie is nothing more than a slightly -- just ever so slightly -- inferior version of the Swedish films.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Mark Wahlberg delivers the goods in Contraband, a B-movie about smuggling in boozy, corrupt New Orleans.

Ferrell hurls himself into the melodramatic, heavy-breathing telenovela style of acting. And surrounded by actors who know the genre and get the joke (Efren Ramirez from Napoleon Dynamite among them), this send-up works.
Pitiless, puerile, pointless and perfunctory -- and those are just the "P's."
The bottom line on The Woman in Black is that it is a very spooky movie. Old-fashioned and old school, it makes a convincing case for life after death and, for Radcliffe, life after Harry Potter.

Diablo Cody and Jason Reitman have still managed to get at a fundamental truth that screenplays traditionally ignore. People don't change. Character "arc" is one of those myths that movies perpetuate.
Didn't Jennifer Aniston already do a bounty hunter movie? Talk about sloppy seconds.
It's a good movie on a great subject, even if it is well short of a great film.
movie_title: In the Land of Blood and Honey (2011)

movie_review_blurb: If it's January, it must be low-grade horror season.
It's something of a sweet-natured slog, peppered, as all of Crowe's films are, peppered with the pop music the former pop music journalist loves.
If only they'd spent the cash on a bad guy with stature, instead of taking that phrase, "the banality of evil," so literally. Playing this Game might have been even more fun.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It's a pitiless picture, but a visceral movie going experience.

Brad Bird passes his audition for a career as a live-action director. And Ghost Protocol more than makes its bones as an argument for why Tom Cruise should continue in this role as long as his knees, and his nerves, hold up.
A big wet holiday smooch from an overbearing aunt...you grimace. You stand there and take it. And you grin afterwards.
It is a vividly detailed depiction of a time, a place and a conflict.

To its credit, the film gets at the things that gave the Airmen their lasting fame -- the odds and racism they overcame, leading to the integration of the armed forces, the civil rights movement and the integration of America.
Gary Ross, who directed Seabiscuit, manages to get this nag out of the starting gate and across the finish line with no major blunders, but without much in the way of inspiration, either.

Timed to come out in the middle of a political dogfight over birth control, when candidates tell their supporters that they'll "get rid of Planned Parenthood," October Baby could have hot-button appeal for a certain audience.
It's a clumsy, dated and stodgy production -- ugly to look at, unromantic in the extreme.
A Sarah Palin joke? A Charlie Sheen wisecrack? Is this a Chipmunks movie or a Letterman monologue?
Even by sloppy Sandler movie standards, this one's a wreck - fart jokes, potty zingers and pit-stain gags.

Clint Eastwood's "J. Edgar" is a lumbering miscalculation, a slow and clumsy re-think of the late F.B.I. founder J. Edgar Hoover's life and career that views his him through the lens of his alleged homosexuality.
Seriously, someday you guys are going to sober up, catch this on video and wonder what gave you the giggles all those White Castle runs ago.
Shannon wonderfully modulates Nichols' portrait of a man whose mind and life seem to unravel before our eyes.
Writer-director Niccol manages to cover the same ground as the most recent "Spy Kids" movie without tumbling into silliness.
Give it points on setting and a couple of the performances, but the joke-starved "All's Faire in Love" only rarely rises to the level of fair to middling.
Atkinson revives the comic secret agent that he first introduced in a series of TV ads in the UK, but this thin script gives him nothing remotely like a rebirth.
Streep's performance of a dismissive line such as "People don't think anymore, they feel," will have even the most dyed-in-the-wool liberal questioning core beliefs.
Pop singer Katy Perry's Smurfette faces award questions about being a rare female smurf, and blurts out, "I kissed a Smurf and I liked it."
"Snow Flower and the Secret Fan" aims for the heartstrings and only strikes a few notes.
movie_title: Snow Flower And The Secret Fan (2011)

movie_review_blurb: That rare teen comedy where the kids aren't gorgeous, the hero isn't heroic and the object of desire has a lot of reasons why she isn't necessarily desirable.
Music video director Marcus Viner's 3D cameras don't take us into the performance or even up on the stage with the dancers. Stylistically, it's a very pedestrian treatment of its subject.
Light enough in tone, but plastic.
It's OK to put out a movie with a message. But rendering even potentially dramatic stories so inoffensive that they bear no relation to reality makes for middling drama.
This isn't satire, it isn't that funny and the only bits that work are the titillating ones.
"Immigration Tango" is like a slow-dance with your sister - perfunctory, awkward and without a hint of heat.
The airless Matthew Fogel-Don Rhymer script makes one long for the snark and sass of Madea.
movie_title: Big Mommas: Like Father, Like Son (2011)

movie_review_blurb: As funny as these guys can be when they work themselves into a purple-faced rage yelling at the TV camera, none of the current generation of wrestler-actors seem to have the charisma or comic gifts of a Hulk Hogan or Dwayne Johnson.
They're young, they're attractive and they glow neon blue when they're hunted. Which is often.
"Never Say Never" is about as revealing as a Canadian snowmobile suit.

Danish director Christian E. Christiansen does nothing remotely chilling iwth the visuals or the tempo, so the movie leans heavily on John Frizzell's strident string-heavy score. Even efforts at playing the titillation game with his stars feel meek and PG.
Predictable. But the chills and thrills work, and it is gorgeous to look at.
O'Donoghue is so stunningly uncharismatic that he kills whatever possibilities this picture from the director of the silly-scary-smart "1408‚Ä≥ had.
Sharp observations, thin on entertainment value -- "Mumblecore" at its heart.
Dr. Dennis Cooper must have knocked off this script while watching "Scrubs" re-runs in the break room. This is "Scrubs" told totally from a black doctor's point of view.
It scores points for being that rare "faith based film" to show a little edge.
Cage's old pal Dominic Sena is a decade removed from their "Gone in 60 Seconds" directing glory, and he gets nothing out of this script that isn't pure hokum.
Blue Valentine feels off-the-cuff and improvised, which adds to the charm of that first date and the danger of that "big fight."
Even at 83 minutes (plus a three minute cartoon) it's a drag, another 3D movie for kids in which the 3D adds nothing, merely subtracting from parents' wallets.
Kind of a victory lap for Jeff Bridges. Dark. And not as much fun as the original.
Weak as they've been, the "Alvin and the Chipmunks" movies are operating on a higher plane than this.
Yeah, it's nuts. No, it's not that much fun. Action comedy, Asian sword slasher pic or martial arts mystical mumbo jumbo, this warrior never quite finds his way.
All Good Things is thoroughly engrossing, a roman a clef that chillingly ponders a puzzle and suggests solutions outlandish enough to be stranger than anything Hollywood, on its own, could make up.
Whatever brownie points Tillman scored with "Notorious", "Faster" is that wake-up call that he's no John Woo.

For every spycraft scene, every illustration of the deadly blowback from the leak that Liman dramatizes, the movie has half a dozen scenes of a delicately balanced home life turned on its head by a government bent on destroying one of its critics.
"Skyline" plays like an effects guru's resume reel, not a movie.
The director of the limp "Pelham 123‚Ä≥ remake takes a second shot at his railway movie, and this time gets it right.

Fresh evidence of widening desertification and other calamities linked to climate change is ignored for a lengthy take-down of Gore's admittedly specious use of Katrina as the future face of hurricanes.
It's only our investment in these fascinating characters and in wholly unraveling the mystery of Lisbeth Salander's awful past that keep it compelling.
movie_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: This scathing expose should be enough to alarm people all over the political spectrum.
Even the fluff feels recycled here.
The film sets us up to judge and then upends those judgments.
"The Elephant in the Living Room" is damning, but also very sad. These stories, as Harrison points out, never have a happy ending.
movie_title: The Elephant In The Living Room (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A gorgeous looking film filled with the sort of footage one can only get with patience and persistence.
Quote not available.
An entertaining variation on a well-worn theme.

You take movies like this for what they are and for whom they're intended. But this script, this leaden direction ensures that even as the teen wish-fulfillment fantasy, complete with young women playing dress-up, "Monte Carlo" fails.
It's perfectly pleasant big screen comfort food -- meatloaf, potatoes and apple cobbler served as bubbly Tom Petty and ELO tunes waft from the soundtrack.
"Beginners" is warm and revealing and bittersweet, if a trifle all over the place stylistically and thematically.
The funniest, best-executed film in the talking, bleeding, Earth-protecting robots-that-look-like-cars-and-trucks series, "Moon" delivers the popcorn in gigantic fist-fulls of fun.
Once you get past the cliched Spanglish dialogue and the sentimental tone of the early acts, "A Better Life" settles down into something both involving and moving.
"Bad Teacher" is a pulled punch, a pot-smoking/kid cussing/teacher copulating farce that is less than the sum of its parts.
It's a bit long to be as kid friendly as this educational and visually striking film is meant to be. But it will give you a renewed appreciation for who these creatures are...
Yes, "Cars 2‚Ä≥ is better than "Cars."
"Green Lantern" isn't "Jonah Hex" bad. But it's silly enough to be part of the same "silliest Warner Brothers comic book summer movies of all time" conversation.
It's not very good, but it works better than it has any right to because Carrey never ever phones it in.
It's another wan tale of an anti-social teen who finds himself irresistible to the sweetest, prettiest girl in school.
An easy-going trek down a road well-traveled by these two.
Glibly put, this challenging time-skipping rumination is the big screen equivalent of watching that "Tree" grow.
Much of the movie - too much of it - is just Buck in the corral, riding, working with ropes and flags, conditioning a horse to behave.
All garish colors, small-scale sight gags and kid-friendly one-liners, it lacks the same comic spark that a recent "Wimpy Kid's" second diary also failed to deliver.
movie_title: Judy Moody and the NOT Bummer Summer (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Co-writer/directors Jesse Holland and Andy Mitton miss as many opportunities as they develop here, but they maintain the mystery and ratchet up suspense like seasoned pros.
Here's a documentary so slick, novel, touching and outrageous that your first thought might be "This has to be fake."
Cute, but never insufferably so, "Born to Be Wild 3D" is best taken as the perfect film to transition your kids from animation to live action fare - short, sweet, and educational.
Co-director Chad Waterhouse's script is filled with melodramatic contrivances.
It's not a put-down of the darker and more straightforward "Last Lions" to suggest "Cats" is to "Lions" what poetry is to prose.

If he's moving on from Madea, and "For Colored girls" and his next couple of announced projects suggest he is, at least Perry's doing right by the old broad, letting her bow out like one big, wise-cracking mother of a momma.
Yes, it's in 3D and no, it's not remotely as good as "Rio."
The film has intrigues, shootings, infidelities and clues -- lots of clues -- which we ponder, along with the poker-faced Smiley, played with Oscar-nominated perfection by Gary Oldman.
By and large "Prom" is exactly what the prom-haters in the cast say it is, a lot of build-up for something that isn't remotely as "special" as those obsessed with it wish it to be.
What "I Am" is wanting is a sense that it actually wrestles with anything, that it can stand up to a contrary point of view that the film's 76 minutes are so utterly lacking.
It lacks the authority, simple displays of hard numbers, contrary voices and the like, that we need from a documentary this provocative.
The film's payoff is clumsy and obvious. But Kristofferson, Corbin, Kilmer, Yoakam and Duff create indelible characters in just a few scenes each.
Narrated in rhymed couplets, it's aimed squarely at kids seeing their first IMAX movie, maybe even their first film, kids old enough to know the rhythms of rhyme.
"Kung Fu Panda 2" is a sequel that delivers more heart than laughs, and is, if anything, more visually dazzling than the 2008 original film.
The lads in the "Hangover" "wolfpack" seem a tad winded, this time around. From concept to execution, "Hangover Part II" has a "been there, done that, jailed for it" feel.
As the title character, Routh has to carry the movie with bravado and charm, appearing in most every scene, narrating in the style of a hundred film noir private eyes. And he just doesn't have it.

The immigration and drug war parable and photojournalism ethics are never front and center, but draw attention because Edwards doesn't deliver well-earned frights or even cheap jolts. It's a good-looking movie with zero sense of urgency.
Veering from the sensational to the maudlin, this is a compromised epic that panders to the Chinese audience.
A semi-serious sci-fi romp, lighter and more fun than many of the comic-book movies that it steals from, a superhero movie in which nobody ever crusades, or wears a cape.
Pinto, stoic and stunning, demonstrates why this heroine and this tale of her woe still have power more than 150 years after it was written.
It's the film's attempt at a conventional, big budget finale, with a big prop(Think H.G. Wells)...that trips it up.
Bogs down in its middle acts, losing track of the epic struggle it sets up, but rallies for a fine finale that most won't guess until it shows up
It's all sight gags and action beats, which tends to cover the shortcomings these assembly-line farces are infamous for.
Can a movie be utterly done in by a botched ending? Maybe.
Through it all, through her cotton-candy-colored hair hues, her candy-store concert sets and cheesy looking stage costumes, all her chart-topping success, Perry comes of as genuine...
A big step backwards for a star who has better things to do.
It rarely stumbles into "terrible," but this "Spider-Man" never rises to anything, either. Where's the charm, the heart, the humor?
A well-acted weeper that walks an unsteady line between the emotional and the darkly comical.
You know what's funny? Seth "Family Guy" MacFarlane making fun of Adam Sandler movies. F-Bombs, lame celebrity cameos, gay jokes, drug jokes. Take away the animation and MacFarlane IS Adam Sandler.
Soderbergh, Tatum and McConaughey strip this world of glitter and body oils. They let us know that for all the supposed fringe benefits, these guys work hard for the money...
The dialogue sounds as if Allen hasn't been out of doors in the past 30 years. The characters are stale stage archetypes. And the all-star cast he's rounded up to play the parts often recognize this.

"History prefers legends to men," Abe narrates from his diary. Writer, director and star have conspired to give us none of the above - not the history, not a compelling legend, and certainly not Lincoln the man.
"Seeking" is a movie you have to give time to work. It was written and directed by the woman who wrote "Nick & Norah's Infinite Playlist," so you owe it that much.
movie_title: Seeking a Friend for the End of the World (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Thanks to this glorious new restoration, "We'll always have THIS Paris."
movie_title: Children of Paradise (Les Enfants du Paradis) (1946)

movie_review_blurb: The writers and animators blend the oafish, brawny Scots humor of "How to Train Your Dragon" with the magic of "The Secret of Kells" into a story about being brave enough to change your fate.
The director never got over his contempt for the music.
A conventionally unconventional romance in the modern mode, a comedy alternating between cute and crude and packing a heaping helping of self-affirmation into its 84 minutes.
Before he was Mad Eye Moody, before he took Colin Farrell to the woodshed "In Bruges," before "The Guard," the great Irish actor Brendan Gleeson was the infamous Irish crook known as "The General."
Director Tanya Wexler struggles to let much air into what could have been a delicious, winking farce.
"Charming, but oddly under-motivated...Netflixable."
Watching stage-parented poseurs play at being punks, mugging for the camera and talking sass to every adult, is not most people's idea of time well spent at the movies.
How much you forgive this depends on your tolerance for tie-dye, Jane Fonda, senior citizens who never outgrew their '60s idealism and the Grateful Dead
"Prometheus" is to "Alien" what "2010" was to "2001: A Space Odyssey." It's the difference between a masterpiece and a merely watchable revision of that masterpiece.
A riot of splashy colors, silly 3-D gimmicks, big, broad kid-friendly gags - and those professionally pesky penguins.
If you can't guess where these "Crooked Arrows" are going, you aren't getting out enough. But Routh is wonderfully light and laid back here, perhaps thanks to the low stakes this tiny film has.
Jack Black, in the greatest performance of his career, makes us see what the people of Carthage, Texas, saw in Bernie Tiede...
A sometimes humorous, often damning but also disingenuous attempt to "Michael Moore" the United Nations.
A tad too twee for its own good.

The people Oren ""Paranormal Activity" Peli charged with turning this idea into a scary movie ignore many of the cardinal rules of horror -- how to build suspense, the necessity of empathy in the characters, the need to give us and them hope...
Sandler has made worse movies, but never one as grotesque as this.
If you're making a movie aimed at people of a particular faith, you might want to cut it below an R-rating. And if you're going to attempt an epic, you need to spend more money than this.

It has the summer's best effects, the summer's highest stakes - Gotham City Armageddon - the summer's sexiest villain and the biggest comic book movie thrills and best comic book movie chills of this cinema season.
The great romantic gem of the summer, a diamond in the rough that bends genres, tickles the fancy and trips up expectations.

The film flutters to the ground like so much GOP convention confetti, all assertions, few facts and little substance other than the conspiratorial right wing talking points that are D'Souza's bread and butter.

The first delightful surprise among the summer blockbusters. Beautifully animated, terrifically acted and edited in a way that hilariously mimics those Endless Summer surf documentaries, it will amuse kids and flat-out tickle adults.
Simply put, "Day" is a mess Cavill never rises above.
What writer-director Leslye Headland has given us is a romp that never quite romps, a teary-eyed string of taking-stock moments without tears, and a serious squandering of major league movie talent.
A pleasant but overly complex variation on an idea Woody Allen toyed-with in his stumbling "You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger," this notion of counterfeit literary fame...
It's fascinating but anti-cinematic and a frustrating film to get your arms around.
Snappy, sassy, full of zingers and zippy cameos, the last film of summer 2012 is a pleasant shock, offering Ari Graynor a welcome promotion from best friend-evil girlfriend roles.
If you see only one Jewish demonic possession movie this year...
Inauthentic, a movie pulled together by a lot of folks who had no feel for the setting or the story they were telling.
Wafts out of the ether like the ghosts of bad movies past, the very picture of the cinema's dog days of August.
Skates by on being simply R-rated "adorable.
A thriller that permits you to stay two or three steps ahead of it. It's a film that makes you yell at the screen, to shout "Come ON!" at many a moment that seems to defy credulity.
A surprising jolt to the system, driven by a great villainous turn by Michael Shannon.
It's been engineered as a vehicle for pop starlet Jordin Sparks. But...when the late Whitney Houston isn't upstaging the title character, the bombshell Carmen Ejogo ("The Brave One") is.
With every shopping spree, every limo ride to McDonald's, Mrs. Siegel underlines the cliche that money cannot buy you taste. Or class.
Irresponsible as a first-person shooter video game? You bet. But it holds together, more or less, right up to the moment Chuck Norris and his dyed beard make their preposterous appearance.
An animated marvel...Oscar worthy.

These two days skip by in a movie that plays like early Woody Allen, with Julie Delpy as the blonder, French-accented Keaton, this time the center of the action and very much in charge of the mess she makes around her.
The Gilroys --co-writer/director Tony, writer Dan -- don't kill or wreck "The Bourne Legacy." But this Treadstone retread just treads water, and that's no way to make it Bourne again.
Movies that step on that third rail of filmgoer appeal - politics - always pull their punches.

Seeing the best in the business act out the no-eye-contact body language, the embarrassment of talking about life's most intimate details, and alternately grump or whimper about it gives this fluffy comedy a tiny dose of gravitas.
