This movie feels too undecided. The movie is so intent on not being "Training Day" that it just isn't "Training Day" enough.
It's as interesting as a viewing exercise as it must have been as a writing exercise. But traveling 360 degrees with your story means you end up right back where you started.
Still dazzling, and the movie Ron Howard's "Rush" is sure to be measured against.
Not the best of the "Wimpys," but Devon Bostick is still a laugh a minute as Rodrick, and for an hour the laughs come quick and sure - slapstick stuff, mostly.
movie_title: Diary of a Wimpy Kid: Dog Days (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Despite all the effects, the action and the showcase performance created for his wife, Kate Beckinsale, director Len Wiseman never lets us forget that he's no Paul Verhoeven.
A movie as elegant, spare and tantalizing as its subject.
If we can't laugh at beer-swilling trigger-happy Neighborhood Watchers, what's the point of moving to the 'Burbs?
The sunniest and most entertaining of these silly kids-gotta-dance musicals.
Loud...lurid...and the best film of the summer
An achingly sweet parent-and-child tearjerker that's every bit as precious as its title.
movie_title: The Odd Life of Timothy Green (2012)

movie_review_blurb: There's no heartfelt bond between the generic main characters, no emotional drive or urgency or pithy observations about life and high school. "High School" only emphasizes the "high."
In the battle of the dueling queens, Oscar winner Theron comes up short against the regally evil Julia Roberts of "Mirror Mirror."
As biographies go, this one's pretty close to hagiography - painting in personal details, glossing over the chinks in his armor and in Israeli history.
movie_title: Follow Me: The Yoni Netanyahu Story (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Yes, this Titans is going to you-know-where. At least this one manages to make the 3-D ride worth the destination.
We don't want to remember it's pretty bad. Then we do.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode I - The Phantom Menace (1999)

movie_review_blurb: A goofy, gonzo thrill ride, Vengeance is a bad movie sequel so bad it's good -- a bad movie that's almost a great bad movie.
As pretty as it is, this Secret World is too Earthbound by far.
It's a brisk sprint over familiar ground with just enough appeal to action addicts and romantic-comedy lovers to amuse fans of both genres.
It's a furiously macho saga scripted by the screenwriter of 300 and starring real Navy SEALS, those always-get-their-man men of mystery.
A few good scenes, a few solid messages...But he's such a dull dramatist and boring actor that the message isn't delivered.
The photography and editing are state-of-the-Bourne-art exciting - breathless chases, brutal, blurry fights and unnerving shootouts.
A random, tedious and tone-deaf comedy, a feeble recycling of every hippie commune cliche you've ever heard.
There's nothing in the film - which lacks urgency - or Seyfried's eyes or physical demeanor that suggests panic, fear, desperation.
"Project X" is that beau who sets off warning bells when he's there to date your little girl. You won't want to let her out the door with this creep.
Unfairly bashed by the anti-environment PR machine, this is a delight.
"Billion Dollar Movie" is proof positive that having friends is a lot more important than having talent in Hollywood.
movie_title: Tim and Eric's Billion Dollar Movie (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Gina Carano has a face that can hold a Hollywood close-up and a fist that can hold your nose until it comes clean off.
A moving but somewhat myopic take on America's newly anointed favorite childhood problem - schoolyard bullying.
A bloated sci-fi epic from Disney that's made watchable by swell effects, passable performances and those little dashes of humor that reassure us that the filmmakers know this is all a lark.
The greatest animated film ever made and one of the screen's great musicals hardly needs this (3D) sort of sprucing up.
The mysteries aren't that mysterious and some may have a hard time embracing its abrasive hero.
Cronenberg spares us few of the gory details of the patient who brought the two fathers of psychoanalysis together and helped tear them apart.
Mad, uplifting and gloriously twee -- a delight.
This "Raiders of the Lost Ark's Greatest Hits" is a delight to look at, even if motion capture isn't your particular cup of animation tea.
An amusingly nerve-wracking trek into the snow and out onto the ice with those funny folks in the land of "you betcha."
Political cynicism, media opportunism, dogmatic native traditions, corporate greed and environmentalist stubbornness are each, in turn, dashed against this sunny confection.
Murphy, without the words to go along with his bug-eyed double-takes and the mugging, is lost here... He's never been a silent comic, and never will be.

"The Artist" drags, as any film telling its story with its mouth and ears tied behind its back can be expected to. But it's a lovely bit of froth, the meringue on a cinema season that is both high-minded and awards oriented.
Like a Nicholas Sparks novel with a dash of wit, a hint of edge and a smidgen less sap.
Paul Weitz's gritty, sweet but mostly unsentimental film of Flynn's book puts a flawed, unpleasantly realistic face on homelessness and gives Robert De Niro his best role in a decade.
Amusingly childish...
Writer-director Ti West goes where many -- especially Stephen King -- have gone before...
They know it's a joke. But like high school itself, 21 Jump Street hits the wall about halfway in and even prom night can't save it.
A movie whose terror can be read in every silent scream on Olsen's gorgeous face, served up in more extreme close-ups than you can count.

Horror has been so dumbed down in recent years that it's a minor miracle when a movie in this genre actually gives you something to ponder, something more than omnipotent nuts-with-knives or teenagers trapped in abandoned summer camps.
Not since Francis Ford Coppola slapped his daughter Sofia into "Godfather III" have we seen a lead performance this dull, whispered and charisma free.

I found the length tedious, some of the dialogue eye-rolling and some of the digital effects lacking (the digital ship's digital wake seemed puny) when "Titanic" first came out. But those quibbles fade with time.
Josh Brolin impersonating the young Tommy Lee Jones is worth the price of admission to "Men in Black 3."
That rare French import that aims no higher than adorable and hits its target every time.

You get a feeling of haste from this film, as if Spurlock...is onto something, but maybe doesn't have the time or patience to stick with it to widen his approach and find sharper people to sharpen his material.
There will be bigger movies this summer, and better ones and worse ones. But there will not be a dumber movie than "Battleship."
Superficial and frothy...choppy and episodic, and funny - especially when Chris Rock, a veteran dad in real life - is holding court.
movie_title: What to Expect When You're Expecting (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Most of the bits are funny, but the film that connects them is flat, the performances -- especially Cohen's -- incomplete, under-developed and poorly cut together.

Can a single tone-deaf, wince-inducing joke, even one that's repeated, kill a movie? No. Not a good film. But a marginal one that has trouble finding its tone? Let's just say wisecracks about spouse abuse don't help this one.
Slow moving...it isn't a great film but it is an entertaining one, a touchy subject given a feel-good flavor...
Broad, mean, with inconsistent political aims and uneven performances.
The cheesy and cheap but beloved TV program takes an affectionate ribbing in the film, which has more in common with "That '70s Show" than its actual source.
A cast of great Brits of old-age pensioner vintage lights up John ("Shakespeare in Love") Madden's film...an adorable comedy about elderly pioneers tackling life's last great adventure.

It works because Joss Whedon never loses sight of the fragile humanity of the characters, even in their special effects brawls. It works because somebody finally got The Hulk's blend of rage, guilt and bull-in-a-chandelier-shop fun right.
With all the talk of "Kony/KONY 2012" wending its way into the culture, this movie gives a vivid picture of who this villain is and why the world should be doing something about him.
As fascinating as it is, "Sound of My Voice" seems to have more doubts about Maggie than the ones the viewer has the chance to develop.
Plays like a five-episode, R-rated story arc from "How I Met Your Mother." With more profanity and more explicit sex. And considerably less drinking. And no Neil Patrick Harris.

"Pirates" plays like a fussy film made by fussy little fussbudgets, clever chaps all wrapped up with making perfect Plasticine trees, but who lose track of the forest - the funny movie that is supposed to be animated around all this detail.
What we have here is basically an American "Transporter," with Statham caught up in the most jaw-dropping, quick-cut fights you've seen in years.
Spurlock has made a marvellous artifact, lacking only the "Odor-ama" that would make this a definitive snapshot of a modern tribe, its sometimes silly sacred relics and sacred rites.
movie_title: Comic-Con: Episode IV - A Fan's Hope (2012)

movie_review_blurb: So why, why more American Pie? It's a lame one, just the same one, now with much older guys. And starlets wearing mileage from all their whiskey and rye. Singing "Why did my career go 'bye'?"
The movie, heavily hyped by fanboys and long-delayed, isn't scary. By the third act, Whedon has written himself and his characters into a corner too silly to gracefully get out of without cheating.
The Farrellys cleaned up their act for a kiddie audience. They even appear on camera for a "don't do this at home" disclaimer at the end, because, as ever, the Stooges are for kids.
Guy Pearce goes into low-Earth orbit to get his cool back in "Lockout," a silly sci-fi B-picture made fun by his star turn.
Like the definition of jazz, "Blue Like Jazz" never resolves itself. It's a meandering medley of disconnected solos, too intent on avoiding predictability or a conclusion to actually come off.

Jeff, Who Lives at Home takes the Duplass Brothers' art to a new, deeper place. Credit the cast or the characters tripping through well-worn situations and relationships, but this is far and away their best movie.
It's a sitcom pilot waiting for re-write.

The great actors, from Welles onward, want the popular audience to see what they see in Shakespeare -- that he still matters, that he still moves, thrills and teaches. With "Coriolanus," Fiennes brilliantly takes his place in their ranks.
"The Lucky One" is the edgiest-ever film adaptation of the writings of Nicholas Sparks. Which isn't saying much.
In bad melodrama, the instant a woman says "You are such a good man, David," to her husband, you know that he isn't.
movie_title: Woman Thou Art Loosed: On the 7th Day (2012)

movie_review_blurb: For all the laughs, Harvey's thesis - that women have to expect more from the arrested-development crowd that make up "the men of this generation" - rings true.
Every now and then, the movie comes close to placing us where the music often did - in the realm of the mystical, with a beat everybody could dance to.
More entertaining than it has any right to be.
Amazing detail and storytelling trump a sometimes cloying cuteness in Disneynature's best yet.
A winning, witty fox trot through the Roaring 20s, when men were men, women were liberating themselves and the 'to the manner born' were losing their grip on their manners -- and manors.
Cute and funny at times, but with a lot of dead spots.
The movie's shortcomings are the Hollywood literalism in the third act, the need to show us things and connect dots that we don't need to connect.

Director Lee Daniels takes us on a journey -- letting us look down our noses at this misshapen lump of a girl with contempt and pity. But Sidibe plays shadings of strength underneath that eventually win our grudging respect.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The movie's a pretty conventional feel-good sports drama in many ways. But Bullock and Aaron give it heart that transcends the genre.
The Damned United is a most entertaining study in obsession wrapped in a traditional sports movie.
It was cut by over half an hour for American release and still plays long. But thanks to that fairy-dusting of Curtis charm, I wouldn't cut a frame of it. It skips by like a much-loved old LP.
Are we meant to applaud when skyscrapers topple and ships capsize, with tiny digital faceless bodies plummeting into the void? You make the disaster this real and it's not entertaining or chilling.
It's broad and yet realistic, silly and yet never exhuberantly goofy.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: By Fezziwig, that story still works and tugs at the heart. It would even if each ghost's visit weren't scored with overly-suitable Christmas carols.
Yoo-Hoo suggests that, yes, Berg broke new ground and, no, she shouldn't be forgotten. But it doesn't explain why she endured, or why she is so forgotten today.
It's a bouncy, engaging, slightly revealing and at times downright moving portrait of Jackson, sweating to his own oldies at 50, prepping a "comeback" he never got to make.
This script, by Marcus Dunstan and Patrick Melton, has a more lyrical bent, and a more satiric bite, than any of the other Saw sequels.
Their most inside joke ever, it leaves you with a lot to chew on, if not a lot to enjoy.
Scattered as it sometimes seems, Good Hair is a real eye-opener...
The movie's big drawback is that it isn't silly enough.
movie_title: Cirque du Freak: The Vampire's Assistant (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Amelia earns a pass, corny as it sometimes is. The lady earned her wings, and Swank, especially, more than does right by both the woman and the legend.
A movie that is tres chic even if it sometimes resembles those corsets Coco banished, a little stiff and confining.
That last stormy night of violence should be the shocker. Giving away his ruthlessness in earlier killings robs the movie of it its payoff as it saps the climax of much of its power.
There is dazzling basketball here and an interesting father-son relationship (Coach Dru Joyce was father of the shortest player on the team).
Owen, not chasing Julia Roberts or anyone else for a change, is pleasant enough making this 100-minute argument for unconventional parenting.
As a children's film, it's a bore. And as a grand film enterprise, Where the Wild Things Are skirts the line between folly and fiasco.
Neeson, in particular, has to rumble through the movie behaving in a way consistent with the ending and comes off as far over the top in the process.
Yolande Moreau plays the industrious but touched washerwoman-turned-painter S√©raphine de Senlis with an open-faced conviction that is almost unnerving in its intensity.
Couples, a sputtering if sporadically amusing misfire, packed a lot of actors off to a pretty location and gave them nothing funny or deep to do.

The immigrant experience gets a fresh, post- 9/11 Palestinian spin in Amreeka, a film that has all the familiar ingredients but is such a well-acted, winning re-combination of those that we see them with fresh eyes.
[A] droll, witty and thoughtful comedy about the thing that really makes the world go round.
Capitalism is alternately moving and disheartening, energizing and enervating.
This is Juno meets Slap Shot, a well-directed, well-cast romp that doesn't quite transcend its worn formula but is still the best girl-powered sports film since Bend it Like Beckham.
It's comical, yes, but glum and brooding, too, a wintry waltz through acting, underground commerce and metaphysics.
It's a tight, minimalist Alien-esque "something is loose and hunting people on our space ship" picture that is as claustrophobic as you'd expect, if not quite as paranoid as you might hope.
For all the inspirations, the pieces of better stories that this tale was concocted from, Surrogates never manages to be anything more than a poor substitute for the real thing.
This Fame is a film without the guts to show Idolized America that, as Debbie Allen so memorably said way back when, "Fame costs, and right here's where you start paying."
It's a "Who dies next?" slasher film masquerading as a revenge thriller.
I have no idea if they serve beer in hell. But I have some notion of what might be playing at the Hades AMC 20. It's I Hope They Serve Beer in Hell, probably on a double bill with All About Steve.
movie_title: I Hope They Serve Beer in Hell (2009)

movie_review_blurb: That flip tone -- the gags and one-liners -- get us past the longing, the depression, the sulking, the almost comically swooning moments.
Trashing Old Dogs is a bit like kicking a puppy. But here goes.
Harrelson gives us layers of hurt under a callous yet needy crust. It may be the best performance of his career and certainly deserves Oscar consideration.
God's given up on the human race and plans to wipe it out. Again.

As Fred Claus ham-fisted as this is, the glint of what might have been a cute kids' comedy still glimmers in random moments. But that Disney touch (which even Disney has trouble replicating) is missing.
Extraordinary Measures isn't extraordinary. It's simply safe.
It's obvious what the book is and the resolution to this quest tale is silly beyond belief. Denzel just plays it quiet, tough and cool, as if that alone will carry the film.
His first time out, Ford has made one of the best films of the year.
Limp and lifeless, this Next Door neighbor should be evicted to DVD.
Jackson overwhelms the thoughtful, introspective nature of the material with whistles and bells -- heavenly effects that scream "overkill."
It's a romantic comedy. We know where this is going. Tucker & Co. don't seem to realize that it's not the destination, it's the witty, winsome journey that counts.
One failing in the film is how boring it is to watch Cruz pretend to be a bad actress. The comic movie within a movie, which borrows from Women on the Verge, isn't funny.
Daybreakers reminds us that from Twilight to Underworld, True Blood to The Vampire Diaries, this is one genre where supply has utterly overwhelmed demand.

The cinema's greatest fantasist serves up towering cliffs and blinding blizzards, Satan conjuring up clouds he can walk on, a road of rose petals winding into a desert -- an imagination that has no peer.
"Punk" and "rebel" don't belong in the same sentence with "Michael Cera." But somehow, they connect in the few-holds-barred teen comedy Youth in Revolt.
Cage, who usually goes gonzo with gusto, underplays this monster. That spoils the fun.
movie_title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: There's more to making sword-and-splatter work than just shiny blades and blood. It's got to have an edge, and the one on Ninja Assassin is dull as a butter knife.
The empowerment message is obvious, the strain of trying to be "hip" and edgy in the script shows. But Meyers sets the table for funny people to deliver laughs.
This is not your great grandfather's Sherlock Holmes.

You don't have to be a royalist to be moved by beautifully staged coronation and wedding moments, and composer Ilan Eshkeri scores such scenes with music so thrilling you'll feel you've got a front-row seat to the real thing.
Whatever slim charms there were in the nostalgic, musically cute and slapstick-friendly first film of chipmunk mania are squished right out of The Squeakquel like so much rodent roadkill.
movie_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Lawrence's recycled observations of the virtues of rural life, his struggles to find something funny about local "types" (an unworldly doctor and his na√Øve-nitwit nurse), his "grizzly encounter" scene, are painful to watch.
movie_title: Did You Hear About the Morgans? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: As visionary tour guide, Cameron has no equal. Predictable story, clich√©d dialogue and logical lapses aside, he's still the man we want leading us into his Pandora's box.
Disney's The Princess and the Frog is an instant classic and one of the year's best films.
Jason Reitman's dry, moving "comedy," based on the Walter Kirn novel, is a sly indictment of Corporate America, Marketing America and Frequent Flying America.
Flaws and all, you can't watch a frame of it without feeling that it has been generations since Hollywood tackled anything on this scale.
Eastwood, returning to race as a theme, has made a timely film about a nation of many races rallying around a leader who understands symbolism.
Over-familiar and industrial, a factory film made because a recycled script, minimal budget, a location, a grab-bag cast and some armored trucks were available.
One laugh -- Vampires, stuffed in their coffins on a horse-drawn wagon, whining to the driver -- "Are ve DERE yet?"
A tolerably sober alternative to holiday froth at the mutliplex.
As predicable and cloying as Brothers sometimes is, the cast is fascinating, young actors now possessing the dramatic heft to pull something like this off.
The plot is an afterthought, the performances given with a wink and a clip-emptying flourish.
movie_title: The Boondock Saints II: All Saints Day (2009)

movie_review_blurb: How can a movie starring six Academy Award-winning actors be such a bore?

Rock fans and Guitar Heroes in the making will get a charge out of visiting where the happy accidents that put guitars into each man's hand happened. And the playing isn't bad, either. Loud. But good.
Coddington, at least, gives us an appreciation of the talent seeing to it that the grandest fashion magazine of them all still sells the dream of glamour with style.
Bright Star is literate, romantic and high-minded.
The comedy about a would-be writer's attempt to cook her way through Child's culture-changing cookbook sees Nora Ephron return to her Sleepless in Seattle form.
Stupid movie, right? But kid-friendly.
The editing and camera work are self-consciously stylish, as if to say "We're better than this." But the human and moral components are shortchanged.
A gimmicky, sad and beautifully acted mystery that keeps its secrets even when it loses its grasp of the logical.
Funny People isn't a bad movie, it's an indifferent one. No funny person wants to hear that.
It isn't Hugh and Andie or Meg and whomever, but (500) Days offers hope that Hollywood can pass that romance baton to somebody other than the crude crew of the Kappa Alpha Apatow frat house.
The digital hijinx aren't great. And despite a committed voice cast that includes two Oscar winners, the jokes aren't all that either.
A few new details about the work and the adventure emerge, but if you've seen any of the many other documentaries on Apollo, The Wonder of it All is simply covering familiar lunar ground.
It feels too slow and moody for the Halloween crowd and too absurd and silly for more discriminating horror fans.

Butler has a funny way with a line and a natural comic virility, something Heigl's previous leads lacked. But they don't click as a couple, perhaps because they're kept apart by a wordy script overloaded with blue banter.
This beyond-the-headlines war movie, a 'ticking clock' thriller from journalist-turned-screenwriter Mark Boal, is the first Iraq War movie to qualify as more first-rate entertainment than sermon.
A formulaic indie road drama.

The look of Waltz with Bashir is what is most arresting. It's a deep, multi-plane style of animation that incorporates photo-real settings, realistic renderings of the people and under-animated movement, especially of faces.
An emotional and involving installment in the hit-or-miss Harry movie series.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Well-acted, beautifully photographed and edited, it's a brisk story told with African music and universal pathos.
Departures is a loving tribute to the Japanese way of death.
A miscast and misjudged graduation-night comedy, Cooper occasionally -- only occasionally -- wanders into 'harmless.'

After you see what IBP is doing to cattle, what Tyson is doing to chickens, what farmers are doing to us and what Monsanto is doing to farmers in the new documentary Food, Inc., you may never eat again.
Too often, Br√ºno feels like Borat's weak-wristed brother, too much of it just a gay cliche aimed straight at the American bigot belt.
Whatever Works isn't deep, but with Grandpa Woody, you accept the warmed over, the recycled, just relieved he hasn't made a spectacle of himself.
Some of the jokes work. The story seems concocted by a committee of Blackberries. But the 3D CG animation is quite an improvement from the first two films.
movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Anyone doubting the role "charisma" plays in the movies need look no further than Public Enemies, an old fashioned gangster picture built on simple star power.
Frears and his Liaisons screenwriter, Christopher Hampton, give us a period piece in which the settings are fab, but the liaisons aren't dangerous, or even romantic.

More quirky than wacky, this winning comedy only hits its romantic high when we return to that framing story, the storyteller who won't casually kiss because she knows, damn well, there's no such thing as a casual 'French' kiss.
movie_title: Un Baiser s'il vous pla√Æt (Shall We Kiss?) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It all adds up to a fascinating psychological study, a film that goes beyond both the public persona and the fighter's own spin to get at the frightened, angry, explosive, yet utterly understandable boy who became a very troubled and very public man.
Away We Go makes a nice metaphor for a rootless, self-involved culture of parents trying to get it right and getting all the wrong advice as they do.
Films that present a moral dilemma and make us consider the unthinkable are as rare as bargain popcorn in the summer. Cassavetes manages that feat and turns this weeper into a keeper.
Is it the worst movie of the summer? Possibly. Will everybody see it? Probably.
Bullock's longtime fans should be happy to see her fully engaged in a role that suits her and paired, at last, with her comic equal: Reynolds.
Year One is this summer's The Love Guru, this weekend's Land of the Lost.
For a 'paranoid thriller' to work, the paranoia has to rise and rise until a climax at the finale, not give away the game halfway in.
The exotic setting and characters deserve more riveting situations than this imperfect Getaway gives them.
It's dumb. It's digital. It's derivative. This Joe, scripted at a toy-selling TV-cartoon level, is a non-stop shoot-em-up edited to induce seizures.
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: An elegy to love, fate, loss and free will, The Time Traveler's Wife is to science fiction what Twilight is to vampire tales -- a femme-centric exploration of relationships wrapped in genre fiction.
It's a picture with the ambitions of a Billy Elliot but the execution of an August Rush.

It's a film whose pleasures come slowly, as we, like the title character, discover the joys he's missed. Best of all, we, like Odd the Norwegian bachelor, figure out it is never too late to start living.
Clever one-liners don't cover the cruelty here. Jennifer is shallow. The movie about her is, too.
If only The Informant! was as giddy as its exclamation-point title, as jaunty as its corporate Muzak soundtrack -- or even as funny as its TV commercials.
Love Happens is a comedy in mourning, a romance so sad that even Jennifer Aniston at her most engaging can't save it.
A delicious farce and a backhanded slap at America the Obese, it may be the funniest animated film of the year.
movie_title: Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs (2009)

movie_review_blurb: For all its frozen blood, assaults with ice axes and killer weather, Whiteout turns out to be only a pale imitation of the thriller it might have been.
It's all cheese, but at least this cheese, for the most part, doesn't stink.
By shoving half a dozen songs -- gospel, funk and soul -- into the film, Perry shows he still hasn't mastered pace and learned to sacrifice scenes to make his movies faster and smoother.
movie_title: I Can Do Bad All By Myself (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Thirst is a grim antidote to the sanitized, pale young things of Twilight, Supernatural and True Blood.
A perfect example of a thin idea stuffed and stuffed with filler until it loses much of its charm.
This was never going to be much, but it could have been more than this.
Hilarious? No. But will you hate your kids for begging to see it? Nooooo.
What's intriguing in this set-up is what the dare might teach the guys about the nature of sexuality.
Extract is a real tour de force for Bateman, who finally has a big-screen role that plays to his Arrested Development strength -- a guy dismayed at how moronic those around him can be.
All About Steve, an unfunny, annoying, badly written, badly acted comic fiasco, may be the worst movie in Bullock's career.

It's not frightening in the least, with only a few amusing moments, a pedal-and-forehead-to-the-metal race track crash opener, and then you just keep time by counting off who survives the initial slaughter, who awaits death when "their turn" comes.
As straight sci-fi action, it packs a punch, once you get past the ick factor.
Charming, amusing and firmly anchored in a child's point of view, this movie from the master animator of Spirited Away makes a great introduction to that acquired-taste style of filmmaking.
It's a car-selling comedy that plays like a backfiring Bentley -- a shiny ride that runs in fits and starts, never quite hitting on all cylinders.
movie_title: The Goods: Live Hard, Sell Hard (2009)

movie_review_blurb: There's no edge, but if you're young enough to not know the original version of I Want You To Want Me, Bandslam may have charms enough to tickle your tweenage heart.
The film doesn't quite come off, though lots and lots of clothes do during its randy, random 97 minutes.
Inglourious is slow, dumb -- and in a first for QT in his cinema savant career -- incompetent.
Gibson tries on a Boston accent (it needs work) and boringly underplays his character before the inevitable "Mad Mel" makes his appearance in the third act.
Paper Heart gets by on easygoing charm, rather like Yi herself, whose low-fi comedy is built upon us rooting for her, perhaps hoping that surely there's more magnetism to her than this.
Post Grad is a Devil Wears Prada without the devil, a Reality Bites without any bite -- and not much reality, either.
As a movie, X-Games 3D: The Movie isn't a movie at all. It's a 90-minute commercial for the games, lacking much in the line of drama, compelling characters or story line.
World's Greatest Dad makes sharp but obvious observations about the social strata of an American high school.
Ang Lee's Taking Woodstock is a coming-of-age comedy that roams the backstage and the back-story and sees that epic concert through rose-colored glasses.
Adam is As Good as It Gets with a dash of Rain Man, movie comfort food, but still charms us through the familiar rhythms of its story.
It's not even as scary as his Halloween remake, and that one was perfunctory, at best.
Robert Rodriguez channels his inner 11-year-old with Shorts, a childish but fun wish fulfillment-fantasy for kids that's equal parts boogers, big messages and product placement.
movie_title: Shorts: The Adventures of the Wishing Rock (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's all bunk and has been for years.
This performance reminds us that Bridges is that rare actor who has never had to make that apology. Crazy Heart lets him be every bit as grand as we'd hope him to be.
There's no escaping the grinding gears of an American buddy picture that loses something in the translation.
It's the sort of movie where "finger food" is offered at a party. And it's fingers. Haw.
Sweet, sentimental, silly and star-studded, Nanny McPhee Returns is one of the best children's movies of the year, a fairytale stressed-out parents won't mind sharing with their little darlings.

The best Jennifer Aniston movie in ages is actually a star vehicle for Jason Bateman. And Aniston's work opposite the screen's premiere mild-mannered funnyman shows her at her most engaged and pitch perfect.
It contains yet another pitch-perfect performance by Robert Duvall, who has given more great performances over the age of 60 than any actor, probably ever.
A melodramatic clash of ideologies and a warm, deeply moving third act lift Mao's Last Dancer above politics and into the realm of emotion, art and beauty.
Eat Pray Love isn't a bad movie -- just a spiritually dead one, wearing and wearying.
Far and away the funniest movie of the summer.
The shootouts are epic, but the stuff leading up to them is lame.
Lujan, a veteran leading man now at an age when character roles more suit him, carries the film with a droll, understated bemusement.
Like the ongoing threat itself, Countdown is simply numbing.
It's the same movie as the earlier "gotta dance" over-choreographed crunk-and-breakdance epics. Exactly the same. Well, stripped of any hint of edge or sex appeal.
The Other Guys is a Ponzi scheme of a comedy, a buddy action picture cluttered with funny characters and hilarious moments.
Delivers its first jolts moments after the opening credits and serves up surprisingly tender moments amidst the suspense and heart-pounding action.
movie_title: The Girl Who Played with Fire (Flickan som lekte med elden) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: This chatty 3D spy spoof is as hard-pressed for laughs as Marmaduke, once you get past the novelty of "Hey, the dogs and cats are TALKING."
movie_title: Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Piranha 3D goes for the jugular. And generally misses, but generally in an amusing way.
This unblinking look at America's Red State Crystal Meth Belt is an instant Southern Gothic classic.
Like a four-star desert at the end of a hit-or-miss four-course meal, the finale is worth the wait.
There are more laughs in the average episode of Gomez's Wizards of Waverly Place TV show than in this.
Jolie's days as an action heroine may be behind her. She's still got the cruel lips. But at some point, a cookie or two needs to pass over them to give her the brawn to pull off this stuff.
It's a bubblegum mess, lacking structure, coherence,and any sense of drama. But it manages moments of daft fun, sometimes in spite of itself.

A generally joyless pastiche of sorcery history, imitation Potter "chosen one" Messianics and mirthless silliness, it's another in a string of recent black marks against Cage's Oscar-owning reputation.

A taut, well-executed if somewhat predictable riff on the murderous caper-that-goes-wrong theme that has anchored sexy, blood-stained crime pictures from The Postman Always Rings Twice to Before the Devil Knows You're Dead.
Inception is an elegant, portentous ride, though I'm not sure Nolan is any closer to visualizing the real (dream) deal than Hitchcock was.

All these years after Predator, these decades past the classic film, Most Dangerous Game, that inspired this genre, it's good to see the idea of the hunter becoming the hunted still gets the blood racing.
An intimate, quiet and even slow movie, its subtle shadings veil turbulent emotions.
Nobody can play beaten and amusing better than Reilly, and no one is better at playing broken, accessible beauty than Tomei.
Despicable Me is a 3D cartoon comedy of whiplash-quick laughs, funny punch lines and a wickedly gimmicky appreciation for 3D.

Nicole Holofcener, who writes the most interesting female characters in the movies, delivers another dazzling role to her muse, Catherine Keener, in Please Give, a delightfully dry dramedy about guilt.
The animation bar has been raised, and not just by Pixar. Poor little Astro Boy hasn't a prayer of clearing it.

The manipulations characters act out with each other are realistic, even if the overlong and not-nearly-twee-enough comedy built around them isn't, making for a movie whose script may have had more merit than its execution. Or not.
The movie's central gimmick isn't enough, and when more supernatural twists that don't play by the movie's own fantasy rules kick in, it lost me.
This colossal folly, the fiasco of the summer of 2010 - gives us all a ringside seat at the sight of Mr. "I See Dead People's" career gurgling down the drain.
Quote not available.
Mendes has made a troubling film that wrestles with big themes and touchy subjects, even if it is set in an overly familiar milieu.
Those multi-media moguls at World Wrestling Entertainment haven't quite got the hang of this "family friendly" turn they've taken with their motion picture division.
We can smell the sweat, urine and diesel fuel in Lebanon. We can taste the exhaust, the metallic tang of explosive fumes from a shell ejected from the cannon.

It's a tour de force for Norton, who fills the air with an intense and yet thoughtful patter about why Stone is in the joint, what he did, what he doesn't want to think about/talk about any more and what he thinks Jack Mabry wants to hear.
They're still here, suffering for their art. Now it's our turn.
This "family" film fails to deliver much more than good intentions and predictable conflict.
A puzzle with no solutions, a tale with a twist that isn't a twist at all.
A melodramatic kitschy Indian musical about a robot built for national defense but who discovers his human side.
It's Kind of a Funny Story really isn't so funny. Cute, bordering on cutesy, yes. Light and shallow and inconsequential in a lot of ways. But funny? Rarely.
movie_title: It's Kind of a Funny Story (2010)

movie_review_blurb: We don't care about any of the characters. They're just video game obstacles to be dispatched as graphically as possible.
Money Never Sleeps is never boring, even as its plot descends into cheap melodrama and the script runs out of banter about the "the NINJA generation -- no income, no job, no assets."
The ghost of John Hughes smiles upon Easy A, a film that freely and giddily borrows from and pays tribute to Hughes' famous Holy Trinity of '80s teen angst comedies.
As with any movie, this kids' film is only as good as its writing -- the jokes, the cute bits, the heart. And that's where Alpha and Omega comes up short.

A transgressive blend of stoner comedy, horny teenager movie and Blair Witch reality riff, this no-budget romp through teen New Orleans crosses the line and erases that line in a hell-bent pursuit of hell-bound laughs.
It's a humorless movie of morphing zombies (they take on beastly attributes), phoned-in performances and trite dialogue.
Quote not available.
The script, by actor turned writer John Posey, has structural problems and motivational issues in between the cliches. And Cena, a few movies into his career, is still all presence and no acting.
Minor, almost trite, but still worth treasuring if you're not put off by "precious."
[It does] that one thing that a romance absolutely has to do -- touch us.
It's a Hispanic American version of a blaxploitation film of the Super Fly school, with bloody action, titillating nudity and a catch-phrase riddled script.
Crisp, compact and cryptic, The American is a standard-issue hit-man thriller tailor made for George Clooney.
The performers are given stock types to play, and Elba and Dillon, at least, can do a little with that.
A modestly chilling, drawn out affair in which the characters and possible "scientific explanations" are more interesting than its predictable final destination.
A gorgeous blend of the magical and the gloriously trippy.
One of the biggest problems in most Christian genre movies is their lack of edge, a reluctance on the part of the filmmakers to show ugly reality.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
At this point in all our Middle Eastern conflicts, we need more from a documentary than just a grunts-eye-view of the frustrating nature of the war.
Quote not available.
This behind the scenes, behind the makeup, behind the plastic surgery documentary catches Rivers hard at work, ridiculously hard at work.
movie_title: Joan Rivers: A Piece Of Work (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.
It's a bit too Wonder Years at times, but the odd two-narrators gimmick plays right into the film's "flip" in structure.
The Twilight Saga comes close to that sweet spot between swooning silliness and special effects slaughter with Eclipse, the third film in the series.
Wicked, blunt writing, a great supporting cast and Douglas doing variations of other sleazy womanizers he's played make this a tart, terse treat.
These guys set out to make a movie where they could crack each other up. At this late date, they can't even manage that.

The odd engaging moment is always followed by a cloying eye-roller, such as when a nearly-new ball appears on their dusty Monterey sandlot. "Father, what does it mean?" "It means God wants us to play baseball!"

Crude, bloody and moody, Kick-Ass embraces, at arm's length, its fanboy origins. But maybe they should have decided if they loved these stereotypes, or wanted to ridicule them to death before rolling the camera.
While Letters to God is certainly family-friendly, the blandness robs it of whatever emotion or redemption the filmmakers were shooting for.
A well-acted and vivid re-creation of a dark, downbeat era when "girls don't play electric guitar," and you had to be someone pretty tough and pretty special to try it.
There's not much here that will stick with you after the popcorn's gone. But as any ancient Greek could tell you, that's sort of the point.
It's not a great film, with some edge Sparks put in the novel left out of the script. But there's real chemistry between the young lovers.
A sloppy, raucous, time travel farce in the grown-men-gone-wild Hangover style, it's a surprisingly satisfying, if not exactly LMAO, riot.

It's more coming-of-age dramedy or "everything about your world view is wrong" message movie than it is a comedy. And that seems like a waste of a funny book, some very funny actors and some darned witty animation.
This is not a bad cast, but whatever wit the script aims for is lost in the queasy details director Miguel Sapochnik found more fascinating.

Comic casting and comic timing pay off in most scenes, with Dinklage landing the big laughs, Malco doing his wise-guy-talking-down-to-the-doofus patter and Buscemi just bugging out and reacting to the craziness.
Aniston doesn't bring her old A-game to this. But at least she's not quiet and reserved and no-energy, her approach to too many roles of late.
No, we still don't believe them as a couple. No, there aren't many surprises here.
The film's tone is all wrong, the pacing is dead and the veering between sex, sadness and sado-masochistic violence is enough to give you motion sickness. It's a bad movie.
Green Zone isn't so much a bad movie as a misguided one.

As cautionary tales about consumerism go, The Joneses manages a deft blend of the sexy, the sad and the silly. And Borte doles out his secrets and surprises in ways that make it easy to keep up with these Joneses.
A broad and formulaic culture-clash comedy built on fill-in-the-blank wedding comedy clich√©s.

You can see why the actors were drawn to this -- good characters, nice monologues, a few explosive scenes. But in keeping all of them happy and still making room for his own excesses, Fuqua loses any sense of pacing.
It's not one of Polanski's masterpieces, but The Ghost Writer doesn't dilute his reputation as a master of suspense.
Purists will squeal, but it's a workable and watchable liberty to take with an oft-filmed yet impossible to film novel.

The Last Station is a moving, fictionalized account of a piece of real Russian history, a tour de force for an actor who's in his prime in his 70s and 80s, and a real return to form for a director most at home in period pieces.
The Crazies struggles to find novelty and laughs, and must battle the overwhelming sense that we've been here, seen this too often and too recently to experience any real surprises.
It feels like an homage to a period best forgotten, just a chance for all involved to sell out and cash in with a crude comedy that reminds us how bad these particular "good old days" were.
Haneke tells this tale a bit too patiently for my taste. But the metaphors are unmistakable, as is the power of the film's message.

An engaging Israeli film about the days when the people throwing rocks, assassinating soldiers and setting off bombs were Jews out to carve a state for themselves out of the British "mandate" in Palestine.
It's not bad, but as Scorsese, America's greatest living filmmaker and film history buff should know, even Hitchcock came up short on occasion.
For what it is and for whom it is intended, it's not a bad movie, just an indifferent one.
movie_title: Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Lightning Thief (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Del Toro gives his least mumbly performance in years, Blunt provides the film with a little heart and Hopkins delivers the laughs.
It's an American Love Actually without the warmth that writer-director Richard Curtis stuffs into his all-star confections, without the wit, without much love, actually.
Too many of the performances are too broad with actors hitting the jokes and the slang as if they're auditioning for a revival of Good Times or 227.
It's as pretty as a Carolina Coast postcard, as warm as a New England beach in February and as romantic as a Valentine's Day TV dinner for one.
The sleepy scenery and charming performances -- Stewart escapes her vampires and reminds everyone what the fuss used to be about -- keep The Yellow Handkerchief from blowing it.
In filling the cast with funny people, none of whom has to carry the picture, LaBute allows Tracy Morgan, Chris Rock, Loretta Devine, Danny Glover and Marsden to score without trying too hard.
The wow factor alone makes Oceans a great Earth Day/Earth Week at the movies.
If The A-Team is half this much fun, they'll be lucky.

Actor turned screenwriter Patrick O'Neill should thank his lucky stars -- both of them -- that Cruise and Diaz signed on for this. They have two of the most infectious grins in the business and their good humor puts this over.
Jonah Hex is a good performance and a few good lines buried in a script whose authors should do a little time in writer's hell for scribbling it.
Dazzling, scary and sentimental, Toy Story 3 is a daringly dark and emotional conclusion to the film series that made Pixar famous.
No, the plan doesn't completely "come together." But this A-Team is close enough for government work.
One thing Pat Morita brought to the original Karate Kid that the great martial arts clown Jackie Chan could never match -- surprise.

Writer-director Richard Squires sets us up for a feisty farce with a touch of the florid, with "crazy" Nat and the locals finding clever ways to foil the folks with the bulldozers. But Squires doesn't deliver.
There's nobody delivering the laughs in this arid action comedy.
Even by talking-critter comedy standards, Marmaduke lacks mirth and imagination.
Romantic obsession at its two extremes is explored with sympathy and intelligence in the thriller The Secret in Their Eyes...
movie_title: The Secret in Their Eyes (El Secreto de Sus Ojos) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Greek might be this year's The Hangover.
It begins with such promise, a kinky modernist twist on a classical sci-fi morality tale. That it degenerates into conventional, genre horror is all the more disappointing.
The hurtful truth is that others -- many others -- have co-opted Romero's whole living dead thing and have been doing it with more style than the Pittsburgh zombie auteur is capable of these days.
A ditzy film that offers more evidence that good actors, good action and one-liners don't solve the one thing missing in every movie video game adaptation -- a story that makes sense.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It's slower and more of an eye-roller than the first film, but also a lot more about the women.
It's really funny for about 15 minutes, mildly amusing for 30 more and a bit of a bore for its other half.

For casual race fans, Racing Dreams is a real eye-opener. And it's a darned entertaining way to get a handle on a sport that can seem like a bunch of cars doing circles for a crowd that seems most interested in seeing that next epic wreck.
Dreamworks seems bored with the ogre who laid the golden egg.

A movie that stands with the best prison thrillers from any country; a film that vividly illustrates the connection between prison and the violent, radical form of Islam that keeps much of Europe on edge.
For all the profanity (quite a bit) and sexual sass, this CBS Films product plays even more like a TV movie than its debut project, Extraordinary Measures.

It is Hye-ja Kim that carries Mother, making her mother of a Mother an all-suffering, all-enduring victim who acquires more spine and subtler shadings as the story deliberately, patiently reveals its secrets.
Director Roger Kumble began his big-screen career with a clever Dangerous Liaisons set in high school, Cruel Intentions, and worked his way down to College Road Trip and now this.
Writer-director Raymond De Felitta has cut together a frustrating comedy, with the misunderstandings piling up like kindling for a bonfire that his movie never lights.
It's a movie that starts slowly, and only starts moving us to the edge of our seat in the third act, adequate for a horror picture, but no more.
Bell, a petite, pretty blonde, may or may not have the Meg Ryan-Julia Roberts-Sandra Bullock goods. When in Rome, a leaden variation on that rom-com recipe, fails utterly to make her case.
