Pulse is the remake of a 2001 J-horror film that was derivative and pokey, even before Hollywood got its hands on it.
It's easily the best movie of the summer.
This plays like a 'Season One' DVD, silly moments interspersed with lots of dull plot and lame high-school send-up situations.
Politically correct, anatomically incorrect and ugly to look at, the only thing that saves Barnyard is writer (and director) Steve Oedekerk's gift for gags and almost-edgy humor.
This grueling trapped-in-a-cave-with-boogey-men movie is a solid thriller, and a terrific horror experience.
Night Listener draws you in to a tale well-told.

[Director] McKay has made another wildly uneven, PG-13-that-could-be-R comedy that veers from explosively funny, overlong improvs (a Southern-fried dinner prayer to 'Dear Baby Jesus') to black holes from which no laugh can escape.
movie_title: Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Scoop. It's a tired, thin, almost laughless reminder of the earlier Allen.
... the movie loses its meanness in its last third, a cop-out that robs it of the reason for making it and giving it such a nasty title
A misguided period-piece musical about gangsters, illegal 'hooch,' 'floozies' and music that is almost entirely unlike jazz.
It works as well as it ever did. It works because Mann makes it work.
One of the most educational and entertaining large-format movies ever.
[Li's] pandering to the domestic (Chinese) market with a tired, formulaic martial-arts melodrama dressed up as epic.
movie_title: Jet Li's Fearless (Huo Yuan Jia) (Legend of a Fighter) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The movie's as icy as Jack's hair, as lifeless as its animatronic, flatulent reindeer.
movie_title: The Santa Clause 3: The Escape Clause (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Catch a Fire ignites, incites and informs as few other movies of the fall do.
The premise is bogus to anybody with all their albumen intact.
It's not a deep documentary. We learn precious little about the real man underneath his sharp-dressed pose.
This is an Igby Goes Down without the laughs, a morbid miscalculation of The Life Aquatic With Steve Zissou size.
The 'God' in Conversations with God acts like a psychotherapist and talks in the buzz-phrases of self-help speak.
A meek little diversion, nothing more.
The movie comes down to Gosling's spot-on performance and how we feel about it.
A perfectly pleasant updating of the story, well-acted, nicely directed and beautifully photographed.
A terrific cast, a gloomy tone and a few well-placed little bits of magic and real history bring a long-ago time and place to life.
This is just a lark, a heavy-handed one without the heart of even the bad histories which gave us a Marie who said (as she never did) Let them eat cake.
Symbols can be moving and powerful summations of feelings. But they should never take the place of the truth.
It's a nearly tone-deaf satire of American politics and the culture of celebrity, a comedy without enough laughs, a satire without enough bite.
Infamous covers just enough new ground to be interesting, but it will always suffer by comparison.
All the King's Men is the noblest kind of film failure -- high-minded, literary, cautionary, well-cast and pretty well-acted.
Esther's triumph isn't because of divine intervention. It's her humanity and bravery that make her a legend, and make that One Night worth remembering, 2,500 years later.
The Departed is Scorsese's most entertaining picture in years, dense, violent (more of his screen sadism played for laughs), and satisfying.
Whatever that 'it' is that comic screen stars have, Cook doesn't have it. The timing isn't there, the sparkle, the Ryan Reynolds sneer. He's just bland.
Evocative as it can be, House of Sand doesn't have enough story or incident to justify the investment in time.
The movie plays like an exhausted hallucination, disjointed and frustrating, much of it owing to the lack of chemistry Gondry allows between his stars.
The wholesomeness of the message and the movie's cast make it feel 1950s retro.
A workmanlike story, an unusual setting, a game cast and a righteous message kind of get lost in the film's excesses. And an imbalance in the leads hampers this by-the-book service-academy drama.
It's not deep and not totally original. But Open Season is whiplash quick with the gags and spot-on with the funny voices.
School for Scoundrels is a simply written, perfectly cast, sneaky-edgy, stab-yourself-in-the-leg-with-a-pen laugh riot.
This is one of the best movies of the year, and one of the two or three best performances.
[Director John Gulager] shows a little flair for the genre, though the editing is so frenetic you really can't see what's going on (a blessing, considering how cheesy the monsters look and move).
A deliciously mean and fluffy little mockumentary.
A long-shelved, watchable but mediocre Mobius strip of a thriller.
The images burn into the retina like the spots you get from staring at the sun.
It's watchable, but this was an epic tale deserving of a huge canvas and, frankly, a better director and actors. And a less simplistic script.
It's as remorseless and disheartening as any of the others, more gory and less scary.
movie_title: The Texas Chainsaw Massacre: The Beginning (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A very engaging indie drama about graffiti artists in San Francisco.
For all its many shortcomings, this old-school laugher is a pleasure to sit through.
This Monster House is a real fun house. It's a 3-D animated kids' film built on classic gothic horror lines, a jokey, spooky Goonies for the new millennium.

Ron Howard doesn't so much solve The Da Vinci Code as preserve it under glass. It's a bloodless best-seller adaptation, competent but uninspiring, rather like the vast bulk of Howard's long filmography.
It's sunny and frothy, with odd laugh-out-loud moments.
Affleck plays this as a one-note turn, all dour. What a life-force like Anika would see in him is a mystery.
Just My Luck runs out of luck long before it runs out of film.
Disney goes to the sports-movie-formula well once too often with Goal! The Dream Begins, which is essentially The Rookie or The Greatest Game Ever Played on a soccer pitch.
movie_title: Goal! The Dream Begins (Goal!: The Impossible Dream) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A movie with the odd, tired joke about art and artists, a college romance that isn't romantic, and a plot twist that doesn't twist at all.
So what if it's not United 93? It's about the spectacularly perilous journey, not the people making it, not some message about an under-regulated industry and accidents waiting to happen.
It's a gorgeously mounted soap, with enough third-act surprises to justify its reputation (it was a huge hit in Latin America).
If Mission: Impossible 3 is the first pitch of the popcorn-movie season, just two words come to mind -- butter up.
This little caper yarn's as breezy as a Buffett song (he peppers the soundtrack) and as simple.
Boynton Beach Bereavement Club never aims to be much more than sweet. If only it had hit that mark a little more often.
Miller has all but smothered the charm right out of his Charm School.
movie_title: Marilyn Hotchkiss Ballroom Dancing & Charm School (2006)

movie_review_blurb: It's cinematic S&M, a bondage-control game masquerading as a thriller.
Cheesy, sappy, full of obvious slapstick and the odd Robin Williams power-improv -- it's National Lampoon's Vacation without the stupidity or the Chevy Chase.
Over the Hedge may be 'just' a cartoon. But it's also a biting and funny jab at SUV-MSG Nation.
... a delight to sit through ...
Writer-director Jessica Bendinger, an ex-model, veteran of Sex and the City and fun girl comedies, throws away more good lines than most teen comedies can muster.
It's utterly fascinating, and if you don't follow New Jersey politics, you will be kept in the dark about the outcome of this 2002 race almost to the end.
It's a marvelously entertaining history lesson -- glossy, emotional and touching.
Starting your film with a display of public incontinence isn't the best way to win over the audience.
This is solid genre filmmaking that makes up for a lack of surprises with superior performances, excellent depictions of tradecraft (shades of CSI) and whiplash editing and pacing.
American Dreamz isn't mean enough or funny enough.
A shrewdly observed slice of L.A. disconnect.
Imagine Waiting for Godot performed by The Breakfast Club.
The worst Holocaust movie ever.
So what if the story, once they get to Africa, is no better than Madagascar? It's hard to let wild predators do wild things when those wild things involve killing the other furry friends.
It is a first peek at a South Africa that doesn't need a Hollywood studio or Hollywood stars to present itself to the world, or to come to grips with itself at home.
Deliciously nasty, naughty satire.
A sometimes incisive, sometimes amateurish look at race in America, the things we do and tolerate as a nation that are really no different from an America ruled by unrepentant slave-holders.
movie_title: CSA: The Confederate States of America (2005)

movie_review_blurb: It's self-consciously clever in a not-very-clever way, a puzzle only its creator finds puzzling. It's fun to listen to, not to follow or watch.
It is a movie that takes us where we don't want to go but need to.
The charm here is in watching Shepard and Lange, and Shepard and Saint play off one another, and the leisurely pace of the 'discoveries' that aren't really secrets in the first place.
... generic and predictable ...
The Last Stand moves, it amuses a while, and it ends.
Lady is the height of folly, an endeavor as wrongheaded as The Postman, as foolish as any 'vanity' project of the past 20 years.
Linklater's willingness to experiment ... is laudable. But I'm not sure he's reinventing animation here, or even adequately serving that older-than-children animation audience.
This is the worst movie Wilson has made since he graduated from being Jackie Chan's punch line.
The effect works better than you might guess, though it's still an ugly, artless movie.
Mehta prevailed, and this scandalous, beautiful and very moving tale of repression, hope and a tragedy is her triumph, and Hindu India's shame.
A movie that is compelling and moving. It's also an artfully filmed and edited study of a real 'rhythm nation.'
A playful, informative and very sweet documentary about the world of words 'across' or 'down.'
Here's the movie to put the giddy back in the giddy-ap of summer.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The Devil Wears Prada is sassy, smart and sophisticated, a Working Girl for the new millennium.
It will get to you, if you can be gotten to.

Strip away the silly ideology of the old films, and Electric Shadows could be any movie buff's tale. It's the memory movie of our own mind, in English, Mandarin or whatever language the local Bijou screened them in.
It aims to be a Badlands for a new generation. It's closer to The O.C. with horses.
Click is perfectly watchable, sometimes funny, and occasionally even touching. But it will be better when you can see it on DVD and fast-forward through all the crummy stuff.
Waist Deep is a hip, hard genre picture that begins well, but quickly gets in over its head.
Wild Safari isn't the most original large-format movie ever, but at least it's one that's most appropriate for a museum such as the Orlando Science Center.
movie_title: Wild Safari: A South African Adventure (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Oddly reverent, faintly patronizing (they shot it in Mexico, with an exceptionally homely cast of extras), and always warm and funny.
This is an exceptionally stupid and irresponsible movie on some levels. But it does score points for style and exotic location.
movie_title: The Fast and the Furious: Tokyo Drift (2006)

movie_review_blurb: That self-indulgent documentary form, the biographical essay film, earns its most onanistic installment ever.
In Mary Harron's film biography of the nude and naughty pin-up girl, Notorious is synonymous with 'joyless.'
You'll giggle and laugh and never look at those things on your feet the same way again.
In short, The Break-Up is too accurate to be light-hearted, too light and flippant to be really romantic.
A simple moral fable told with compassion and nerve.
There's a resonance to Sophie Scholl that crosses borders and approaches the timeless.
A sober, smart and blunt environmental-catastrophe-to-come documentary.
It's not pulse-pounding. Not very often, anyway. But it is ominous and smart and more cerebral than your average horror film in these Hostel days.
By the end, it all pays off exactly the way a hundred earlier Westerns did.
It's beautiful to look at. The talking cars feel more alive than talking cars should.
The movie brings us an old-fashioned radio variety show, in all its glory, and an old-fashioned Robert Altman movie, all ensemble-and-improvisation.
It's barely coherent as it is, but at 2 hours and 23 minutes, The Lost City is simply infuriating.
It doesn't quite work, but it fails with warmth.
Just consider A Tail of Two Kitties more endurable, more a movie than Garfield: The Movie, and you won't be too disappointed.
movie_title: Garfield: A Tail of Two Kitties (2006)

movie_review_blurb: It's not meant to be uproarious. But even as comfort food, Steins can't keep up.
Cute as a boutonniere and bouncy as a swing beat, Take the Lead is an 'inspired by a true story' spin on Mad Hot Ballroom.
Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan is as fearless as mockumentaries get.
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Here's hoping that Flushed Away won't be the last gurgle from Aardman in feature-film form. Aardman shows us that animated humor, even in the toilet, can still be good clean fun.
Firehouse Dog is like that corgi or collie who won't or can't learn a trick. It just lies there, looking cute, gathering fleas.
Are We Done Yet? isn't funny or original enough to recommend. But it's amusing to watch Ice play straight-man to McGinley's perky, needy, too-helpful Chuck.
Penn is just wrong for it.
Silly as a drag queen convention and subtle as an un-flushed toilet, Blades of Glory is everything you'd hope for in a Will Ferrell comedy.
The plot is slapdash and derivative.
It's not scary, not novel.
It features a gritty, macho performance by Mark Wahlberg, stinging political commentary and more 'Here's how you do that' moments than the complete MacGuyver collection on DVD.

Awkwardly constructed, with a lame teacher-tells-a-story-in-the-future framework that gets the film off on the wrong foot. It takes a good, long while to get going, and the action doesn't exactly crackle when it does.

It has a dreadful Ghostbusters-Stargate plot, virtually no decent jokes, but toss in a little digital skateboarding, a lot of digital swordfighting (gunplay, too), a couple of 'Cowabungas,' and you've got yourself a hit. They hope.
It was a smart move, pulling Reign Over Me from last fall's release schedule. Perhaps the world just isn't ready for an Adam Sandler Oscar nomination.
It's a feel-good movie whose warmth lasts only as long as we're in the pool.

A classic 'before and after' document, terrific images of what was once there, actual footage of the storm itself, moving TV news coverage of the disaster and a conclusion that's more optimistic than it has any right to be.

Florian Henckel von Donnersmarck's film is a melodrama in a minor key, quietly affecting, quietly chilling, quietly quiet. It captures the drab architecture of totalitarianism, the soul-dead buildings of a soul-dead state.
Confusing, convoluted and yet gripping and emotional almost in spite of itself Premonition is the first movie Sandra Bullock has successfully 'carried' in years.

You go to Grindhouse for the same reasons people went to the original grindhouses primal, visceral action and primal, visceral sex (Wait'll you see how that's handled). Nobody ever went for the acting or 'the art.'
Everybody talks so fast that you'd swear you were hearing snappy banter. You aren't. Not really.
Funny and moving, and several steps above the Hallmark Channel pabulum that Fox Faith has mostly rolled out up until now.
A full-blooded, testosterone-spiked shot glass that you down in one ferocious sitting.

As with all of Minghella's films, there's intelligence and texture and depth and feeling, though here the emotions can seem frostbitten. Perhaps the first thing that wasn't working and needed to be fully broken to heal was the script.

A little cute cussing, a few decent jokes, a lot of sight gags involving spills on the bikes these 'Mild' Hogs get by on being good-natured, and willing to trade a little star power for the chance to ride and get paid for it.
A cartoonish Baby Doll, with a suggestive blues song title, about sex, guilt and redemption. Black Snake is also a rather flimsy parable unable to support the weight of Brewers ambition.
Zodiac is fascinating and engrossing and realistic and every bit as unsatisfying as real life and real police work often are.

A dreadful mismatch of indie 'arty' filmmakers and a Hollywood popcorny family formula script. The [directors] copy shots, icons and themes from The Right Stuff, but plainly never got a handle on how to make their quirky screenplay work.

Amazing Grace arrives Hollywood-slick, a polished British period piece. It manipulates, but then again, so does the song that gives it its title. Movies, like hymns and history, should give us a good cry.
The Number 23 plays a bit too much like Memento for Dummies.
Reno does manage a titter here and a giggle there. But it's a cheap, dumb, obvious movie. How cheap? The big screen never seemed so small.
It's a movie without that emotional spark that lets us connect with her, or anybody else.
Murphy, devouring a bad girl role to go with her image, makes her the most alive person in what is most certainly not your typical Hollywood serial killer movie.
The movie gives us counter-espionage without the Bourne or Bond embellishments, and superb acting from Cooper, Phillippe and Linney.
A fanciful, emotional and entertaining movie.
With Miss Potter, Renee Zellweger has won back that precious thing that stardom rips away and the tabloids won't let you reclaim: her charm.
Ghost Rider is a joke -- a monumentally foolish comic book movie with lots of unintentional laughs, mixed in with the intentional ones.
An amusing bounce through an unhappy period in American history, recalling the attitudes, fashions, politics and paranoias of the day.

The design, the limited, primitive color palette and the breathless, primal violence make Pathfinder work about as well as any movie with this director and this cast and villains who speak Norwegian was going to work.
Gracie is an engaging sports drama about a girl, a soccer ball and a family lost in grief.

Knocked Up positions itself as this summer's 40 Year Old Virgin. But it's actually this summer's Jersey Girl, a tone-deaf skip down parenthood lane for a generation that grew up on bong hits, blogging and supposedly safe sex.
This could have been a City Slickers on cycles. But it's an incredibly lazy movie, from the on-the-nose casting to the soundtrack ('70s vintage road rock) to the script to the scouting of locations.
This bittersweet romantic farce teeters and then tips into precious, a forgivable sin once you know this sweet movie's sad history.
The effects are spectacular, Knightley and Bloom have more to chew on and more romance to play, and Depp, vamping multiple versions of the ditz he created for this role, is uproarious.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Jared comes off as a plucky kid whose horizons aren't necessarily limited by the loss of his sight. They're just changed. That's the most inspiring thing in this movie. He may have been Blindsided, but he never lost his feet.
A splendid documentary thatexplores this rarefied 'crue' life of 'privilege,' pain and responsibility, all lived at the point of America's spear.
A stunningly ambitious Vietnamese-American indie film that aims to wrap up the whole of the Vietnamese experience into a Vietnamese Exodus.
Beautifully written, from an Alice Munro short story, this movie directed by an actress rarely missteps, even when it bravely includes the dark humor inherent in this situation.
It's fitfully amusing, and only 80 minutes long.

The story: Georgia 'weekend warriors' are shipped off to Iraq and somehow, between Georgia and Fallujah, the plane taking them dumps them into Mexico. No, the screenwriter didn't know how to read a map.
A frenetic killing machine -- illogical, telling in its grasp of human nature and utterly incapable of embracing the humanity it wants to show us.
Well-acted, sometimes amusing but flat-out tone-deaf.
The appalling sausage factory that produces what we see on network TV is nicely skewered in The TV Set, an engaging if not exactly edgy comedy that exists to restate the obvious.
The chills are genuine. And there's something very rewarding about sitting through a new version of a movie any film buff knows by heart.
Braff and Bateman make this patchwork just funny enough to be worth our trouble.
It's a limited movie, from the musical palette the performers choose, to the number of players the movie spends time with.
The whole house of cards collapses into an agreeable sort of predictability.
Every story is more trite and less interesting than the one before it, with Snoop taunting the viewer at every turn.
Raimi's everything-including-the-kitchen-sink third film robs the Spider-Man movie myth of its lightness. He has taken something heartfelt and witty and reduced it into just another comic-book movie.

Kazakhstan supposedly spent $40 million in making this martial-arts epic. That bought a laughably corny Hollywood B-movie, gorgeous scenery, Hollywood B-actors and extras who plainly weren't members of the Screen Extras Guild.
It's a movie in mourning, a dark comedy where we never quite see the light at the end of the tunnel.
Who says preposterous junk can't be fun?
What the bottom-feeding bottom-liners at WWE condemned us to was a cut-rate action film with a promising premise, lacking the heart or smarts to make us care.
Even if this fine French meal isn't as rich or feels a little less than it might have been, it's still delightful to sit through, course after winning course.
This rude, bodily fluid-spattered romp is like the Red Bull version of every bad buddy police picture a little Lethal Weapon, a lot of Bad Boys, and waaaaay too much Point Break.
An entertaining battle of wills and styles.
Strictly by-the-numbers horror.
It's a wistfully humorous romantic weeper with emphasis on the humorous.
To think we laughed at Boston. Then. They knew a bomb when they saw one.
movie_title: Aqua Teen Hunger Force Colon Movie Film for Theaters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Verhoeven never loses sight of the larger message -- that in those evil times, ordinary people were forced to do extraordinary, and even awful, things just to live long enough to tell their tale.
[Perry's] gotten comfortable behind the camera. And without Madea, his obese, smart-mouthed alter-ego auntie, to portray, the man in the dress shows he really can direct.
If Music and Lyrics were a song, you'd have to say it doesn't have a good beat, though it is easy to dance to.

O'Toole spent so many years being better than the little material that he was offered that it's heartening to see him sprint toward the finish of his career with such a flourish. If this is his curtain call, it's a glorious one.
"Some pig?" Sure. Some spider. And some book. Some movie, too.

For anybody who ever has been at the bottom, or feared they were headed there, it's a reminder that there's no guarantee of luck or happiness in the Declaration of Independence -- just the right to pursue it.
In today's polarized America, you pick who you stand with, even in pop culture. Kopple's film makes that choice stark...
movie_title: Dixie Chicks - Shut Up and Sing (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Director Edward Zwick is the Ron Howard of action films. Glory, Courage Under Fire, Legends of the Fall, all gorgeous looking, nicely written, well-acted and thought-provoking movies with violent settings.
Mel Gibson's Apocalypto passes the only movie test that's important. It's the 'I'd pay to see that' test.
It's a holiday farce in a minor key, suitable for the not-ready-for-PG-13 crowd, too boring for anybody else.

Any holiday movie with a dollop of sweetness and a touch of wistful deserves a little slack at this time of year. This one is pleasant enough, but The Holiday won't be one you'll remember after the eggnog has worn off.

[Arbus's] most famous images still have the power to shock, hanging as they do on the walls of the world's museums. Fur, the movie about her, reaches for that same jolt and settles instead for a raised eyebrow.
movie_title: Fur: An Imaginary Portrait of Diane Arbus (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The Rise of Taj never rises to the level of time-killer.
movie_title: Van Wilder: The Rise of Taj (Van Wilder 2) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: This one is just too obvious, almost from the title.
This is the movie Mel Gibson should have made, a simple tale simply titled and sweetly told.
It's a tin-eared movie, in many regards, history rewritten by that C-student who tries to jam too many footnotes into every character.
By the time The U.S. vs. John Lennon is done, the filmmakers have reinforced the sense that pop music once produced prophets, as well as profits.
They were going for Crossroads. They settled for VH-1 Storytellers.
movie_title: Tenacious D in The Pick of Destiny (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The experienced actors (Irons, Malkovich, Carlyle, Hounsou, and Sienna Guillory) earn the big bucks just for keeping a straight face.
Fans of Guest's brand of repertory-company character comedies will find a few reasons to grin. But even the fanatical will have to admit that this one is hardly worth considering.
The Fountain is [Aronofsky's] most accessible movie, romantic and almost straightforward until its finale.
Does anybody in Hollywood celebrate Christmas anymore? You have to wonder, with the woeful Christmas fare that has been hurled at us the past few years.
Barely worth the trip.
Robin Williams saves Happy Feet.

A serious subject; a director who loves to listen to people talk things out; and the nightmare this must have been in the editing booth, play out in front of us in 100 of the longest minutes you might ever spend in a theater.
It's not as bad as Die Another Day, and not up to the jolly mayhem of the best films in the series.
Endless scenes of the two guys riding along, venting and cursing and chugging beers play like acting-class exercises, badly written ones at that.

Nobody wants to see a violent James Bond send-up, with a British teen risking life and limb for Jolly Olde England, matched against a toothpick chomping 'computer genius' villain played by Mickey Rourke.
A Good Year is like a promising wine that's a bit new to the bottle. It goes down rough, but there's this marvelous aftertaste on the palate.
It's a great film made with style and heart and hope, a cautionary parable and an almost certain Oscar contender.
Sunny or dark, comedy should never be as predictable as Little Miss Sunshine.
Willfully eccentric, odd in tone, it is an English major's comedy, a wry exploration of plot, narrative, character and a writer's imprint on her or his work.
A simple ghost story that is, for all its faults, elegantly told, and compellingly acted.
If this genius turn by Whitaker (he starred in Bird and The Crying Game) doesn't earn an Oscar nomination, then those little statues will lose what little meaning they have.
Washington and Scott manage to make Deja Vu perfectly watchable, no matter how many times we've seen this before.
...A ringing indictment of a system that's not just broken. It's rigged and needs replacing.
movie_title: This Film Is Not Yet Rated (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Too many of the arguments are whispered, too many settings are missing the horrific atmosphere the movie requires.
Nothing that happens here is particularly touching, exciting or funny.
It has the same dramatic flatness of Love's Abiding Joy, which was made by the same filmmakers. Frankly, these folks are more suited to the Hallmark Channel.
Eddie Murphy plays three roles in his latest Nutty Professor clone, titled Norbit. And Eddie Griffin still steals his movie from him.
Rising is a movie that solves a mystery no one should want solved, with more grisly crimes that spare us no detail, held together by an actor who is no Anthony Hopkins.
There isn't much of a script to work with, and for the occasional pull-out-the-stops moment, it never really builds towards its finish.
There's a charming bonhomie among the sisters, and there are cute touches to the romances.
Terrific acting, a perfectly captured period setting, and a simple, aching farm courtship, that's all Sweet Land is.
Blood & Chocolate does offer two tiny consolations. At least it's not a vampire movie. And at least this bad German horror director isn't Uwe Boll.

Catch and Release is a perfectly likable romantic tragi-comedy, and therein lies the problem. If the essence of drama and comedy is conflict, what do you get when you wash the conflict away in an effort to make everybody 'likable'?
Pity [the producers] couldn't find anything funny to do once they'd built the sets, and found dead ringers for Anna Paquin, Paris Hilton, P. Diddy and Jack Black.
Putting Ben Affleck, and the poor man's Ben Affleck, Ryan Reynolds, in the same movie? Not a good move.

It's clever and entertaining. It's marvelously deft, but never daffy. It works well enough, despite feeling like the most conventional film this great, envelope-pushing Spanish director has ever made.
A violent fantasy set during the Spanish Civil War, this magical film from Guillermo del Toro manages that intellectual high-mindedness, even as it resonates on a primal, mythic level.

The proper way to appreciate Letters and Flags is to treat them as complimentary halves of the same epic movie, a Godfather war epic. One half is plainly more ambitious than the other, but both have virtues that distinguish them.
This cast almost makes The Good German watchable. It's just that their screenwriter and director don't do them any favors.
A stylish, jolting remake that has some of the virtues, but also the dramatically unsatisfying, amoral plot points as the original.
Don't get attached to anybody, or anything. Poor actors. They took off to make a movie in Africa and all they got was a stinking, fake-blood-soaked t-shirt.
It's big, it's beautiful, and you won't leave the theater feeling cheated, no matter how much of a letdown the finale might be.

We Are Marshall (it's the rally cry of the team) doesn't always have a handle on the grief, but it does keep emotions close to the surface. That allows McConaughey to be the most refreshing, funny and believable he ever has been.
Kids, supposedly too bored to go to such museums anymore (one of the film's messages, along with 'learn your history') should find this a Night to remember.
It's a perfectly paranoid world that director Robert De Niro chronicles in this patient, methodical thriller.

Taking a production pretty much intact from stage to screen robs it of its surprises. The cast seems to know what's coming, and so do we. There's not a single moment where you sense 'discovery' taking place.
Cedric the Entertainer is never going to be Cedric the Leading Man.
An old-fashioned great-teacher-turns-bad-students-into-scholars story that ranks up there with Stand and Deliver.
In good times and bad, for good or ill, she is the public face of her nation. Mirren, Frears and Morgan let us see just how much a burden that mask has been.

movie_review_blurb: [Writer/director Cassavetes] never masters the tone and lands as many unintentional laughs as intentional ones. But he still manages, on occasion, to chill you to the bone.

movie_title: Perfume: The Story of a Murderer (2006)

A zombie breakup movie whose best joke might be its all-the-description-you-need title.
Ambitious, smart, funny -- kind of loses itself in the violent drug trade portion of the story, but easily the most daring comedy of the summer.
A welcome return to form for Pixar, which gets back to making movies with smarts and heart.
A flat and predictable mental patient on a quest drama that hides its secrets as if we can't guess them just after the opening credits.
A good idea -- con artists using Shakespeare for their hustle -- surrounded by a lot of trite and overused ones, which then take over the movie.
A gritty over-reaching 1970s street gang history documentary that shows us the fictional "The Warriors" got it almost exactly right.
A fascinating life nicely but lightly skimmed over in the manner of a TV documentary.
Almost exactly the same story as "Jurassic Park," only "Terminator" violent and "Godzilla" dumb...a serviceable summer popcorn picture, in other words.
Pretty good, and melancholy. But it could've been great.
Touching, funny and wise. And only occasionally cloying.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Handsome, and Wasikowska shines in it. But the liberties taken with the story make one wonder if the director didn't miss the point.
The dysfunctional Duggars of Arkansas have nothing on the Angulos of New York's Lower East Side.
A haunted house horror sequel whose finale will make you cry? Rare indeed.
Ambitious, pretentious and pretty -- but falls way short of its hype.
Clever sci-fi/horror conceit, nice end-of-days setting and tone, weak acting, thin story dull dialogue.
McCarthy and Feig give up the fat jokes for a more deft, daft Bond spoof that benefits greatly from pairing her up with Jason Statham.
Re-wraps up things that the TV show already wrapped up in a nice, dull bow.
Long, handsome and sober memoir about the events that created a famous pacifist -- a little on the emotionally chilly side.
Some wonderful, out of body music creation moments thanks to Paul Dano. John Cusack isn't bad either. Pity he couldn't be bothered to lose his jet-black perma-dye job to look more like Brian Wilson.

From the dewy-eyed closeups pushing a romance that doesn't click to the insipid Hawaiian pop meant to tie this mess together -- but doesn't -- this makes you wonder if Cameron Crowe has lost it. Or was just full of it, all along.
Formulaic, but well-cast, well-played with well-executed earthquakes by the world's best effects houses. It works.
A fun, dark and sexily modern riff on "Madame Bovary," with Arterton shining in a role she was born -- or at least named -- to play.
Conventional, predictable ticking-clock thriller. But Jovovich and Brosnan are well-cast as foils, and give fair value in their roles
Khan shows that Bollywood unfiltered can be more vexing than engaging.
The novelty of having a recovering junkie star as a junkie wears thin quickly in this meandering character study/streetlife portrait.
Random, contrived and generally pointless
Fairly amusing, but more a rough-draft for a high concept high school comedy than a finished film.
A ponderous and misshapen true-crime tale from France
movie_title: In the Name of My Daughter (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Blase actors rob this of any prayer of being scary.
Ambitious period piece without the budget or the script to cover as much of the Abolition Movement as it tries to fit in.
Steve Howey, as a stoner-sage gay Hawaiian personal trainer, almost makes this worth watching all by himself.
Sad, wistfully romantic and featuring maybe the best performance Harrison Ford has ever given on the big screen.
Stately, old-fashioned and sentimental...and historically revisionist.
Zombie movies are horror's low hanging fruit, and zombie parodies the lowest of low hanging parodies. Whatever its shortcomings, hhy would anybody spend more than it cost to make this one?
Generic. Preachy. Predictable. But watchable.
Lautner? Not bad, and he does enough of his own stuntwork to make it feel real. But seriously, spend the money to cast a decent villain.
The finale, at least, gives one hope that this series will finally diverge from its YA "Hunger Games" formula in the next film.
Stark, dark, bleak and funny. Just like "Fargo."
Great tone, good acting, but this sci-fi tale of sentient robots gives away its ending pretty much at the opening credits.
A first-person shooter thriller, dark and grim, for the Just for Men/Grecian Formula set.
A darkly comic and cynical Uruguayan thriller about The Holocaust. A little loopy, but it works.
A lovely, lifeless and mirthless corpse
Nothing new to see here, not that scary either.
A "dead teenager movie" that gives teenagers, and others, a moral dilemma to ponder? Hair-raising. Literally.
A good "behind the music" genre documentary that took entirely too long to reach theaters and suffers by comparison with some of the films that it inspired.
Solid, if entirely too superficial look at the allure and downside of The Fight Game.
Tom McCarthy got stuck making an Adam Sandler movie, instead of the other way around.
"Do you believe?" No.
A bit on the nose, but Heigl hits the mark in a role that seems tailor made for her.
What little edge this tale had has been rubbed right off for this stale, slow and mirthless sequel
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: You can see the fear in Vaughn's eyes as another gag limps to its payoff, another scene fails to deliver anything but stony silence where the laugh is supposed to be.
Excruciating...They gave the "Alien" franchise to this guy?
An overly broad and somewhat random attack on a broad range of targets, but damning enough to make you mad
Informative, but there's not much fizz to this rather flat documentary about how the bubbly is bottled.
Archetypal modern Western noir... with most of its edge rubbed off.
Well-cast but botched in execution
A amusingly loathsome character, but a generally pointless picture
Considering the source, shocking sweet. And funny.
Harrowing, fanciful and beautifully filmed bio-drama built around a coy and confident performance by Kat Dennings. Deserves to be an instant cult favorite.
movie_title: To Write Love on Her Arms (Renee) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Barely passes muster
A few shrewd observations about getting old, but outdated, tone-deaf and a real waste of Gena Rowlands, Rita Moreno and Anthony Zerbe.
movie_title: Six Dance Lessons In Six Weeks (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The stakes are low -- nobody died, nobody divorced, nobody's career ended...Why was this made, again?

movie_review_blurb: An imitation of the sort of ultra-violent low-budget B-movie that Tarantino used to make, before he discovered the joys of bloat.
Narrow in focus, not terribly ambitious, but elegiac and well-acted.
Kevin Hart shoehorned into a standard issue Will Ferrell character comedy
Flat. Dull. Why was this made again?
Striking, grim, darkly funny at times. But who, exactly, is going to want to watch a movie built around graphic dog abuse?
Slow-footed "Cinderella" riff, with or without the glass slipper
Amusing, here and there, but entirely too predictable -- especially in casting Kroll as a classic Nick Kroll Summer's Eve sort of character.
Slack, lacks the urgency that you expect a kidnapping thriller to have.
We always knew Travolta's laziness as an actor would catch up with him.
The theater echoes with the sounds...of silence.
A great gimmick, but uncinematic and not as scary as you'd hope.
Hill and Franco are well-cast, but the meant-to-be-more-suspenseful film? "Capote Lite."
An engaging, kid-friendly nature doc with a hint of social commentary rolled in.
A thoughtful, quietly compelling parable set in a time of civil war.
Visceral and bloody, but too slow-footed to make it a genre classic

Bits of characters and scenes suggest a less cheesy or more breezy movie could have resulted from this.
The interpretative dance is the most passionate thing in this true story of Iranian oppression
Insipid
Austere, cerebral and chilling
Amusing, a bit on-the-nose and self-consciously clever, but it never outsmarts itself
Just edgy enough to be interesting, maybe too edgy to qualify as a faith-based drama.
Aimed squarely at eight-and-unders.
Well-cast, well-played, sharply cut...but it talks talks talks you to death in the third act

Maybe the closest Pacino will ever get to playing himself.
Wilmer Valderrama -- yes, HIM -- reinvents himself as a truly scary heavy in this brisk and biting thriller.
Hire a hitman, face the consequences. Cheap thrills and lots of dark surprises.
Sometimes funny, often just cringe-worthy
When it comes to casting Fannings, if you can't get Elle, no Fanning is better than any Fanning available.
Head-slappingly stupid
Great story, cliche-clogged script.
A faith-based swashbuckling Revolutionary War period piece that doesn't have the wit or the budget to quite come off.
Fascinating, but almost as chaotic and disorganized as the band itself

Dull and undramatic
Violent and on-the-edge of funny, "Fargo Lite," right up to the end, where the wheels come off.

Flip, funny and sentimental. Not "Man on Wire," but not bad, either.
Cute.
Roughly twice as many laughs as the original. Still not enough, though the little kids will giggle.

One long Mexican testicle pun, with cockfighting as its punchline. Marketed to children. Um, no, amigos, no.
The laughs come from the vintage bits, and there's a little missing context. But any documentary that humanizes Chevy Chase is a movie making miracle.

movie_review_blurb: Mostly taut, well-cast and well-acted thriller let down by the faith-based infomercial that concludes it.

Quite good, but not quite the first "great" movie of the fall.
Cynical, slow and deathly-dull.
The only original writing screenwriter Tyger Williams managed was that adorable first name he invented for himself.

Deeper than a mere "laugh at the stupid hillbillies" documentary.

The best picture of 2015. Certainly the most important.

Wrenching
