A delightful and heartwarming cinematic treat.
"The Darjeeling Limited" is director Wes Anderson's ("The Royal Tenenbaums") latest vision of flawed relationships.
"Bee Movie" has a little bit of something for everyone. It's loaded with action and sight gags for the kids and enough adult humor to keep the grownups happy.
Cutting right to the chase, Faster seldom slows down.
Diane Lane delivers one of the finest performances of her career.
Falling short of a mind-blowing experience, Megamind is still fine family entertainment that doesn't require deep thinking.
Just the ticket for fun at the movies, Unstoppable is a non-stop joy ride.
Tangled puts a happy twist on a grim tale.
Strictly for the hardcore fans, "Sex And The City 2" may not be in vogue for long.
The exciting "Knight And Day" is a blast that stays in Cruise control.
For the non-fan moviegoer, a true blood transfusion may have helped this slightly anemic soap opera.
These toys are unbreakable - in a series that will last to infinity and beyond!
"Robin Hood" is a jolly good show, with spurts of violence for the guys and just a hint of men in tights for the gals.
Staying close to its roots, "The Losers" won me over.
There is an environmental message delivered along with the goofy mayhem involved in catching the fuzzy culprits. But fair warning: once inside the theater, the audience is trapped.
A crowning achievement that's sure to be the talk of this awards season.
It's nice to have Jennifer Lopez back on the big screen - delivering the lines and handling the slapstick with ease. Here's hoping she has a hit on her hands and doesn't need a back-up plan.
"Angels & Demons" earns its wings as an intelligent action movie.
The movie's tagline "The End Begins" could be prophetic for the theatrical series - it may or may not be back.
Destined to become a sci-fi classic, "Star Trek" boldly goes where none of the previous entries have gone before.
Practically perfect in every way, this is Pixar's most uplifting adventure yet!
"The Hangover" will induce headaches - from laughter.
It was powerful, thought-provoking and held my interest right up to the end.
Thoroughly delightful and entertaining, this is exactly the type of movie Walt Disney would make if he were alive today.
It is a joyless rehash of old plots and jokes. File "Fred Claus" under lump of coal.
"Beowulf" is an astounding, eye-popping 3-D makeover of the ancient Old English tale. If you have a choice, go see the 3-D version for added depth. "Beowulf" is a monstrous treat.
"Mr. Magorium's Wonder Emporium" lacks sparkle and wonder.
"August Rush" is a familiar, yet entertaining experience that works mostly because of the wonderful cast and the haunting mix of music.
"Things We Lost In The Fire" is an overlong downer that crumbles under the relentless strain of anger and grief.
movie_title: Things We Lost in the Fire (2007)

movie_review_blurb: "Iron Man 2" rocks!, with no signs of rust in the series' armor.
The super-charged 'Captain America: Civil War' is a winner.
While not perfect, 'Rules Don't Apply' is a welcome break from big screen violence. As a king of Hollywood royalty, Warren Beatty still rules.
'X-Men: Apocalypse' has enough going for it to keep this series from becoming X-tinct.
Halle Berry's believably fierce performance and some outrageous chase sequences keep this mindless and mildly entertaining "B" movie from totally veering off the road.
'The Dark Tower' fails as a shining example of King cinematic adaptations.
A striking dramatization blended with graphic newsreel footage makes this an absorbing and, at times, harrowing experience.
With Charlize Theron in fine form, 'Atomic Blonde' is a blast.
Director/writer Christopher Nolan masterfully revives the classic war film with an edge-of-your-seat, emotionally-charged thriller.
With the spaced-out 'Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets', Luc Besson remains in his element.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Swinging into theaters, 'War for the Planet of the Apes' is thought-provoking escapism.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This refreshing new spin on the Spider-Man legend is fun and lighthearted with a few thrills along the way.
Driven by an infectious soundtrack and revved up action, 'Baby Driver' is a gas!
Total Bayhem, this bombastic event is a knight to forget.
The freewheeling 'Cars 3' keeps the series on track.
Frenetic action and some ghoulish effects make this anemic thriller a mindless piece of popcorn fare.
Gal power whips up a roaring adventure.
'Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales' is indeed see-worthy.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Thrills, chills and buckets of gore add up to a bloody good show.
Boisterous humor and good chemistry between the two stars give this predictable comedy an entertaining boost.
Style over substance dethrones this cinematic heir to the royal legend.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: I am Groot! 'Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2' is a rousing and rollicking galactic trek.
High-speed chases fuel another frenetic entry in this indestructible series.
The appealing 'Colossal' is a gigantic leap forward for originality.
Strong performances overcome this cliche-ridden drama for a truly emotional and rewarding experience.
'The Boss Baby' is formula, but not as infantile as the title suggests.
The tedious 'Ghost in the Shell' lacks spirit.
The remarkable true story of the ≈ªabi≈Ñski family's courageous efforts in Warsaw is effectively dramatized in this inspirational film.
The thrilling and scary 'Life' won't be the death of this genre.
Rich in outdoor adventure, 'Wind River' overflows with tense drama.
As a revealing and edgy sequel, 'T2 Trainspotting' is right on track.
Action, humor and the stars' chemistry keep 'The Hitman's Bodyguard' on target.
Horror and a dash of humor keep this Goonies-style chiller afloat.
With 'Sing Street', John Carney once again is pleasantly tuned in to the music scene.
More darkness than light, 'A Wrinkle in Time' has much to iron out.
Relevant in today's climate, an intelligent spy drama takes wing in 'Red Sparrow'.
Dark humor and an appealing cast keep this engaging game in motion.
Director Nick Park and those creative folks at Aardman Animations have carved out another toothy, gag-filled claymation treat.
The wildly enjoyable 'Black Panther' claws its way to the top of the Marvel Universe.
The kid-friendly 'Peter Rabbit' merrily hops along.
Impressive action sequences can't save this series' final chapter that has a very familiar plot and is void of heart and soul.
'12 Strong' finds its strength as a flag-waving, stand-up-and-cheer movie.
Annette Bening lights up the screen in this stunning portrait of a fading star.
movie_title: Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Overflowing with heart and humor, this delightful romp is a charmer for the whole family.
This tuneful, joyful and emotional spectacle is filled with razzle-dazzle and wonder.
The forceful 'Star Wars: The Last Jedi' is a cinematic triumph.
Solid performances can't overcome an anemic plot that's void of any sympathetic characters.
Mexican lore and culture spring to life in this dazzling and delightful animated spectacle.
'Justice League' is super-charged fun!
This tense thriller is a gripping character study with bursts of violence.
A stellar cast and lush scenery make this latest filming of Agatha Christie's 1934 novel an entertaining, if not riveting, journey.
Miles Teller's dominant performance drives this emotional drama.
'Only the Brave' is an uplifting, courageous and ultimately heartbreaking salute to these heroes.
This captivating real-life courtroom drama is a winner thanks to Chadwick Boseman's multi-layered portrayal of the nation's first African-American Supreme Court Justice.
Director Denis Villeneuve's visual stunner deftly expands the 'Blade Runner' universe.
Tom cruises through this high-flying biography in top form.
Over-the-top performances and graphic comic book violence enhance the spy jinks of this amusing sequel.
Good performances and bloody action give this popcorn thriller a shot in the arm.
Soderbergh rolls the dice with 'Logan Lucky' and comes up with a winner.
'Beauty and the Beast' magically transforms from animation to live-action in grand fashion.
Some laughs, twists, surprises and good performances freshen up the familiar plot.
The darkest and arguably the best of the Wolverine adventures is an emotional journey that's marked by bursts of bloody violence.
Fashion designer Tom Ford, who wrote the screenplay and directed, has stitched together a romantic thriller where parts are more satisfying than the whole.
With an entertaining nod to 'Sixteen Candles', 'The Edge of Seventeen' edges easily into Hughes territory.
Briskly-paced, the whimsical and thrilling 'Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them' is bewitching.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: There's much to like in "Loving", a historical true-life drama that is relevant today.
It doesn't take a Sherlock to see that 'Doctor Strange' successfully sends the Marvel Universe spinning in a mystical new direction.
Cutting right to the chase, this matinee thriller is an adrenaline rush from start to finish.
Delivers just enough excitement and suspense to ensure that Reacher will come back again.
Without Affleck's impressive performance, 'The Accountant' wouldn't total much more than a standard crime thriller.
A knockout performance by Emily Blunt saves this effective, but predictable, thriller.
A tense buildup and a frenetically-paced final act combine for a fitting tribute to those who perished and the survivors of the disastrous oil rig explosion and resulting spill.
Explosive action and a good cast make Antoine Fuqua's exciting reboot a western worth seeing.
Ron Howard's pitch-perfect documentary is a fabulous love letter to past, present and future fans of the Fab Four.
movie_title: The Beatles: Eight Days a Week - The Touring Years (2016)

movie_review_blurb: 'Sully' deserves to fly high on the radar during the awards season.
'Hell or High Water' bristles with true grit.
It's impossible to top William Wyler's 1959 cinematic spectacle and this fact is proven once again.
Some killer performances rise above an anemic and predictable story in this DC Comics antihero film.
Non-stop action almost makes up for a thin plot in this spy thriller.
Based on the popular British television comedy series, this big screen version is an overblown barrage of jokes, sight gags and fashion.
This well-paced outer space adventure is a glowing tribute to the iconic television series.
Brimming with whimsy, but not afraid to enter dark territory, 'The BFG' is a Bedazzling Fabulously Grand adventure.
Some explosive action sequences and a dynamic performance by Matthew McConaughey elevate this long, but interesting, cinematic piece of Civil War history.
From start to fin-ish, 'Finding Dory' is unforgettable.
Overflowing with action, adventure, awesome effects and a logic-free story, this sci-fi sequel will satisfy its target audience.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: This sequel to Tim Burton's 2010 dazzler is also a visual spectacular filled with magical nonsense.
'Kong: Skull Island' reigns as prime matinee fare.
A wonderful tale of the South Pacific, 'Moana' delivers oceans of family fun.
With a sack full of coal, 'Bad Santa 2' is number one on the naughty list.
In the tradition of Disney's best live-action features, this charming re-imagining is a grand family adventure.
Revealing her strength during the end of the presidential Camelot, 'Jackie' is a royal depiction.
Peele has much to say about society and race with an inventive approach that blends chills with a dash of humor.
A strong, heartbreaking performance by Shia LaBeouf can't make up for a confusing and disjointed plot.
Massive sets, lavish costumes, outstanding special effects and a cast of thousands can't keep this wannabe epic fantasy from tumbling down.
Strong performances by David Oyelowo and Rosamund Pike raise the quality of this by-the-numbers look at a fascinating true-life story.
The tortured romance of 'Fifty Shades Darker' is just another big tease.
'John Wick: Chapter 2' is wickedly entertaining.
Fine performances by Asa Butterfield and Britt Robertson make this a pleasing little romantic adventure with a touch of sci-fi.
Aimed squarely at dog lovers, this sugary tearjerker misses the mark - but not by much.
Director/writer M. Night Shyamalan returns with a chilling and disturbing slice of psychological horror.
'xXx: Return of Xander Cage' plays fast and furious, but not smart, with moviegoers.
As a thrilling, emotional and reverential experience, 'Patriots Day' goes the distance.
Director Ben Affleck, who also wrote the screenplay based on Dennis Lehane's crime novel, has crafted an almost epic gangster film with mixed results.
This mystical coming-of age drama is thoroughly engaging from beginning to end.
'The Lego Batman Movie' is a well-constructed laugh-fest.
If you're searching for fulfilling feel-good entertainment, the royal 'Lion' exceeds expectations.
While 'Miss Sloane' may not exceed expectations, Jessica Chastain's performance is worth lobbying for during awards season.
With its by-the-numbers storytelling, 'Hidden Figures' has all the right stuff to enlighten the audience.
Explosive action, interesting characters and a compelling story make this stand-alone movie in the Star Wars universe a winner all the way.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Director/writer Damien Chazelle reinvents the Hollywood musical with style and class.
This boisterous comedy may not be art, but there are much worse ways to spend a couple of hours.
As harmless family fun, the melodic 'Sing' stays mostly on-key.
Fine performances, especially an award-worthy turn by Helen Mirren, are hampered by a disjointed story that never fully comes together.
Chemistry between the two stars keeps this anemic sci-fi romance from being entirely sucked into the black hole of forgettable films.
'Assassin's Creed' is increedibly bad.
About that bathroom humor, 'Why Him?' deserves to be flushed away.
Denzel Washington brilliantly translates August Wilson's Pulitzer-Prize-winning play to the big screen.
Does Werner Herzog know what documenting these stories can do to a man? These stories of tragedy and hope and loss that he learns about, staring into eyes just as insane as his...
Train to Busan is one of the best surprises of the year; a redemption tale that reminds us how close we are to losing our humanity, but also the compassion we are capable of. All aboard.
It took substantial self-control to resist making fire jokes, but it's now or never, so here goes. Inferno, despite the best efforts of an always-dependable Tom Hanks, burns up in a raging fireball.
Alas, even Leonardo DiCaprio can't survive this apocalypse.
Oh Batman: Return of the Caped Crusaders, what have you done? You were supposed to be a kitschy throwback to 50 years ago, a gleeful POW! in the face of a brooding Batfleck, but you're so much more.
movie_title: Batman: Return Of The Caped Crusaders (2016)

movie_review_blurb: No Tom Cruises were harmed in the making of this film.
Like George A Romero, Christopher Guest has been overtaken by the films and TV his work inspired.

Amanda Knox is put together like a sleek thriller - complete with a grizzled, I'm-too-old-for-this-s#!t lead investigator who likes 'detective movies', and can be found, guilt-ridden, in cathedrals, often with a forgotten pipe dangling from his mouth.
This movie is as much a romantic homage to the melodramas of the past as it is a radical, path-breaking piece of modern filmmaking. It is one of the best films of the year.

13th has the urgency of a last-ditch attempt, a final warning sign before the road forks into uncharted, dangerous territory. It is a great film. It's streaming on Netflix, where it'll exist forever. You have no excuse to not watch it.
You can't really fault a film for a lack of ambition if it doesn't pretend to have any in the first place, can you?
The film rests upon the more-than-worthy shoulders of Denzel Washington - who brings his trademark strut, iconic slouch, and a cocked gun paired with that legendary cocked head.
It bites.
If only the same care that has gone into its visuals were put in the rest of it, Doctor Strange could've been a trippy, psychedelic adventure, and not a middling entry in a 14-film-old franchise.
Don't Breathe is a beast of a movie - it's tight, relentlessly thrilling, fiendishly clever, and for its audience, it's one of the most satisfying films of the year.
Spare a thought for poor Laura Linney, whose only co-star in this film is a landline telephone. But Tom Hanks? He's the real American hero - even in the movies.
In its own weird way, Miss Peregrine might be one of the most personal movies Tim Burton has made in his career.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Welcome, dear Mexicans, to the United States of Donald Trump.
Brad Pitt, that Inglourious Basterd, is hunting Nazis again...
Watching Fantastic Beasts is like being guided by Rowling herself, our hand placed gently in hers, in a world that is as warmly familiar as it is excitingly fresh.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Donald Trump could learn a thing or two about walls from this...
Unless you've ever found yourself wondering what it would be like to watch Jackie Chan dance to a Mongolian tribe's cover version of Adele's Rolling in the Deep, you needn't suffer Skiptrace.
It's like being eaten to death by infected zombies.
Kill it before it lays eggs.
In Live by Night, Ben Affleck finds every imaginable way to shoot his own film in the foot - and then light a match and set fire to the gaping wound, as it hobbles away into oblivion.
It's a different kind of beast; one of those rare films that could very well draw whoops and cheers from certain audiences, and at the same time, it's equally possible that it puts the rest to sleep.
To have captured grief with such raw honesty, not just the confusion, but also the rage, is where Bayona has knocked it out of the park.
Being a war hero isn't enough. The power of celebrity Trumps everything. Billy Lynn's Long Halftime Walk: Made in America. By an immigrant.
It's sort of like the Matrix, but with all the philosophical heft of a Trojan virus.

You have been wronged far too often, I know; the movies have wronged us all. They have stood us up, left us alone on rainy curbs, but you must put your faith in them, one last time. You must run to La La Land.

Barry is for all the lost souls getting punched by strangers in alien hallways, it is for all the wanderers with nowhere to be. It captures the beautifully conflicted dumpster-fire that the world is right now.
Deepwater Horizon is a solidly-crafted disaster film, with fine American actors performing a quintessential American story - a story of corporate greed and everyday heroism.
It is a truth universally acknowledged, that a sports movie in possession of a good story, must be a boxing movie.

Moana is a terrific Disney movie; vibrant, joyful, with great music and enthusiastic performances. It is steeped in tradition, both of its many legendary predecessors and the colourful culture it celebrates.
Awarding it a bag-full of Oscars come February would be too puny a recognition, too inconsequential; it deserves to be shown in museums, to governments, in schools. Missing it should be outlawed.
For a film designed for an audience that will unlikely be able to purchase its tickets with their own money, Nerve is a surprisingly solid, if derivative teen thriller.
We must trust this series, a series that made us fall in love with scruffy-looking nerf herders, trigger happy fuzzballs and pessimistic droids. We must trust the Force.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: BTW, WWJD? JK, LMFAO XOXO.
Mastizaade isn't a movie. It's a bunch of sweaty sleazeballs exploiting Sunny Leone's star power and straight up robbing your cash. Don't let them.
When it is all said and done, summer 2016 won't be remembered for the unending DC vs Marvel feud. It will be remembered for films like Pete's Dragon.
Room is an ephemeral moment in time and I will always remember it with fondness because there's no way in hell I'm watching it again.
This movie can go to hell.

In the Heart of the Sea works as a survival drama, a rip-roaring adventure and even a monster movie, but what it really accomplishes, like Interstellar, is to remind us that once upon a time, humanity was unflinching in its thirst for discovery.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: In his misguided attempt to make what he surely believes is a tribute to an entire gender, David O Russell lost sight of only thing he shouldn't have: Joy.
The Danish Girl is the cinematic equivalent of a half-hearted shrug, the movie version of a really long sigh.
It looks the clich√©s right in the eye, brings them in for a warm bear hug, and slyly sinks a katana in their unsuspecting backs.
It's true that not many were pleading for a Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon sequel, especially one that arrived about 15 years too late, but they made one anyway, bless them.
movie_title: Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon: Sword of Destiny (2016)

movie_review_blurb: 10 Cloverfield Lane is a three-act stage drama masquerading as a psychological thriller, which, by the time act three rolls around, evolves into a whole different kind of beast.

Michael Bay's retelling of the Battle of Benghazi lives up to its name, because when the last man falls to the ground, limbs gruesomely ripped apart, it feels like you've been watching it for half a day.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Gavin Hood has created a near-perfect anti-war thriller that culminates with one of the most tightly-wound scenes you're going to see this year.
Why must movies be hopeful? Why must they uplift? Why must they make promises they can only temporarily keep? And why do we fall for them, every time?
This is what happens when an overexcited studio exec's buddies tell him strong female characters are all the rage these days.
The film has its moments, but there comes a point when you can't justify it to yourself any longer. There is only so much grim brooding one movie can accommodate.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The film, pun fully intended, is an ungodly mess. What could have been an adventurous buddy comedy, an old-fashioned, Ben-Hur style epic, or a knowingly deranged B-movie ends up being an early contender for the worst film of the year.
Howard Hawks was the one who described a great movie as one that had 'three good scenes and no bad ones.' Every scene in Sicario, the new film by Denis Villeneuve, is better than the last.
You'd be better off watching that cursed Samara video.
Luckily, we already have our seminal Armstrong movie in The Armstrong Lie. And it is not, as the blandly titled The Program would have you believe, about a lunatic drug addict with a God complex.
They put Morgan Freeman in a Bob Marley wig didn't they? They did. The put Morgan Freeman in a Bob Marley wig.
With Special Correspondents, Ricky Gervais proudly strides into the Adam Sandler phase of his career.
X-Men was always about the outcasts, the misfits, the ones beaten down. It's unfortunate then, that Apocalypse spends so much of its time trying to fit in.
I'm bad, and that's good. I will never be good, and that's not bad. There's no one I'd rather be than me.
Get some rest Jason. You look tired.

This is from Tallulah/ Just like Johnny Flynn said/ The breath I've taken and the one I must to go on/ Put the grenade pin in your hand, so you understand who's boss/ My defeat sleeps top to toe with her success
You. Yes, you, reading this. You don't deserve Steven Spielberg.
More than anything else, Ghostbusters is just a quirky, goofy, loud, immature tribute to the movie we all love so much. So let's stop those angry tweets now, yes?
Star Trek Beyond lives up to its title: It goes above and beyond what was expected, and, like its predecessors, turns out to be the best blockbuster of summer 2016.

Ice Age: Collision Course can potentially have a similar effect on kids as raising them exclusively on 10 hours of TV, 2 litres of soda, one block of cheese and unlimited, unrestricted Internet per day might.
This isn't a particularly intelligent film, and I think it knows that. But if you accept it for what it is - a pulpy B-movie - you're in for an immensely satisfying time.
It's like that childhood friend of yours that kept giving you the most disgusting dares in a round of truth or dare, mocking you for not having the courage to follow through.
Think of it like a John Green adaptation directed by James Ponsoldt and scored by Arcade Fire; filled to the brim with clich√©s. But clich√©s exist for a reason.
Just like Quentin Tarantino with feet and Nicolas Winding Refn with hands, Roland Emmerich too has a fetish. It involves CGI.
I've now sat through all but one of Jon M Chu's 7 films. His best remains his first Justin Bieber documentary (he's made two). Need I say more?
Perhaps the best metaphor for this movie is its own ghostly antagonist: A 72-year-old curmudgeonly pensioner named Bill who died watching TV in his old armchair.
Warcraft is a film made with love. It is unafraid to be nerdy, it laughs in the face of mockery. It is, for better or for worse, the best video game adaptation that I have ever seen.
The Nice Guys makes you want to catch hold of the first random stranger unfortunate enough to cross your path and demand that they drop everything and watch it.
It might be damning with faint praise but Alice Through the Looking Glass works better than Tim Burton's original. And if I were a kid, that would be enough.

"He's Tarzan, you are Jane. He will come for you." There couldn't have been 10 more perfect words to sum this movie up. And Christoph Waltz, bless his one-trick act, delivers them with just the right amount of smug venom.

For a children's movie - one that is essentially about plastic toys pounding each other into the Phantom Zone, which also includes a Z-list villain named Condiment King (he shoots ketchup and mustard out of special guns, duh) - it's pretty terrific!
Dunkirk, a film about men, created by men, is a force of nature - an elemental beast of a movie about finding the meaning of life surrounded by the meaninglessness of war.
Life had been scraping along before Chiron was born, and it will likely keep trudging towards an overdose once he is gone. Moonlight is the story of a lifetime, a worthy Oscar contender.
Dwayne Johnson makes Robin Williams proud.
Where there is a Will Smith there is a way.
A profound spiritual experience.
It could - and I know this is stepping into some very murky conspiracy theory territory - be one of LaBeouf's elaborate performance art pieces to exonerate himself - in which case, well played, sir.
In which alleged domestic abuser Mel Gibson encourages a child to commit sexual assault.

Not only has Kenneth Branagh retained the exotic romanticism of Christie's novels, he has found dimensions to the Dame's stories that I - despite being a tremendous fan of her books - had never expected, and honestly, never even thought of.

For better or for worse, Justice League is the sum of all its predecessors' parts; as grand as Man of Steel, as murky as Batman v Superman, as messy as Suicide Squad, and as optimistic as Wonder Woman.
The problem with Insidious: The Last Key is that it simply doesn't have the slightest enthusiasm to muster up something fresh for its fans.
Calling it a broad comedy would be like fat-shaming an entire genre.
Feels like Gerard Butler repeatedly yelling 'This is Sparta' at your face for 2 hours.
Wheelman is paced like a juiced up F1 car, racing through its roughly hour-and-fifteen-minute run time with barely any pit stops.

1922 is a terrific example of just how powerful horror movies can be. Not only does writer-director Zak Hilditch employ a gorgeous, psychological slow-burn approach to the storytelling, he punctuates it with sudden bursts of visceral horror.
Finally, the hot girl next door running a Satanic sex club movie we were all waiting for.
The best Adam Sandler film since 2009's Funny People. Would it be too weird to begin an Oscar campaign?

Obnoxiously, it slaps you on the back, barks some nonsense about the good old days, and laughs loudly at its own jokes. But behind those sparkling white teeth, there is a snake's tongue. Beneath that immaculate exterior, there lies a bitter heart.
With this, there can be little doubt that Denis Villeneuve is one of the greatest science-fiction filmmakers ever - right up there with Kubrick, Fritz Lang, and Nolan.

Everything from the font used in the titles, to the synth-infused rock opera score by Mark Mothersbaugh, to the gloriously retro set design and visuals clearly inspired by the art of Jack Kirby, there is no Marvel movie quite like it.
It is possibly too early in his career to tell, but there aren't many filmmakers who display in their films the empathy Ritesh Batra does in his.
Ridley Scott just made history, and you need to witness it.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The Post is a brave movie - perhaps even braver than its biggest inspiration, All the President's Men.
It's one of the most stunning displays of directorial vision in recent memory, sure to be a classic of the genre in the years to come.
Angelina Jolie would be slightly envious of Alicia Vikander's Lara Croft. That being said, the film feels like a gruff handshake when it should have felt like a warm hug.
Saoirse Ronan, 23, has three Oscar nominations already. What have you been doing with your life?
The worst thing to happen to Justin Theroux this week.

Three Billboards not only aspires towards greatness, but confronts it, screams at it, and when it has everyone's attention, revels in it. It's a profane and profound masterpiece that will evolve into a time capsule of sorts, when things get better.
This is a Christian Bale performance that will likely be forgotten amid the dozens of louder ones he's delivered, as will this movie, but that is perhaps what makes Scott Cooper such a rarity.

They will write about this movie and make videos about it, it will be discussed among friends of all ages, all races, all shapes and sizes; it will be taught in school, debated among intellectuals, it will be seen as the moment everything changed.
Right now, Downsizing is ahead of its time, understandably rejected by audiences (and in an unbelievable betrayal, also by the critics). They should pick on someone their own size.

The Shape of Water is the world as Guillermo del Toro sees it - full of injustice, but also, crucially, decency. Where others see pain, he sees hope, where others see fear, he sees compassion, where others see monsters, he sees friends.
Who needs real actors when all Clint Eastwood wants to make is propaganda?
This is John Wick we're talking about. It is said that he once killed three men in a bar with a pencil (a pencil!).

Phantom Thread is an oddity. It's a movie about love and obsession and obsessive love. It's Freudian and sadomasochistic, and for one glorious moment, almost passes off as director Paul Thomas Anderson's answer to Fifty Shades of Grey.
Just when you were about to brace yourself for your bi-annual abusive appointment with Gerard Butler, he went and did the best thing he's done in years.

Is this as disappointing as the final Hunger Games movie? No, it most certainly isn't. Is it as bad as one of those Taylor Lautner solo vehicles? Nope. But is that a reason to recommend it? For the third time, no.
Gary Oldman delivers one of the finest performances of his career in director Joe Wright's technically brilliant but narratively flawed companion piece to Christopher Nolan's Dunkirk.
Liam Neeson reunites with director Jaume Collet-Serra for the final action movie of his career. We're going to miss his unique set of skills.

The Ritual is the finest, pure horror movie since Get Out. And if we're being even more traditional with our definitions, you'd have to go as far back as 2015's The Witch to make a suitable comparison.

There's an energy to the flight sequences that I haven't seen since Cruise was screaming about 'the need for speed' more than two decades ago. And there's a jittery, almost cocaine-addled pace to the story.
A painfully bad film that's a pockmark on JJ Abrams' (and Netflix's) legacy.
Like a Charlotte Bronte adaptation directed by Nicolas Winding Refn. Utterly brilliant.
Johnny Depp is adrift at sea, shipwrecked aboard a sinking vessel, drowning in a typhoon of CGI murkiness. Savvy?
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The only realistic situation in which these... Aliens... would even bother to waste a reflex glance in our direction would be if Trump accidentally lobs a nuke at Texas. But anyway, Michael Fassbender kisses Michael Fassbender in this movie!

The soundtrack has bigger hits, Groot is an even bigger scene-stealer, and the villain problem has been solved. But it's all a means to the heart of the story: Family. And not that Fast & Furious nonsense either.

There's a good chance you might forget Sand Castle exists moments after watching it, much like how the world seems to have forgotten the massive scandal that the Iraq War was, now that every day basically begins with a chance of it ending in nuclear war.
For a film in which Arnold Schwarzenegger's character loses his entire family in a tragic plane crash, it chooses to open with a dig at Donald Trump.
The strangest, darkest, most outlandishly bizarre entry in the series.

It does offer, in addition to all the cool visuals, one of the purest forms of joy available to a movie fan: The sight of the great 'Beat' Takeshi Kitano, gunning down fools in a dank, vaguely Asian alleyway, dripping in neon haze. Yes please.

No actor plays dimwits quite like Brad Pitt. And they aren't just regular old dimwits: They're the sort of bafflingly idiotic, all-star dimwits you couldn't picture using a spoon properly, let alone solving that pesky Middle East crisis.
Anne Hathaway has monsters in her closet. Watch, as she kicks them in the nethers.

The movie is, to put it plainly, like a mutated clone birthed in a secret government lab using smuggled Alien DNA. But it's made with such well-oiled precision, delights in such gleefully claustrophobic chills, it's difficult to resist.

It is uncompromising in its brutality and fearless in its reverence of these iconic characters. It's a testament to the power of storytelling, and what creative freedom can produce. Goodbye bub. You've changed superhero movies forever.
It's the anti-Trump movie America needs right now.
Thank God Lion exists. We need more films like it, like Slumdog, to shame us into being better by showing us our worst, and to inspire us into being brave, by showing us our best.
I let out an audible gasp at the end. That has never happened.

Faith. Why must we have it? Must we have it at all? And do we - can we - comprehend it? There are no simple answers to this, and perhaps that is why Scorsese is still making movies. Silence is yet another masterpiece.
Nothing about this film could inspire serious discussion - not even its ah-I-see-what-you-did-there ending, telecast, of all places, on Fox News.
To borrow the motto of my favourite caf√© in my favourite hilly town, "There is no good explanation for what is happening here..."
It boasts unpardonably terrible CGI, even worse green screen effects, and the maturity of a 12-year-old boy whose internet privileges have been revoked.
Despite stunning visuals and a fine cast, Kong: Skull Island is, well, crushingly monkey brained.

Cars 3 was the underdog, coming from behind, facing shiny new competition. It was betrayed by its own family, and challenged by Gru. But it saved its best for last. In its final lap, it won. It became the first film in the series Pixar should be proud of.
Perhaps it'll take her a few more films, but it is my firm belief that one day Angelina Jolie will make a great one. She's almost there.
Categorically the worst movie of Tom Cruise's career.
It is funny and warm and touching and frightening and profane and profound. It's one of the best horror movies of the year. You'll float alright.
Kidnap is a shoddily-directed movie - filled with ADHD editing, ridiculous twists, and a tone that irresponsibly swerves between gritty thriller and Road Runner cartoon.
Matthew McConaughey walked into a terrible movie, and Idris Elba followed.
Annabelle: Creation borrows heavily from modern Spanish horror movies - movies like El Orfanato, Los ojos de Julia - which is fortunate, because modern American horror movies are (usually) the pits.
One of the worst films of the year. It's the poop emoji personified.

It's the kind of movie in which characters foxily pull down their shades to reveal come-to-bed eyes; the kind of movie in which hot women take luxurious drags off half-smoked cigarettes, and walk with the clip-clop of stilettos on cold concrete.
A chronic side-effect of movies based on existing properties is that they usually alienate those outside its immediate fanbase. Not Death Note. It feels like the first in a series you'd want to see.

Not only does Berlin Syndrome go for the emotional punch of Room, it also wants to appeal to B-movie fans by never missing an opportunity to undress Teresa Palmer, and then take Polariods of her against her will.
In a fair world, Okja would have the power to make even the most belligerent meat eaters consider vegetarianism. It is the first great film of 2017. Protect it fiercely.
It might be the first great post-human movie, and an almost Biblical conclusion to one of the finest modern trilogies. All hail Matt Reeves.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Her bones stick out like the blades of a prehistoric reptile. Her stomach - or, at least the area where her stomach should be - seems to have had air sucked out of it with a vacuum. When she moves, you almost expect a clanging noise.

It is, like they promised, a quintessential American coming-of-age movie John Hughes would've been proud of, complete with jocks and nerds, bored teachers and detention, after-school hijinks, and first love.

I've never been to the opera, nor have I ever seen a 90-piece orchestra play Beethoven. But I imagine this - the action in this movie - is what it must feel like. Baby Driver is symphonic. It's ecstatic. It's hypnotic. When it soars, it soars.

About an hour into the film, Besson pauses the story and forces you to gawk at a shape-shifting Rihanna prancing about on a stripper's pole, while a bejewelled cowboy played by Ethan Hawke cackles in the background.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Transformers: The Last Knight is a rusty, rotting heap of scrap metal. It's Michael Bay venturing into the most self-indulgent, the most conceited corners of his psyche.
This is a crafty move on the director's part, as it translates facts into a humane narrative without giving much room for prejudice.
When the final action sequence begins, it seems like another film rather than the part of the ongoing one.
Befikre begins on a promising note and slowly turns into a film that's been made and released several times before.
Pretension, ego, sense of male superiority and skewed ideas of perfect womanhood make it complicated, intriguing, disgusting and disturbing. But, we have seen this happening around us in real life.
The writers must be credited for keeping the heat up throughout the final Sirhind battle sequence, but they take good 45 minutes to get there. The build-up, in large parts, states the obvious.
The film doesn't glorify substance abuse. Instead, the film has its heart in the right place: Punjab is in the grip of drugs, and only its youth can unchain it.
The Accountant starts from nowhere and reaches nowhere as it keeps oscillating between a good idea and an average execution. The film seems longer than its 120-minute length.
Dishoom is a quintessential buddy-cop movie. True to Bollywood, this John Abaram, Varun Dhawan-starrer tries to be a romantic film with added attractions of songs and dance.
Kyaa Kool Hain Hum 3 is not cool at all. It's stupid.
We all know what to expect from such a film, but it's still a lot of fun to see the underdog win.
TE3N catches you by the neck and keeps you engrossed till the end credits. Amitabh's superlative form is just one of the incentives to watch it.
This could be Aamir Khan's best performance till date. Yes, even better than Lagaan.
Too obvious and predictable.
Its head-on take on the overuse of natural resources should be considered an alarm bell.
It's a terribly made film with nothing much to offer except Narendra Jha's performance as the suave villain.
Haraamkhor is one film you just shouldn't miss, even if it's just to see how Hindi cinema is exploring new themes with finesse.
A caricatured D and his antics, coupled with bad sound designing, make Coffee With D end nowhere close to a fun film it could have been.

Kaabil is not extraordinary, but it has all the elements of a 'masala' potboiler. The catch is that it's been dished out in a typical Bollywood style which may not give it a novelty. But there isn't any particular reason for not watching it.
Overlook some of the minor flaws and you have a 140-minute solid entertainer on your hands.
Running Shaadi has its moments, but they are too few to keep you engrossed.
It may be one of the most awaited films in recent times but Rangoon is a royal misfire.
Commando 2 lacks heart and is all muscles. If may not even quench your thirst for some adrenaline-pumping stunts.
Still, Badrinath Ki Dulhania has its moments, especially the comic ones. Dhawan and Vaid show impeccable timing, but overall the film belongs to Alia Bhatt.
It's this feeling of being lonely and left-out that makes Trapped a scary experience.
The Emraan Hashmi charm mixed with shy Azharuddin mannerisms makes it a heady cocktail. You wouldn't want to put it down without giving it a try.
Abbas-Mustan disappoints like never before. Even machines will find it hard to enjoy Machine.
Rocky Handsome is a very average film with some finely executed action sequences on display. But, make no mistake: Don't expect anything more.
Baaghi borrows heavily from The Karate Kid and Bloodsport. The focus is on action, but occasional songs and melodrama spoil the fun.
Despite flaws, Balki is definitely a brave director who has attempted something new in Shamitabh.
The story is so predictable and the pressure to sound 'funny' is so much that they lose control.

The 134-minute long Begum Jaan has Vidya Balan in good form, but it lacks cohesiveness as a complete story. It shies away from delving deep into the theme, but you may appreciate its documentary-like feel.
It's a film that will keep you glued to the screen for all the 135 minutes it runs into. Don't think of even missing a minute of it.
There are some very powerful scenes in the film that will make you cry, uneasy in seat, and even laugh sheepishly at times.
Now, the filmmakers are concentrating more on realistic stunt scenes, but is this enough to bring mainstream Bollywood at par with foreign action films?
It's entertaining for sure but it would have been easier for the viewer to form a positive opinion about the film if it would have been edited by at least 20 more minutes.
NH10 displays a great potential and then fails to capitalise on it.
Sometimes, it seems that the director has deliberately underestimated the audience's IQ.
Watch it only if your survival depended on it.
Tevar is another run of the mill story which has nothing new to offer.
Ek Paheli Leela is regressive, illogical and completely dependent on Sunny Leone. She looks stunning and dances pretty well, but that much was also available on YouTube.

[Akshay Kumar's] hand-to-hand combat will remind you of his earlier Khiladi days where he used to bulldoze a barricade of 20 guys with just one kick. And, where these things don't work, his lethal comic timing comes to aide.
Thanks to fantastic CGI, [director Anurag Kashayp's] sets look authentic and provide a credible backdrop to the characters.
It's a total throwback to Shah Rukh Khan's '90s avatars, but he once again shows how good he still is in that genre.
One of the best films in recent times, it's an experience not to be forgotten easily.
movie_title: Qissa: The Ghost Is A Lonely Traveller (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A treat to watch, and a commentary on the clash of Indian and Western ideas.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The climax is another big let-down.
The film's biggest weakness is its writing.
What brings Guddu Rangeela down is its below average writing.
Bajrangi Bhaijaan is totally dependent on Salman Khan's superstardom and he pulls it off provided you overlook his in-your-face 'bhai' act in some scenes.
Stunning, gripping, edge-of-the-seat, shocking, engrossing... use any of these adjectives for this Ajay Devgn version of Drishyam.
Bangistan deserves applause for its message-oriented content.
Some judgmental errors are so glaring that it's hard to think them as continuity mistakes.
Nothing is well with All Is Well.
Welcome Back is funny in parts, but that Welcome fluidity is missing big time.
Hero features many shallow characters. Radha and Sooraj are no exceptions.
Jazbaa is a film which thrives on style
It's a mindless film, but with some great fun-filled moments.
Bachchan's dialogue writers make a mistake here. They have given him very superficial lines.
The movie turns into an illogical chase that ends nowhere. Even the movie's glossy cinematography and sleek editing couldn't be of much help.

Hindi Medium is a much-needed comment on the private school system and how it has become so important in our lives. It's also a lesson for the concerned officials, who turn a blind eye to government schools that have millions of potential winners.
You know how investigative officers are used as storytellers in such films. Here, Khanna plays that role with ease, finesse and poise. He binds the story together.
Akira isn't an out and out action film. In fact, the makers are too concerned about making it look like a family drama. Lacklustre supporting cast and depthless writing make it even duller.
The mood is right, the tone is right, the pace is right. The film doesn't delve in the grey zone. There are two sides and you need to pick one.
But you know what seals the deal for Julie 2? It's when Aditya Srivastava whispers, "Thanks for sharing Julie's story." Yeah, right. Zero star.
From performing planchette to listening conversations via paintings, Tera Intezaar can entertain you at many levels. Just don't doze off.
I thought Great Grand Masti was the worst film this year. What a great competition it has in Beiimaan Love!
The frenzy and enigma surrounding a small boy is conveyed with precision. The meticulously planned screenplay makes the audience a party to the story.
With a brilliant theme, a narrative structure that flows, and social relevance that hooks the viewer, Chauranga makes for a powerful watch.
In short, Daawat-e-ishq is not a film to miss this weekend. For me, Aditya Roy Kapoor is the show-stealer in DEI. A delicious watch.
Fukrey Returns is a tedious 141-minute watch which is unfunny, unintelligent and repetitive.
Dilwale hugely banks upon Khan's stardom and he tries his best to reciprocate. The rest of Dilwale has a very little heart.
There's still some time to catch up with Hollywood, but Tiger Zinda Hai is probably the best a filmmaker could do with a superstar.
The ingredients are there, but loose ends restrict Shivaay from becoming a smooth ride.
Sharman Joshi tries really hard to infuse some soul into this 131-minute narrative, but there's hardly anything in the script.
Some melodious tunes may entice you, but that's not enough to keep you hooked for the two-hours and odd saga.
Vodka Diaries is about under-utilised actors and losing a promising opening. It probably needed a more thorough approach.
It has enough to bedazzle you, so go for the sheen and Ranveer Singh's lunacy. After all, Padmaavat has passed so many hurdles to reach you.
For the want of a better term, Kapoor & Sons is an emotional roller coaster. It's a tear jerker for sure, but also features the intricacies of a middle class life.
Some scenes are so true to the nature of traditional Indian middle class that you automatically give them your approval.
Love Per Square Foot doesn't delve deep into matters of the heart, but it's a feel good film for sure.
Kuch Kuch Locha Hai is an insane, bizarre film with absolutely no intention of making the audience satiated in any which manner.
Hooda owns the screen with his spontaneity and rustic appearance.
Aiyaary is sketchily-written and not compelling. It tests patience even if you are a fan of the genre.
It's not worth wasting your time, money, patience and intelligence on this mind-numbing promotional video.
Jishnu Bhattacharjee's innovative cinematography tries to cover-up, but he can't rescue a film that fails to explain its lead's sudden change of character.
You deserve better than this. Respect your intelligence. So much hate may ruin all the good things in your life.
The 156-minute Mukkabaaz is the best film in last one year or so, and this year couldn't start on a better note. Let's cherish Vineet Singh and his thickheaded brawler with open heart.
Half Girlfriend is confused, forced and takes the audience for granted. In one word: disappointing.
It may not appear to be a very polished product or a free flowing story to some, but it punches with all its might in the climax, and that's where you suddenly realise its worth.
Don't let this guest come anywhere near your house. Stay alert, stay safe.

I wiped my eyes when the same footage played inside the theatre, I won't deny that, but that's mostly because of the nostalgia attached to my teens. It's reliving the Sachin magic, not a perfect docu-drama on him.
It's a faithful remake of Oculus and can make your hair stand at times.
A Death In The Gunj totally relies on acting skills of a stellar cast.
Raabta lacks the finesse required to pull off a theme like this, but it is definitely good to look at.
All Eyez On Me might be about Tupac and his insane lifestyle, but it guides our attention to issues far beyond the realm of music.
It's been a while since Salman Khan started playing a clumsy yet golden hearted man-child. He has aced this game by now and Tubelight might be his best shot at it.
Rukh has its own narrative technique. To categorise Rukh as an art-house film would be an injustice to Atanu Mukherjee's talent. It's a 'different' film, for the want of a better word.
You remember how it felt while reading Roald Dahl or Harry Potter? The same happens while watching Jagga Jasoos.
This isn't the right tribute to the moonwalking King Of Pop.
In the second half[,] the film gets totally centred on Anil Kapoor and his antics. Unlike Welcome, he doesn't get much support from his co-actors and gigs become repetitive in nature.
This 137-minute soldier versus traitor story is totally worth your time.
It's a big disappointment to see Shah Rukh Khan returning to his comfort zone and yet not performing on top of his powers.
It's a story that delivers a really important message about personal hygiene and proper sanitation system in rural areas. It's just that we hear the messages clearly in the first 50 minutes.
Mom does what it intends to: Become a film that can hold the audience's attention for 148 minutes.

Most of the tactics used by the director fail to distract the audience from anticipating the climax, and when it starts we all know how it can end. Despite this, Bareilly Ki Barfi is sweet and delightful.

In 106 minutes, Gurinder Chadha ably paints the anxiety and painful relocation of millions on the both sides of the border. Her handing of a clean chit to England's last Viceroy to India seems over-simplification of the historic episode though.
Secret Superstar will still make you laugh and cry with ease. Show some appetite for drama and you have an entertainer at your service.
Tu Hai Mera Sunday is concerned about our well beings and that makes it notice-worthy. It's a sweet, little film asking for your support.
movie_title: You Are My Sunday (Tu Hai Mera Sunday) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Judwaa 2, like the original, isn't a piece of art, in fact it's mediocre, but it's that one film which may lift your mood.
Despite its 124-minute length, Haseena Parkar is a tedious watch. We already know whatever is shown there.
movie_title: Haseena (Haseena: The Queen Of Mumbai)(haseena Parkar) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Newton is one of the finest political satires we have seen in the last couple of years.

Lucknow Central fails to utilise its resources, especially Diana Penty, and loses out on a chance to become a really engaging film. Like Prison Break, it never reaps the benefits of a promising start.
Sunny and Bobby Deol and Shreyas Talpade resort to crass comedy at times, but the movie is funny often enough to recommend.

Baadshaho has too many ordinarily written characters jostling for whistle-worthy one-liners for 136-minutes. Eventually they run short of the steam and Baadshaho becomes a rehashed '90s story with some gloss and a lot of disappointment.
At best, Qaidi Band brings up a new concept and offers some wonderful songs, but that's about it. It remains an average story told in an average way.
Babumoshai Bandookbaaz has got the ingredients, but their proportions are not right.
It's a tedious watch even with a reasonable 120-minute duration. Patel Ki Punjabi Shaadi demands patience and is not likely to make many laugh.

At 90 minutes this movie is short, but it feels much longer.

A PlayStation game come to life, XXX is a movie almost exclusively dependent on the special effects department and the charm of its leading man, Vin Diesel. But it's sound and fury signifying nothing.
The dialogue is so bad in Driven that at one of the dramatic points, the crowd erupted in laughter.
All in all, Brown Sugar is a satisfying well-made romantic comedy that's both charming and well acted. It will guarantee to have you leaving the theater with a smile on your face.
There are a lot of movies struggling to get out of Crazy in Alabama, and most of them are bad.
You, dear moviegoer, must not buy a ticket to this badly programed sequel. You must save the world from Universal Soldier III: How Bad Can It Get?
Those hallmark Farley situations, when he bursts into apoplexy over some challenge or outrage, seem unconvincing here. As for Perry, he doesn't show nearly enough charm or ego to be of interest.
This is a cookie-cutter buddy movie, as predictable as they come.

A sub-par script.
Lays up a little short in the character development department.

The rock and roll movie against which all others are measured.

Naive, corruptible, lonely young man meets femme fatale, and it all leads, inevitably, absurdly, to destruction.
It's a wonder that so stark and minimal a film can create such potent feelings, images and moments that linger so persistently, divine intimations that seem so inescapable.

movie_review_blurb: Its message of costly sacrifice and hard-won reconciliation is at the heart of the gospel, and the fact that this story is drawn from actual events demands attention.
The film tries to do way too much: it's a mess. But, crude misjudgments aside, it's a tremendously entertaining mess.
It nods in the direction of tons of potentially interesting developments of plot, theme and character, but doesn't bother to follow through on any of them enough to pay off.
The devil -- and the delight -- here is in the detours.
Whether altered for the sake of incorporating superfluous extra material (cat fight!) or for reasons even less compelling, the editing rhythms here are way off.
Those seeking anything resembling a real discussion of the issues had best seek elsewhere.
