Life is a bitch and then you go to L.A.
The suburbs of the rich, the barrios of the poor and the watery world of the fish child form the stage for this unique and successful mystery thriller by Lucia Puenzo
A near perfect allegory of the deadlocked struggle for peace in the Middle East, this is rising star Hiam Abbass' best performance to date.
Too much science-babble obscures the truth of Perestroika. The tragedy of the aftermath would have made a better story unvarnished.
A sweet effort in a low budget film, O'Horton is a calm experience into the near-panic of growing old.
An unabashed polemic promoting more female artist exhibitions, and art sales, this film is as entertaining as it is one-sided. Inspiring enough that men, too, might be moved to artistry.
movie_title: Who Does She Think She Is? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Pretty durn good family drama with very egalitarian lines distributed amongst young and old. Not an easy film to watch but there are lessons for everyone.
An April Fool's Day release may be more appropriate than the audience expected in this random collection of interviews and experiences on the heart and soul of yoga.
Like 2003's "Shattered Glass" this film is a story of one of the best scandals ever. A well done documentary and valuable opportunity to see how good a con-artist can be.

A variation on the theme of Central American gangster films, "Nombre" adds a mystery thriller note in the tone of early American "gangster on the run" films that makes it riveting to watch while telling a heartbreaking story.

A film of mixed feelings, Lost Islands seeks to show contented, vibrant family life leading to oedipal father-son conflict. Too much to hope for, this commendable goal fails to generate a strong conclusion.
A great example of truth being better than fiction---a combination of "Mission Impossible", Billy Wilder's "Spirit of St. Louis" and Charlie Chaplin's "Modern Times."

Although it would be great to see Chazz Palminteri break out of the usual tough guy roles and Robert Davi break through into a successful career of writing and directing, this is not the film that does either. Decent viewing for the family but neither th
A splatter flick that stays a splatter flick. In spite of some glimpses of genius, this film never strays far enough from the genre into potentially promising moral territory.

A moving story combined with first rate acting and a great screenplay by a new, but determined, writer/director make this an indie film not to be missed. Modern film noir from the streets of Mexico to the streets of America.
A thrilling and painstakingly researched story combined with the best costumes imaginable and superb performances makes this a biopic to see.

An obscure and terrifying mental disorder leads a reporter to the strangest and then the most terrifying story of his life. A neat film noir in a very modern setting amongst people who are not all there.
Indie director Brad Furman has unleashed a powerful low budget thriller that makes good use of the talents of John Leguizamo as well as those of supporting performers Tyrese Gibson and Rosie Perez.

Half road trip and half learning how to make a home, Trucker gives Michelle Monaghan a chance to show what she can do and the result is encouraging, although twelve year old Jimmy Bennett nearly steals the show.

A well meaning but ineffective coming-of-age story set on the surfing beaches of the industrial mining center of Newcastle, Australia. Mediocre action footage and tedious angst make for a film that is an effort to watch.
A wonderfully complex exploration into people's attempts to control the fates and their own discovered strengths in the wake of illusory failure.
James Carroll goes on a crusade of his own, exposing the hypocrisy of politically motivated religion and the violence of the evangelical Jihad in our own Colorado Springs.
A visual treat for Dafoe fans that goes well beyond the conventional horror genre into questions of reality and fantasy and how, or if, we tell the difference.
Aussie mayhem with cannibalistic inbred idiots and upper middle class whitebread victims fails to set this film apart. But great fun nonetheless.
The most beautiful and tear jerking journey in a child's world of make believe. The child in us interprets Rambo and the film character never looked so good.
Close but no cigar as a great international corporate mystery thriller slows to a crawl in a drawn out study of death. Frank Langella and Elliott Gould should have been used better.

Director Daniel Myrick has taken his excellent work from the ultra-low-budget "Blair Witch Hunt," added some modest resources as befits that success and come up with a great little tale of suspense and horror.

An excellent execution of cinema verite' by the man who invented the concept. Although the facts are well known, the tone and body language of the most famous president of the 20th century tell a story all their own.
Agnes Varda shows us what modern film making is all about in a whimsical look at a cinematic genius.
movie_title: Les Plages d'Agn√®s (The Beaches of Agnes) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A tough and realistic cop story that stays believable from beginning to end while delivering the truth about loyalty, courage and gut-wringing fear on an inner city military mission with no second chances.
A towering monument to the exposure of one of the darkest secrets of the Soviet era, the Katyn massacre of 1940. One of the best films of one of the best directors in the history of cinema.

Upbeat rom-com grounded in solid work by Ryan Reynolds and Emily Mortimer tells a meaningful story while still staying in-bounds with the PG-13 rating. Unusual Western Canada seacoast photography and upbeat soundtrack make for an entertaining film.
Lush photography of the beautiful New Zealand hills combines with skin ripping mayhem and over-the-top humor to make one of the funniest of the new wave zombie satires yet.
The reigning champion in the archival footage department features great Soviet footage of those days that (hopefully) will never be seen again---the days of the US-Soviet space race.
Surf's up in Southern California as the modern art world invades Nixonville and Reagan City in the 1950s. A fascinating look at the start of something big: modern art in Los Angeles.
A weak plot still makes a viable vehicle for a couple of great performances with some unbeatable screen chemistry and a good old fashioned plot twist at the end.
A hackneyed slacker scenario reduces this film from an entertainment marathon to a plot treading water. The feel-good message comes around, but there is too much packaging for the product.
Hardly a walk in the park, this powerful journey is one of Van Sant's darkest. Grips the viewer in a vice of guilt that gets tighter to the point of strangulation. A dark and gripping masterpiece.

Previous films such as "Gunners Palace" and the more famous "War Tapes" gave us intimate footage of the day to day danger and tedium of the war, but no film has shown both sides with the power and accuracy of "Battle for Haditha"

A look at the sprawling and incredibly powerful Camorra crime family in Italy shows mostly the lurid details of conventional crime. The value of the film lies in exposing crime that is not business as usual.
What do four young film makers and a demented savage with a bag over his head have in common? They all want to be stars, and they almost make it in this super-indie horror satire.

Maxwell Smart is back with a vengeance. Although this vintage Mel Brooks shtick will mean a lot more to those who saw it first hand in the 1960s, it is still headed for one of the top notches in the usually doggy summer film season.
A classic French family drama featuring fine performances by legend Catherine Deneuve and reigning star Mathieu Amalric even if the raging and crying might be a bit much for the Christmas season.
movie_title: Un Conte de No√´l (A Christmas Tale) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Not something to be taken too seriously, De Niro's latest comedic flight is completely entertaining with most thanks going to supporting cast Catherine Keener and John Turturro
Although this is a commendable study in the future of animation it is not accessible enough to be entertaining. Undoubtedly better films are yet to come from this group.
movie_title: Peur(s) du Noir (Fear(s) of the Dark) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Far too long at 126 minutes, "Stranded" adds little to what we have already been told about this heroic tale of survival. First hand accounts of cannibalism are handled deftly and with respect, but that is not enough to carry an entire film
movie_title: Stranded: I Have Come from a Plane That Crashed on the Mountains (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Rating high in the unvarnished truth department, "Ballast" does not bring enough entertainment to the table to merit the price of admission. A commendable exercise in plainness does not constitute a reason to see this film.
Cinema verite' filmed in an unabashedly one-sided, pro-demonstrator mode, this film fails to make the grade as either hard hitting documentary or staged narrative fiction
Luscious enough photography and fun to watch, "Appaloosa" brings nothing new to the table. As a collection of things that have been done before who will watch it over the originals?

A stellar cast and the usual percolating plot of the Coens combine in one of their most entertaining crime comedies to date. Funny stuff with Clooney, McDormand and Malkovich frame a breakthrough comedic performance by Brad Pitt.
Scoring high for creativity, the story of the fantastic life of urban nomad and unwilling Bolshevik Jan Dite gives us too little to hang on to. This is hard work for a laugh.
movie_title: I Served the King of England (2008)

movie_review_blurb: More action, gun fights and swords fail to make this a better film than the spaghetti westerns that came before. Tarantino is great but his small part is too little to lift this Eastern oater much above average.
Great old-fashioned spy thriller action with a solid backdrop of religious tension amidst the dilemmas of war. A solid plot and good performances make this entertainment that makes the viewer think.

More of a conspiratorial look at the changing of New Orleans than a hurricane doc, this film examines the soft machine of politics that is trying to transform New Orleans, its houses, its people and its art, into something we may not like.
See this film to relive those high school days that you have tried to forget. Or, just talk to your kids.

Powerful acting by Melissa Leo and Misty Upham and a setting in a little known microcosm of international intrigue, "Frozen River" tells a fascinating story that keeps up the pace from start to finish.
Although adding nothing to the previous body of knowledge on the iconic jazz singer, this film is a precious collection of extremely unique jazz vocal footage that should not be missed.
movie_title: Anita O'Day: The Life of a Jazz Singer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A charming break-out for Luke Wilson but not the role that provides him with the dynamics we want. Touching with the right amount of mystery. Great family viewing but no thrills.
Bordering on the surreal, Chabrol's latest film investigates conflicting desires in a woman in love. The old meets the new and the quandary remains unresolved.
movie_title: La Fille Coup√©e en Deux (The Girl Cut in Two) (A Girl Cut in Two) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Woody Allen's latest is a pure relationship-fest, but the audience can't help but be transfixed ( a little threatened?) by Bardem's stare. A thoroughbred cast and crew makes a very watchable romantic tryst, but no classic.

At the risk of over-doing a good thing, if that hasn't been done already, Lucas and crew cuts the final link to reality by going full animation with Star Wars. A righteous battle, but one that will appeal to ever decaying audiences
It's close but no cigar for first time writer/director Charles Oliver as he bashes his unfortunate audience with a preachy and one-dimensional exposition of revenge wearing restoration clothing.

A man wakes from unconsciousness to find his wife dead and himself the center of suspicion as strange forces and deadly assassins close in from all sides. So many twists and turns it would hard to encapsulate spoilers for this one.
movie_title: Ne le Dis √† Personne (Tell No One) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Step back to the good old days when anybody could be brought before Congress and interrogated about their beliefs, and meet one of the most famous of those who refused to answer.
If you want to see ignorant self destruction, see Troy Duffy in "Overnight" and forget this film---the worst mistake Josh Hartnett has made in his career.
A love story that holds out happiness as a carrot dangled but never obtained. Too busy, but still lush with the loving work of director Jan Hrebejk.
If you thought Disneyland was fun, take a trip to this complete simulated Iraqi village in California, and learn how the other half live. And die.
A sweet and tidy neo-noir underworld thriller with a heart, thanks to excellent performances by the lead trio and a great setting in the seedy underworld of gambling con-artists.
Some very different cinematic methods and above-average acting and direction make this entourage of beautiful people a rom-com worth watching.
One of the most intriguing films of the year. A film that says a lot by saying little.
movie_title: Before Tomorrow (Le Jour avant le lendemain) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The worse politics gets for the constituency the better it gets for the comedians. A political roast of unprecedented accuracy and intensity and a comedic dream.

Delicious cinematography and a story so real you will be in Manchester shuffling about delivering those letters. Football legend Eric Cantona adds little but the archival footage of "King Eric" cannot be denied.
Slick compared to films noir of old, the stunts too cool and characters too swishy, but swaggering with a good old-fashioned edge and raw steaming action for each and every one of its 105 minutes.
Ridley Scott and Russell Crowe will be better off pointing their arrows in different directions after this Dark Age howler.
A rare chance to see Anna Halprin at work over the last 50 years. Not the same as seeing her in person but close.
A swinging look at underground rock music in Tehran and the young hopefuls who make it happen.
movie_title: No One Knows About Persian Cats (Les Chats Persans) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The more love changes the more it stays the same. History itself falls prey to love in this delightful retelling of the Ramayana.
A love story and film noire with delicious overtones of dreadful memories and love that will never die.
movie_title: The Secret in Their Eyes (El Secreto de Sus Ojos) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A thought provoking film about a dreadful body of work and its legacy for those yet unborn.
movie_title: Harlan - Im Schatten von Jud S√ºss (Harlan: In the Shadow of Jew Seuss) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Emerging director Tim Blake Nelson takes another step up with this comedy drama starring Edward Norton in what might go down as Norton's best performance yet.
It isn't clear if "Warlords" is supposed to be a comedy or an adventure thriller but it will only appeal to those who appreciate the screaming cast of thousands.
Although fun to watch, it will take a princely kiss to make a legitimate documentary out of this Disney vehicle.
Predictable but enjoyable mystery thriller with great psycho performances by Julianne Moore and Amanda Seyfried.
A screenplay caught between pools of blood and emotional healing, "Eclipse" cannot make up its mind any more than can its ambivalent characters.
A film that brings the food and spirit of Italy to your doorstep in a light hearted set of afternoons with the grandmothers of Rome.
Love is just a screech away as Ben Stiller bares the soul of a crazy man who seems to like it that way.
Preserving a sense of hope for today's children, there is too much in this film that is too hard to believe.
A great piece of natural indie noir film making that entertains for all of its 152-minute run time.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Everything you wanted to know about a marriage and probably a few things you could have done without.
Do not have a relationship over the phone unless you know the person at the other end. You never do
A fine documentary that inspires thought long after the details of the art collection are forgotten.
Who needs a plot with a herd of stand-up comics and a bushel of wisecracks?
A documentary that wakes us up to the pitfalls of politically controlled television and then puts us to sleep watching the people producing it.
A road trip to Vegas turns into a road trip to Hell in this great little romp with the master of misfortune, Steve Buscemi.
With animation like this it is no wonder kids develop ADD. The current generation of Python influenced animation talent comes to a screen near you.
movie_title: A Town Called Panic (Panique au village) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: This French buddy cop action comedy owes its limited success to John Travolta. If you don't love him stay an ocean away from this flick.
One of the few films so far this year that deserves to be called an epic. Great acting and superb sets and cinematography make this a great success.
A film that keeps us from taking the theory of evolution for granted. Darwin paid for those words.
A Berretta that is a few shots short of a full clip, Michel Hazanavicius' lightning jabs at the spy super-hero fantasy are disjointed. Too little, too late?
movie_title: OSS 117: Rio ne r√©pond plus (Lost in Rio) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A zany, funny and heartwarming tale told through excellent photography and a smashing soundtrack.
Nothing new here, just four highly polished performances, a kiss and a tear at the end, and black ink on the bottom line.
Pascal Chaumeil's debut rom-com gets by with a little help from Romain Duris and the enduring beauty of Vanessa Paradis. He may not be so lucky next time.
With a family like this, who needs enemies?
Not the knockout punch of his previous Kinatay or Serbis but an unvarnished look into the inner-workings of a world forced to brutality.
A young and talented cast put energy into this timeless story of the citizen warriors of occupied France.
A cinematic soap opera that shows what can be done with expensive cars a high fashion clothes. Not much.
The second half of the French gangster series drags a bit at the end but is fun, macho stuff nonetheless.
Simple and charming, an exquisite expansion of a great book into a great animated film.
A macho good time. The rebel without a cause finds out that wartime training with guns has its advantages.
Of the most visually thrilling escapist yarns ever made. Italian golden age cinema takes on a gun fetish.
A pre-chainsaw extravaganza where the Romans talk like James Bond and the Picts have better military backgrounds than the American generals who invaded Afghanistan.
As gritty as they come, another Aussie crime action thriller with great performances and good social commentary as well.
Too much of the same thing torpedoes this potent essay on human rights in Israeli occupied Palestine.
movie_title: Salt of This Sea (Milh Hadha al-Bahr) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Skullduggery is afoot as well as laughs in this footloose mystery thriller.
The most intense war film since "Das Boot." There are no winners in war.
A realistic and grounded spy thriller that sheds the Hollywood and drills down to the real people and events of the most famous spy story in history.
Dorothy parachutes into Dublin in search of the Wizard but there is no place like home.
Directors Tim Hetherington and Sebastian Junger have come up with one of the most direct, searing documentaries in the history of US war in the Middle East.
The film is as much about who killed Sid Vicious as who killed Nancy Spungen, but an enthralling and touching story all around.
One of the most amazing investigative documentary films of all time. The interviews are few but of the highest quality
An entertaining and thought provoking film with more celebrity pictures, and interviews, than you can shake a stick at.
"Spellbound" taken to far greater heights. A touching and honest portrayal of the fight to be the best in the least glitzy business in America---science.
An uneven look at modern family in crisis. Stay awake during the slow stretches, the good footage is worth it.
A funny and touching look at the self-crowned queen of comedy.
movie_title: Joan Rivers: A Piece Of Work (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The truth comes out and the audience is left to wonder what it all means.
A romantic comedy with an edge born out of desperation.
Great performances by Fraser and Ford will pay the bills for this one but that is as far as the good news goes.
Michael Hoffman extracts the maximum benefit from a brief period of Leo Tolstoy's last days in this comfortable and endearing drama.
Lush cinematography combined with first-rate acting and a valuable story make this a great film for the whole family.
A film of the simplest and most complex of working worlds. A wonderful visual poem.
The slice of life story of two masters of the modern hoax. More laughs per dollar than any other film fuel.
movie_title: The Yes Men Fix the World (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Suggestions of a potential smash keep the audience hoping this film will come together but in the end it is too much and too little.
A tremendously important lesson for times when it seems like we are always at war. Will the person stopping them always be branded a traitor?
movie_title: Most Dangerous Man in America: Daniel Ellsberg and the Pentagon Papers (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A lethal look at the after-shock of apartheid. Tough to watch but bearing a powerful message.
A good natured cheer-leading session for clean vehicles, "Fuel" is several measures short of the intensity it will take to put Hummers where they belong---in museums.
Although more of a stage play than a film this performance has great acting and great music combined with a heart felt message.
The best look to date at the rotten US housing mortgage system that developed over the last ten years. Clear enough to make you cry.
Although the ranks of great IRA films are swelling rapidly this combination of political history and mystery suspense masterwork is one of the best.
Gritty inner city drama with a message presented by new names and faces makes a great film.
As the glossiest of colored glossies this film delivers a message than creativity is still alive in America. But the main reward seems to be corporate bottom lines.
Hirokazu Koreeda has written and directed a family drama that tells a powerful story that can not be told through words alone.
A heart warming piece of summer fare for those nostalgia buffs in the audience.
A funny television satire and heartening viewing experience that has personal lessons in courage as well as much needed commentary on US/Mexican border relations.
For those who play the instrument, watch this film and learn something about the guitar. As for the rest%u2014listen to the CDs.
A fascinating story and film about the down-under in us all.
A combination splatter flick and demon child extravaganza that succeeds in bloody special effects but fails to become an actual movie.
A very engaging and civilized comedy that combines a great story with spirited acting and an undercurrent of criticism about the brave new world of medicine.
Precious in its realism this film is so plain is threatens to slip off the screen. Kudos for the honesty but the entertainment is lacking.
Charlyne Yi's road trip in search of love is an easygoing investigation into the ultimate riddle without an answer.
A real life spy thriller led by marine activist Richard O'Brian that is also a genuine and heartfelt plea for the marine environment.
A classic piece of historical action narrative told in a lean no-nonsense manner with riveting action sequences. A great war story.
movie_title: Flammen & Citronen (Flame & Citron) (The Flame and the Lemon) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: One part myth, one part vampire and one part over the top hilarity is a promising combination, but this story doesn't add enough to the overused vampire genre to succeed.
A good, if contrived, romantic comedy that exposes the world to Asberger's syndrome while drawing a line between love and dependence.
A passionate exploration by the Dardenne brothers into greed and the power of men to do endless harm in the context of international politics.
A fun production with a great soundtrack and scrumptious English scenery but the decisions are ultimately too dim to believe.
A great new director with a great and laid back saga that will be too laid back for some but well worth the watching.
Too psychological and "film school" for some but a fine homage to Theo Van Gogh's integrity and courage as a filmmaker and student of the human condition.
A haunting exploration into men's minds that becomes too much of a psychological study to qualify as accessible entertainment for most.
Andrea Arnold puts all her eggs in one basket in this film and the thin storyline fails to carry the day.
A subtle and mysterious look into failing feudalism and the involuntary passing of the baton.
In this extreme minimalist film adventure set in the seemingly routine inner city subtle unusual truths emerge with undeniable strength.
Self-flagellation never felt as good as filmmakers head to the high country for the last experience of the good old days.
Just when you thought it was safe to be a vampire , corrupt corporate politicians spoil the fun.
Off to the usual howling good start with the current master of sexy comedy "Up In the Air" runs out of fuel towards the end and barely is able to make it to the terminal with message intact.
Guy Ritchie hit the big time with this flick but there is too much of the gangs of London and too little of the rumpled professor in the character of the famous detective.
A film that was brought back from the worst of bad luck, "Dr. Parnassus" is a fascinating collection of things that might have been.
Charles Bukowski morphs into Dewey Cox in this denunciation of the evils of paralyzing drunkenness.
Although lacking in the sharpness and precision of his previous hit "Chicago" this is the glossiest film with the best cast of the year. A feel good film for the Holiday Season.
Girls at risk take the world by storm at an artists' refuge where it's all right to scream.
The most articulate film to date describing the modern means and methods of the free market enslavement of undeveloped countries.
A couple new characters and war brewing does not fill up two and a half hours of screen time
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Fun, fun, fun until the Prime Minister takes the T-Bird away.
A heart felt effort but too slow to be called completely entertaining. Plenty of time to think in between crises.
movie_title: The Private Lives of Pippa Lee (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A small but revealing inside look at Orson Welles at the crisis of his life and the inside story of glamorous 1930's Broadway.
A surrealistic look at a family thrown onto the chopping block of modern technology.
A good look at men dealing with women and a good look at the supposedly soft side of porn doesn't make a good looking film.
This film will be too much for some viewers because of the spot-on antiwar statement but the story is tight and the performances powerful.
An unabashed sales job for symphonic Russian legend Valery Gergiev produces some of the most beautiful music in any video as well as some insight into the current maestro of maestros.
movie_title: You Cannot Start Without Me: Valery Gergiev---Maestro (2009)

movie_review_blurb: C√©sar nominee writer/director Karin Albou summons a genie with this pair of love stories, set in the worst of times, that challenge loyalties to the limit.
movie_title: Le Chant des Mari√©es (The Wedding Song) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A blood soaked horror fest with surrealistic overtones in the stripped down von Trier style. Overly disturbing but still a must see for fans of von Trier, Dafoe or Gainsbourg.
Maybe fun viewing for some kids, but even most eight year olds will want more story than this.
A low budget art house film stretching the envelop in comedic drama. Hilarity and insanity in the world of the workaday.
An explosion of acting, sets and costumes that leaves the viewer with a feeling of near permanent glossiness.
Nostalgic and fun to talk about but not that much fun to listen to. At some point the dead will simply rest in peace.
A sumptuous and saddening feast of noir massaged in minute detail by the master of women in trouble.

Step back to the guilt and self recrimination of the 1940s film noir in a cozy nest of plotting, cyanide and the best friend's lover. Those subject to nostalgia will love this pot boiler every step of the way.
Slow in the father-son heart to heart parts, Champ brings it all back home in the end with a great story line and saving performances by Jackson, Alda and Hatcher
Watch this film only if you are a die hard Meatloaf fan and have seen everything else already. Best to watch with the sound off and with his Platinum album playing in the background.
movie_title: Meat Loaf: In Search of Paradise (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The seamy underbelly of Paris seen through romantic American eyes keeps the noir alive.
How many Iranian skiers does it take to tear down a mountain?
The first chip has been knocked off the shoulder in the 2008 presidential horse race.
War is up close and personal as soldiers film it from their helmets and gun turrets and delight in $56 feasts of Halliburton ham and eggs.
Wavering between dark humor and the anguish of the creative soul, this look at the self-destructive TV industry never quite gets at either.
Black teenage comedy in a cautionary tale about the dangers of kids growing up alone.
A grand and soapy experience set in the fading glory of apartments meant for a better time and place.
Busts loose with every cool white guy urban clich√© from baseball to video games...but the women save the day
A thrilling get-acquainted tour of a side of the Philippines most never see.
It's rainy and dark as death in Bucharest in a tale of that last ride on Medicare.
A film of limited ambition that may be before its time.
A film that threatens the war movement with every showing, the Bush administration should outlaw it from all theatres within fifty miles of an armed forces recruiting station.
Politically incorrect to a broad spectrum of social cliques, "Dreamz" makes a statement and has some fun at the same time.
Even if the dialogue is too glib for the dark and ruthless heroes, a great cast and edgy story keep this thriller moving to the very end.
The most unflinching look yet at the meth pandemic that is sweeping across the Midwest as family values are plowed under by modern corporate agri-business.
A shaky director, a deadly critic and a losing ball club collide in an entertaining surreal showdown just off Broadway.
Director Eimbcke scores a bulls eye as Ferris Bueller takes a day off in Mexico City.
JT LeRoy may be a scam, but Argento's scalding treatment of adults behaving badly is as real as cold French fries in a West Virginia truck stop.
movie_title: The Heart Is Deceitful Above All Things (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Beauty of the mind and body conspires to survive under the guns of UN troops guarding the fragile peace against the moonscape of war that is Kabul.
Mao shows his fun side in world class camp taken very seriously.
movie_title: Yang Ban Xi: The 8 ModelWorks (Yang Ban Xi, de 8 modelwerken) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Forgive the occasional forays into schmaltz-land as Marilyn Hotchkiss shows us how to dance, and love, in spite of it all.
movie_title: Marilyn Hotchkiss Ballroom Dancing & Charm School (2006)

movie_review_blurb: An inside look at the weird world of the cult hero of grunge rock who is, well, weird.
Spike Lee gets downright entertaining in a buddy suspense thriller you won't figure out until the lights come up in the multiplex.
Boynton takes up deep inside politics Madison Avenue style as green stamps fail to establish a lasting government in Bolivia.
A successful stock broker forgets it all and becomes a film maker. But not a very good one.
The world's tallest shy comedian floats out of the radio with a power cast that even Altman is challenged to harness.
Strident environmental warnings and political rhetoric do not a movie make.
'She Got Game' in a wolf pack attack of high school hoops that's tough love from beginning to end.
Mandatory viewing for those fighting for legal reform.
Documented proof that life in the good old days of the 1960s was not all that good. The dark side of love and flowers.
Sexual confusion made manifest in a romantic comedy gender-bender first try by newcomer Martin Curland and a host of young faces and bodies.
All the audience can do with this DOA comedy is wait for their next chance to see Robin Williams do another stand-up routine, providing a precious break in an otherwise tedious film.
An inspiring look at an idea the medical establishment doesn't like grass roots pharmaceutical research.
Although there will be claims of wasted talent, Scorsese's new blockbuster wanna-be combines sizzling dialog with no-holds-barred action for this year's top-of-the-heap gangster flick
A nice mix of real facts, and what could have been real facts, in a sweet look at the man of steel killed not by kryptonite, but by television.
Lassie d√©j√† vu filmed in the magnificent British Isles with more than enough animal stampedes to enthrall an entire theatre of ten year olds, and their parents.
Although deserving a place in the annals of dignified cinema, Georgia Lee's breakthough feature film is a snoozer.
"Hill Street Blues" set in Paris, Xavier Beauvois updates film noir with a gritty tale of a tough woman in a tough city.
Photography from inside a shoe box makes for a dull film no matter how close up and personal.
Too much quiet makes for a film too easy to sleep through. When we will get to see Camilla Belle act up?
Matt Dillon shows his stuff in the ultimate troubled-male role of Bukowski's archetypal slacker.
One friend may be all it takes.
Marriage noir with another devastating performance by Huppert that plumbs the depths of unhinged despair.
Technical details and weak characters fail to derail the latest frontrunner in blood soaked underground horror.
A taught thriller all the better for somber and distraught grayscale photography
Trained assassins do the right thing and rehash a very bad clich√© at the same time.
The Queen of the Indies ploughs the fertile ground of feminine self-empowerment with good vibrations for all.
In summer multiplex fare, Owen Wilson does better than Cable Guy, but not much.
Deeper Than Y is a short and sweet documentary about what we are and what we may become, from them that know.
Looking for love in all the wrong places cools in the warmth of the Haitian sun.
Completely over the top and proud of it.
Minimalist day in the life of the angry young leaves us wondering.
Napoleon Dynamite behind the microphone, Fish puts his life on the silver screen.
The condemned die a thousand deaths while awaiting execution in Iran.
A creepy, Lynchian dream-walk into the purgatory of human mass production
What starts as a clever documentary of Golden Gate Bridge jumpers becomes one the most compelling examinations of suicide ever put to film.
Not just a story of a person but a story of a neighborhood, a city and a plan to escape.
Who is the star here, Neil Young or Hank William's guitar?
Evelyn Glennie hosts a surrealistic ride through the waves of her preternatural percussion as she invites the audience to feel as they hear.
A desperate cop is in over his head under the spell of a reincarnated lesbian vampire with great hair.
People murdered in Africa, a plague on the way and large corporations behaving badly. Tea at the British embassy, anyone?
A documentary about the modern Israeli Maginot Line that keeps peace at bay as effectively as it limits terrorists.
As crazy as the sequel tries to be, it is about as funny as watching people eating worms on reality TV.
One of a handful of great nature documentaries that transcend the podium with fact made poetic.
Who says you can't make it with anyone by carrying pictures of Chairman Mao?
movie_title: Balzac and the Little Chinese Seamstress (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A flashy piece of artificial intelligence that travels at Mach-5 but goes nowhere.
A Rabelaisian journey of timeless humor that makes the audience an insider in the world of stand up comedy.
Featuring quadriplegic athletes who don't play well with others, "Murderball" is the essential human competitive spirit unchained.
In his final summation of the guilt, alienation and ennui that is the stuff of life, Bergman ends with a glimpse of hope in this, his last film.
Slow in the beginning, with a neophyte performance by lead Damien Nguyen, Nolte lends a helping hand with a weighty performance in the closing minutes.
Fast out of the gate but slowing in the back stretch, this film will need witchcraft to keep all but the hardiest fans awake for the final kiss.
Glen Close and a passel of young talent collide in a pot-boiling web of personal crises in the artistic bowels of Manhattan.
In spite of fighting performances by Quaid and Dern, its hard to bite on this ice-fishing pot-boiler.
A rom-com short on comedy, Apr√®s Vous has coziness to spare thanks to Auteuil, Kiberlain and Paris.
Dreamworks lets their computers do the talking in a fine cartoon freed of the weight of a significant message.
Priceless footage inside the secret church-state of North Korea and the beautiful Mass Games, this documentary sheds little light on the people themselves.
The world's first superstar shows you are only as Bohemian as you feel.
A dark and dangerous look into men's souls pits Romain Duris against his abusive father in the steamy streets of gangland Paris.
movie_title: De Battre mon Coeur s'est Arr√™t√© (The Beat That My Heart Skipped) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Deprived of his legacy, the brains behind the failed bank robbery that became Sidney Lumet's Dog Day Afternoon gets closer than ever to his fifteen minutes of fame.
In spite of the excessive TV feel, a great collection of information about a history-making bust and upper crust arrogance on an Olympian scale.
movie_title: Enron: The Smartest Guys in the Room (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Although narrow in its appeal, this tribute and capsule drama class by influential acting coach Roy London is a must-see for students and aficionados alike.
The blind faith of youth flies in the face of a grieving father's stubborn refusal to engage life and delivers a simple message of hope and sunny days to come..
The arcane world of elite dessert chefs forms the atmospheric setting one of the ultimate tests of strength and spirit. Another winner from Hegedus and Pennebaker.
Big Sky Country offers up an introspective teen drama about a teenage kleptomaniac who can't steal a break.
Westby's escapist fantasy's happy ending falls short of a meaningful message in spite of a rib-tickling individual effort by lead Melik Malkasian.
A scary movie made all the better by its inquisitive prodding of insanity, spirituality and freedom.
Light hearted TV fare that packs more wallop as a beer commercial than a romantic comedy.
A story of commitment that makes up for lack of glitz with currency of message.
Albert Brooks unleashes a low-key cross-cultural comedy that takes the Muslim world by storm but flies over the heads of American shopping mall audiences.
movie_title: Looking for Comedy in the Muslim World (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Ike Eisenhower lives on in a critique of the military-industrial complex. Is anyone surprised?
More education than entertainment, Mashayekh's first feature length film tells a valid story but fails to produce on the promise of court intrigues and swordplay.
movie_title: The Keeper: The Legend of Omar Khayyam (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Rashomon meets Spirited Away in a frenzied animated who-dunnit that dares the audience to join in the fun.
The deep and nearly imponderable lesson of Fateless makes its watching more duty than entertainment.
An entertaining film noir about a grasping tennis star who spins a deadly wheel of fate.
A haunting expose' about a camera with a mind of its own and the closet of skeletons it barely holds in check.
Indiana Jones goes to Jurassic Park in the reigning king of computer graphic monkey business, King Kong--2005.
Anthony Hopkins recreates a mechanical miracle in taking a 1920 motorcycle to 201 mph in the biopic of New Zealand's motorcycle saint Burt Munro.
A sweet movie that fails to make the distinction between old age and death.
An experiment in the brave new world of same-sex child-bearing goes badly and is turned into a film.
An edgeless one man show by Ribisi that acts like being insane.
A collision of adult sexual contradictions and teenage sexual survival filled with sensitivity, respect and, above all, humor.
Mid-life crisis takes on a completely new meaning when a skin and bones muscular dystrophy victim risks death for one last Harley ride and a bus to the Grand Canyon.
The pain of human isolation and the stark beauty of the desert make this preferred director's cut a giant re-release onto comparatively bland screens.
A propaganda fueled documentary that tries to probe our funnybone but fails to find the Michael Moore in anti-Semitism.
Bankrupt fascist politics and a talent in the ring combine to force decisions no teenager should have to make.
The Hungry Man deluxe of frozen entree mocumentaries, Anders and LeVinus break the seal on freshness with the sleeper slacker comedy of the year.
Veering at times towards film school, "Nine Lives" rewards the patient with scalpel-like insights into life as a woman in the USA.
Some very creative comic book artistry morphs into a film but fails to find significant connection with the sought after unconscious.
Entertainment by Philip Seymour Hoffman both fun and heartbreaking in the enthralling retelling of the American saga that was the end of Truman Capote.
Baroque gun-toting fantasy and an uneasy sound track by the 1960s Zombies make this the heavy teen self-destruct flick of the year.
Kingsley's Fagin takes us on a fantastic joyride through the sleazy and disease-ridden 19th century London tenderloin and leaves everybody smiling in the end.
Moments kinky and sweet put this spontaneous docu-fiction about growing up gay in the forefront of experimental narrative drama.
An uneven but entertaining romp amongst sexuality as varied as the textures of the French Riviera.
The rough trip of South African anti-apartheid hero Patrick Chamusso from apolitical worker to galvanized revolutionary and the brutal Afrikaner regime that tried to contain him.
A slick look at the cocaine trade of the 70s/80s that made Miami the home of more homicides per capita, and more banks per square mile, than any other city in America.
A fantastic and imaginative story of the normal and freakish in the fictitious prequel to the singular photography of Diane Arbus.
movie_title: Fur: An Imaginary Portrait of Diane Arbus (2006)

movie_review_blurb: An attempt at a tribute to a great man. Strummer doesn't need it.
movie_title: Joe Strummer: The Future Is Unwritten (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A classic that manages to combine sweet romanticism with upbeat and intellectual humor. A joy to watch.
A tribute to ultra-low budget explorations into the unknown and the politically incorrect. This is the stuff that art is made of.
The more famous Mapplethorpe is moved aside to give Sam Wagstaff the spotlight. But the best photography in the world steals the show.
movie_title: Black White + Gray: A Portrait of Sam Wagstaff and Robert Mapplethorpe (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A good performance of a landmark Broadway play will barely be enough to bring audiences to this one. But the history alone is worth the price of admission.
An entertaining look at the flagship of American empty calories, King Corn is a few bushels short of being the next Super-Size Me, but brings a legitimate message.

Failing fixer Clooney is great but has to fight for center stage next to supporting actress Tilda Swinton as the ethically maimed corporate attorney. Add Tom Wilkinson, Sydney Pollock and a dynamite screenplay and we have the thriller of year.
A buddy rom-com featuring Martin Freeman and Simon Pegg owes its success to on-screen chemistry but fails to shake the foundations of the silver screen.
If it only shows how love fits into people's lives in our liberated present times, that's enough for one night.
If Ayesha Dharker and the Kamasutra are waiting for me on the other side, outsource me up, Spock!
An R-rated Doris Day film set in a shopping mall. Amazing enough, but who will pay to see it?
A near miss by director/screenwriter Penn when he mistakes a self-absorbed college student for a hero of the counter culture
A creepy and daring look into one of the most destructive, and self-destructive of American anti-heroes
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A well done low budget indie production that lets the viewers' imagination picture how bad it gets when mother earth is finally pushed past the breaking point
A mysterious crime family with smoldering secrets plays with sharp objects off the slimy backwaters of the Thames. Cronenberg and Mortensen are at it again, with relish!
If an admirable attempt at the iconoclastic, Dans Paris is too much film school for an afternoon. Lacks even the modest structure and resolution that most audiences will demand.
Albert Pierrepoint single-handedly killed over 450 people in his career, dispatching most of them with an icy precision in less than 30 seconds.
New York's Little Italy is going to the dogs, check that, to the rats, and not just the rats in the local fast food joint. A zombie rat movie of the first order.
Zeta-Jones, Eckhart and Breslin play second fiddle to Ratatouille in what amounts to romantic drama fast food.
Although lacking the lyric force of March of the Penguins and Winged Migration, the film combines a great story with world-class photography to tell a unique National Geographic tale.
The squeaky clean love story of Jane Austen fails to make hay of either women's liberation or the miracle of creative writing, sticking to lush estates and courtly costume finery instead
A successfully executed cautionary tale condemning war and racism in the context of growing up in cloudy Northern England
A great romp with both Steve Buscemi and Michael Pitt having the time of their lives. Especially fun to see Pitt do something completely different.
A predictable expose' of a foreign country with a dictatorship that encourages the most violent of crimes. But how far away is America?
A valid exploration of chaos and control told by a guy who knows. Good low budget sci-fi with a hip side.
One successful story out of three is not good enough as Redford steps up to the plate. Too little first rate photography and too much collegiate tedium.
Try as he might, Director Garant cannot bring a winning performance out of this summertime silliness. Ping pong remains in disfavor as of the dog days of August.

Tommy Lee Jones combines forces with the Coen Brothers in the unforgiving winds of the West Texas prairie. Javier Barden's psycho-killer and the Coens' creepy direction and screenwriting pops out the grittiest film of the year.

Fun graphics, beautiful photography and great special effects will not save this tedious and self-absorbed epic from a direct trip to the DVD bin. The horse is beaten to death and even the bottled energy can't bring it back.
Not quite enough new here to make this film a hit, but enough of Theron, Hopper and Harrelson to make the film worth watching.
Telling a love story, and a story of tragic loss, has never been sweeter than through the archival footage of this totally independent documentary.
movie_title: Miss Universe 1929 - Lisl Goldarbeiter. A Queen in Wien (2006)

movie_review_blurb: What do Willie Nelson and one of the world's biggest environmental killers have in common? Austin Texas! A very local perspective on the corporate war on the environment
A most righteous cause, but one has to wonder if this is a documentary film, or an infomercial for the subject hospital

Shot in the unvarnished sets of New York's Iron Triangle, the unpaved mud holes of the streets and the rough plywood of bedroom walls tell an unforgettable story of growing up in a world with little pity
A scarred war hero and a delicately placed courtesan spar amongst the moldering walls of Restoration Paris. A graceful story of love's struggles amidst a brutal social climate of denial and despair.
movie_title: The Duchess of Langeais (Ne Touchez Pas La Hache)(Don't Touch the Axe) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: As much a comment on peace as on war, criminals do the right thing in the wrong context for the murderous boss in the suburbs. Dark comedy at its finest.
Visually stunning photography of the silent byways and crannies of the ancient medieval city of Bruges frames a story of guilt and honor played out by wonderfully demented hit men.
An extended cruise ship commercial run through the blender with "Gilligan's Island" sub-plots and slacker pratfalls. A teenager's story about treasure hunting that not even a teen-ager could love.
The fastest and best boxing action around plus a candid look inside the fight business make this a great film for aficionados of the sport. But there is not a lot there for most others.
A very real and state-of-the-art 3-D experience showing the undubbed work of the one the greatest rock bands and several of the greatest rock audiences in the world.
A few badly conceived scenes and misused actors cannot completely negate the positive message of this situation comedy. Diane Keaton deserves better, but lives to laugh another day.
Good special effects and some scary characters put together with great cinematography make this one notch up from a B horror film. Turn off those cell phones now, boys and girls.
A gentle and pleasant soap opera done in a fairly high cinematic style. The characters are far too attractive and the plot too simplistic, but the film grows on the viewer as the minutes glide by.
Hillary Swank makes the best of her lonely heart role but never gets to take off the gloves in an entertaining romantic drama. Supporting she-wolf Lisa Kudrow steals the show.
A sweet and masterful story of survival, transcendence, loyalty and friendship told with striking cinematography. A spiritual piece of work.

Even if we don't expect to learn much new from another analysis of the irrational, the glimpses of the illusions of the Warhol period, and the work of Danny Williams, are not enough to keep this pic afloat.
movie_title: A Walk Into the Sea: Danny Williams and the Warhol Factory (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Even if "Look" exploits reality TV by boosting a sub-marginal plot with very realistic security camera footage it is still a great perspective into our brave new world
Creepy and mysterious as The Usual Suspects, unseen forces and cryptic messages pit men against themselves in one of the darkest and best action-thrillers of the year.

Some of the most creative and beautiful cinematography of the year combined with the best performances to date by Knightly and McAvoy and earthshaking work by relative newcomer Romola Garai make this one of the best films out there
Taking on the most over-used documentary topic in America, this JFK assassination flick has to produce a new angle. It doesn't do it.
Exploiting what it is supposed to renounce, Badland combines a dreadfully long and dull screenplay and extremely plain surroundings to make a well-meaning anti-war film you'll want to miss.
Stepped up in edginess from the Errol Morris template, Yu's Greek tragedy of modern extremists weaves four disturbing stories into a cautionary tale in step with the times

A slimy log dumped into frigid Alaskan waters emerges as the hand-selected Steinway for a world-class performance. A fascinating look at the mini-city within New York City where hand work still prevails.
movie_title: Note by Note: The Making of Steinway L1037 (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The most disturbing and successful release since the start of the Iraqi war. Another anti-war film that may be too good for its own good.
Love conquers all, including the Nazi war machine and an angry wife, in Ohayon's new Holocaust documentary.
Heroic redemption succeeding where several thousand rounds of 9 mm ammo fail, Exiled makes a mark with the last stand of pals doomed by fate and the changing hands of time.
Ten astronauts try to tell it like it was, but weighted down by the heaviness of the politics that created the lunar exploration program, the best stories will have to wait for later
movie_title: In the Shadow of the Moon (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Great action, sets and camera work set this traditional western up for success in spite of stereotypical good guys and bad guys
The music industry kicks itself in the butt and vows to go straight as the founding fathers and mothers of rock decry the greed and falsehood that has suddenly crept into pop music.
A venture into the world of lust and love scripted with the beauty and discipline of Greek tragedy. As enthralling as it is disturbing. A must see for those who can tolerate the explicit sex.
If it's comic books you want, you'll love this look at Spartans versus Persians. Even better in IMAX, but don't expect much story to go along with the sound and fury.
If Heather Graham is on the way to becoming the next Goldie Hawn she has a ways yet to go in this soft-core coming out flick by Sue Kramer.

The fresh, bright and funny exploration of the bureaucracy of war, when mandatory Israeli military service meets "Laverne and Shirley." A touching and personal slice of life as two 18 year old women redefine the age-old battle of winning hearts and minds
Visually sumptuous but flat of plot, eccentric characters can't redeem this mildly funny romantic comedy from the hum-drum.
A clear and urgent essay on the battle for soldier's hearts and minds in the context of foreign wars. A great action war film featuring suburb acting throughout.

A neatly crafted thriller with first rate acting, directing and writing combined with spy paraphernalia and political intrigue. Fully deserving of its status as Germany's Best Foreign Film Oscar nominee.
The super-accurate reportage may be lost when combined with the war-flick plot. Fact and fiction have different audiences.
Alan Arkin tries, but fails, as the gold standard curmudgeon who never had it so good.
A pack of attractive Romanians do it werewolf style in a mixed bag of teenage romance and watered down scariness. Unfortunately, neither romance or horror enough for enthusiasts of either persuasion.

An engaging and honest journey through provincial Russia skillfully lensed from the perspective of a six year old. A powerful testimony to the human spirit and a strong statement in favor of the modern family.
A touching but slender piece on the number one news piece in Japan. But what is the rest of the story?
A well crafted five part ensemble drama of the toughest sort. Tight dialog, first rate acting and searing images make their statement on the tragedy of runaway abduction.
A lush and perfectly produced period piece that, if not increasing our pulse rate, at least provides viewing the whole family will enjoy.
Judi Dench and Cate Blanchett go the extra yard to bring genuinely anguished insight into the reverberation of sexual and personal predation.
A period piece with an edge, combining lush photography with an engaging script, strong acting and on-screen chemistry between Norton and Watts.
Golden mums by the millions spell incest and death as Yimou Zhang tests the American market for saturation with the martial arts. Our cup may be running over.
An engaging and humorous look at the father and son in all men. Very much worth the watching.
The inner city doesn't work for either Minghella or Law in this tedious pot-boiler that even Juliette Binoche can't pull out of the fire
A gripping triptych of the HIV virus taking hold of every shred of human frailty in a tale of a pandemic both sexual and commercial.
'The Piano Tuner of Earthquakes' is a semi-animated, human-acted fantasy that plays sweetly but takes too long to say too little.
A dynamite ensemble cast gives a good try but writer/director Emilio Estevez bites off more than he can script in a too ambitious Robert Altman experiment gone mediocre
Massive motion capture in a super-computerized animated romp in Antarctica with the feel-good theme of being yourself.
After 'Brokeback Mountain' Heath Ledger goes on to a second self-sacrificial role in the reigning standard of gritty and graphic junkie destruction derbies.
A plain-spoken film of true grit that tells the dishonorable heartbreak of war like it is. A gem of filmic honesty in an entertainment world obsessed with heroic actions and simple solutions.
movie_title: The Wind That Shakes the Barley (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Sandra Bullock morphs from the shopping mall rom-com queen to the sixth sense psycho but can't pull it off in this solo performance of woman's intuition gone bad.

A film with a depth of feeling seldom scene in commercial cinema, Charles Burnett's student project of life in LA's Watts neighborhood is a textbook of neo-realism and of the artistic use of the film media stripped to its basics.
Dark secrets eat away from within, but after 120 minutes of self-loathing this soapy tale fails to engage with either genuine mystery or genuine reconciliation.
A 'B' horror movie not bad enough to be good, Unearthed fails to build tension while also failing to give us a good monster.
Tremendous footage of war-torn Afghanistan and Pakistan combine with introspective thoughts of a life-style left behind in this engaging documentary.
French superstar Daniel Auteuil reunites with Cesar-nominated co-star Dany Boon from their previous sit-com "The Valet" to give light hearted comedy another try, with the same mixed results.
Realistic without being exploitative, Herzog tells one his best stories and one of the best survival epics ever.
The energy that flows out of the screen is not only uncontrollable, it is contagious. Miss this flick at your own risk.
Ben Kingsley takes it easy and gives Leoni and Wilson a chance to shine in this easy-going gangster comedy about friends and killers.
Without question one of the most bizarre love stories of the 20th century, backed up with a socko sound track and unmatched archival footage.
movie_title: Mi tao cheng shu shi (Crazy Love) (1993)

movie_review_blurb: One of the best films of the year and what will become an ageless standard in preserving and depicting aborigine culture and the tragicomedy of the human race.
A great sampler of Roma (Gypsy) music with outstanding road footage would be enough, but the insight into the Roma heart is priceless.
movie_title: When the Road Bends: Tales of a Gypsy Caravan (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A gripping look at hard times in pre WWII Paris and a passionate lead performance make this film a must-see for Piaf aficionados around the world.
How far would you go to eat a finger?
movie_title: American Cannibal: The Road to Reality (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Hal Hartley brings back Parker Posey as the spy who knows too little in this quick-witted follow-up to his 1998 "Henry Fool."
High quality pictures and a smashing sound track with no slack in the suspense until the curtain drops. A fine piece of fright.
Sigourney Weaver scores big with her first role in recent history that shows her at her best. Alan Rickman provides the perfect counterpart as the loneliest man in Central Canada.

For something completely different, controversial subject matter (New York bombing) combines with seamless set/surroundings to project a set of abstract images and a marginally successful experimental adventure.
An expressionist journey with the best, most shadowy sets, the most outrageous inventions and the most horrific childhood memories ever seen in a lighthouse or an orphanage, let alone both.
The engaging story of the obsession that is Broadway musical theatre with the world-class melodies and melodrama that go with it. A vibrant microcosm of human hopes and dreams.
"Rear Window" updated to post 9-11 corporate downsizing has too many mixed messages to convey the simple fear of a classic thriller.
Eighteen short stories in 120 minutes is almost too much to take but this film seems to bind them all together, somehow, with love.
Daniel Auteuil gets funny with an enjoyable 85 minute sit-com of how not to balance an irate and powerful wife with a smart and paparazzi-popular mistress.
Serpico meets the zombies at high noon as Pegg and Frost take a stab at the mock buddy cop movie with some funny lines but overall mixed results.
An eminently peaceful portrait of love and loss inviting the audience into the emotional inner workings of a snowy and somber Paris.
Fast paced, intriguing and fun from beginning to end with a super cast and nary a lack-luster performance---the years best scam flick so far.
An ambitious set of scrappy performances combined with a screenplay that threatens to fragment from shear edginess. Succeeds only due to the pure sincerity of the cast.
[The film] shows respect for open communications and differing life styles and lets the audience in on diverse feelings and ways of acting them out.
Although there is little new in this finely crafted WWII pot-boiler, it remains a thoroughly enjoyable wartime thriller during its entire 145 minutes of good-guy/bad-guy subterfuge.

Jackie (Kate Dickie) works as a CCTV operator. Each day she watches over a small part of the world, protecting the people living their lives under her gaze. One day a man appears on her monitor, a man she thought she would never see again, a man she never
A combination of poem and polemic. The obituary of a society that never had it better.
A genius at making money with computer games, space tourist Garriott will recoup little from this cartoon of a space adventure.
movie_title: Richard Garriott: Man on a Mission (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The cerebral side of the Great American Mortgage Meltdown. A classic documentary.
A great performance by Ben Stiller makes this an easygoing Sunday afternoon movie, if not one of Baumbach's best pieces of self-examination.
A real life interpretation of the "Godfather" series that strips away the glamour and leaves only despair.
The werewolves you can accept, the humans you can tolerate, but the Christians?
movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Change the things you can, accept the things you cannot, and go to jail and die either way.
Stripped down and heartfelt essay on what it takes to love and be loved.
A lean, no nonsense film crafted in the most brutally honest style of the Dardennes with a stellar performance by Marion Cotillard.
Johnny Depp as an updated Baron Munchausen.
A thrown together collection of hackneyed and screwball soft porn, toilet humor and predictable violence.
A deliciously deviant romp into sexual adventure grounded in the real life struggle for enduring intimacy.
Not as violent as the title would imply, this is a sterling essay in inner strength.
Jennifer Aniston does something completely different in this potboiler of a psychodrama and succeeds marvelously.
Although the book paints a better picture of Chris Kyle as a man, this is one RPG of a war story.
James Bond grows a brain but the audience is not buying it.
Put the time-travel gibberish into the background and the result is a great, gritty Aussie noir flick not to be missed.
Ignore the stoner humor and hackneyed clich√©s and appreciate the mood and setting of this most neo of the neo-noirs.
A rich performance with the pathos and drama of a new age of technology set within the hardships of war.
An oft told story is given stirring insight through first rate performances and production.
Walk on the bland side in a comic book of biblical proportions.
A rich slice of hardship and redemption from the unforgiving frontier.
Starting off as a great military/industrial complex send-up, the story flounders in the home stretch when it grasps at the serious and ends up in slapstick.
A tight knit and brutally honest essay on familial conflicts and the complications of living a Western dream in an environment of limited possibilities.
Then, again, so are many corporations.
A combination of spectacular special effects, marginal physics and grindingly slow treacle, McConaughey pulls this one out of the fire.
Screenwriting bromedy that shows Bollywood is not that much different than its American counterpart.
A lean and mean essay on human bondage, a minimalist examination of living life to the least.
Ripped from the headlines, it is not as good as "Capote," but close enough.
A lot of emotion but not enough screenplay to keep things moving even for the spare 92 minute run time.
This pot-boiler takes the viewer by surprise after a slow start, but the start is too long and the surprise too short.
Russell Crowe gives a nice try but gets no cigar in this maudlin rehash of a horrendous moment in history.
Hoping the pounding 60's soundtrack will jar the audience into enjoyment, this yarn evaporates into TV fluff.
Philosophy steps out of the classroom and into murder.
A good performance by Charlize Theron is all that saves this movie from the poverty porn dustbin.
Meryl Streep did not miss her calling as a rock star, but the chemistry with her daughter Mamie Gummer makes this flick a winner.
A thoroughly entertaining movie that probes our most painful history and provides a scalpel of a plot.
Television stops imitating life and becomes it in the first reality show of all time.
All the gadgetry and double the action fall short. But the pure charm of the movie saves the day.
An amazing look at the new world of methamphetamine manufacture and distribution and the losing battle locals are fighting against it.
A charming but fatally slow exposition of yet another real Sherlock Holmes.
Extracts from the Disney attractions are dreadful but personality wins the day in this light duty superhero tale.
A defense of the performing arts blossoms into a larger plea for democracy.
An almost fatally derivative fight flick is saved by a key performance and some good old on-screen fight hokum.
You will love every minute of this walk through show biz history.
Arnie is back with his tongue in his cheek and a toolbox of special effects.
An inside look at the 1970's Leon Russell that is not much of an inside look at all.
movie_title: A Poem Is A Naked Person (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Steps out on the edge with a fearless exploration of life told with exceptional creativity. A refreshing and remarkable accomplishment.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The reigning king of special effects lacks the clever acting of the original, but triples the action in 3-D IMAX.
Some films take hundreds of hours of tedious work and countless exhausted nights of ulcerous brooding. Some simply make themselves.
Take a walk on the wild side with thirty nine scenes that make the complicated trivial.
movie_title: A Pigeon Sat on a Branch Reflecting on Existence (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Formula slapstick and slick production makes a must see, but only for Melissa McCarthy fans.
A cute walk through history with an unwilling history-maker.
movie_title: The 100-Year-Old Man Who Climbed Out the Window and Disappeared (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The lack of acting and screenplay is hardly a bump in the road for this hyperventilating 3D quake-a-palooza.
Safe and sane hip dialogue, beautiful people and a cast to die for drive this rom-com one step ahead of the crowd.
The men and women of the American western frontier make their plans but fate decides their disposition in this stylish western noir.
There are some people from NYC and there are some people who make NYC. Iris is one of the latter.
