This is a straight ahead essay on warfare at its worst and the survival of the human spirit at its best.
One of the sparest documentaries ever produced, this film takes the audience into the very heart of mechanized food production.
Ed Harris is back in command and the world depends on him. Look out.
Slow and imperturbably bookish, this film slowly reveals the dark and threatening side of life in the big city.
An inside look into one of the most secretive and sophisticated intelligence apparatus in the world may not be what you expected.
One of the most powerful war stories to appear on screen. A story of the universal defeat of war and the enduring survival of the human spirit.
A stark, romantic and beautifully executed version of the Grimm fairy tale.
A cautionary tale of humans adjusting to their environment, instead of attempting to make the environment adjust to them.
movie_title: Happy People: A Year in the Taiga (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A little too slick to be the next great action film and not funny enough to be dark comedy, this over produced bullet fest barely keeps going for its 98 minutes.
A fluffy excuse for random violence is saved by ethereal performances by Saoirse Ronan and James Gandolfini.
The gritty beauty of the time of the original melting pot and the mysterious origins of the most famous photo in the world.
A nail biting triumph from the lethal streets of Nazi occupied Lvov through the sub-human underground of the city and back into the world of the living.
Two Italian teenage girls defy the suffocation of small town, traditional Italy and emerge at the end of the day with dreams intact.
The latest and greatest in a string series of films about the second highest mountain in the world and the pilgrims who try to climb it.
Non-reality TV finds a place in war-torn Afghanistan in this insightful slice of life of the fledgling broadcast industry.
A touching, and sad, piece of history and a brilliant performance by Juliette Binoche.
Life and love on the rocks finds a way in The City of Light in this pleasing, light hearted romantic comedy.
Too much of the same emotion and too little back-story doom this movie to tedium.
A fresh and very funny look at the romantic comedy through the Korean-American lens.
A funny walk on the meshugener side for those who can still laugh at religious stereotypes.
Rote sci-fi dogma fails this flick well before the finish line.
The Vesuvius of social-psychological potboilers. All the screaming and twice the anguish of the average Italian movie.
A high-energy music doc that will make almost anybody appreciate Hip-Hop.
Closure or exploitation, you be the judge.
movie_title: Out of the Clear Blue Sky (2013)

movie_review_blurb: This mission is a bit stilted from beginning to end.
A short and easygoing film, this is a great movie to take in before dinner and one you should see when it comes to your local art house. Do not miss this bus.
movie_title: La Camioneta: The Journey of One American School Bus (2013)

movie_review_blurb: An inexperienced cast and crew try to rush this atmospheric heist flick and the result is a visually striking film noir that runs out of gas.
Straightforward old school mental anguish combined with all the moodiness the Irish Sea can muster, a thoroughly professional crime thriller from start to finish.
All the geeks, thrills and laughs, and double the technology, of the toughest motorcycle race in the world gone electric.
A lively and funny essay on the life in love and the survival of love.
movie_title: Tutti i santi giorni (Every Blessed Day) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A riveting mystery drama about living, dying, illusion and reality.
With all the depression and twice the passion of Camus' final novel, this film comes as close as could be imagined to putting the impossible on the silver screen.
This is a cryptic film for those who do not know the story. Learn the story first and the film comes to life.
The sparks almost fly in this slow and tedious look at the, well, slow and tedious side of computers.
A band call Death comes back to live in this hilarious and poignant peon to hard rock with a soft heart.
A collection of home movies so pathetic and shocking that the viewer cannot help but feel at least temporary sympathy for Richard M. Nixon.
Charge up Amelie's cell phone, rev up the scooter, and we are off to save the world.
A film that would be a satire were it not so chillingly real.
Although just one of the many Ali films, this is a great look at an American hero and the price he paid to preserve freedom for us all.
Touching and believable.
A work of art or a double shot of depression. Prepare yourself if you take in this study of love and loss.
In fact, the revolution will be televised.
Although this film is a "must see" for baseball aficionados, its narrow scope takes it out of the big leagues.
The outcome of this adapted play by debut director Nick Sandow is well short of the mythical trifecta.
Truth that is undeniably stranger than fiction. A film that shows us that we may have found the enemy, and it may be us.
Inspired by a true story, this Disneyish sally to the crash site that spawned a miracle lacks the muscle of reality.
A thoughtful look at the unthinkable, Lorene Scafaria preserves impending doom with humor and a new appreciation for tomorrow.
movie_title: Seeking a Friend for the End of the World (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Although appealing to narrow slice of art aficionados, "Abramovic' carries a deeper message, and a warning, to an increasing mechanized and medicated world
movie_title: Marina Abramovic: The Artist Is Present (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Lynn Shelton's fourth feature after her well-received "Humpday" demands more patience than understanding.
A remarkable work of indie craftsmanship. The forgotten people who point the way to the forgotten side of the Western world.
Thoroughly well scripted and well-acted. May be the greatest work to date from one of the greatest directors working.
Great camera work and postproduction combined with the genuine grit of police work make this a film to see.
A little too slick to be a classic, "Unit 7" comes off more as a violent autograph session than a tragic cop drama.

A remarkable statement about a modern paperless product with paperless funding, paperless sales and paperless enjoyment. However, the exposure of the artists and the hovering threat of failure will never change.
Skipping over the neighborhood like a spinning stone, Lee's rocking Red Hook looks great in Technicolor.
Legendary Russian director Andrei Zvyagintsev creates a great film noir.
Good overall plot and production that do not come together in the sharp focus of a conventional horror film. Entertaining nonetheless.
One of the most touching films of the year. A brilliant tragedy that transcends boundaries of age, country, race, religion and gender.
No surprises here, just a fun and funny piece of PG eye candy.
A message in favor of the environment from someone who really means it.
A commendable ultra-low budget indie road trip flick, "Natural Selection" fails to fire on all cylinders.
Packs a lot of Lower East Side quirkiness into 97 minutes. Maybe too much.
A tragic figure in the person of an eleven year old, but a boy who never gives up.
This film overflows with Kiwi humor that, unfortunately, will be lost on many audiences.
The birth of the cool in the USSR forged into a rocking Soviet Graffitti that will heat the world.
Keen insights into an ancient society do not give this film the boost it needs to make an impact.
Taika Waititi's journey into the heart and soul of an 11-year-old boy in New Zealand will take you back, regardless of your country.
The bottled chaos that once was Bobby Liebling and the band Pentagram did not age well.
Teenage Alma takes on all of the taboos of Western sexuality in this delightful coming-of-age fairytale.
A dreadfully slow screenplay in the second half undercuts the interesting handling of black and white exposition.
An unprecedented inside look at Chinese politics and a fascinating tour of modern art at the same time.
A sweet junket into the land of the new agers, and youth that refuses to grow old.
A fine example of unabashed bloodletting in the context of the two worst applications of capitalism in our history, bounty hunting and slavery.
An examination of life and death, this minimalist film succeeds on all levels.
Christian Petzold's latest thriller threatens to cross over the line from minimalism to nihilism.
Take a step back in time to visit the home of FDR and Eleanor, but have a cup of coffee, first.
Emerging director Andrew Dominick comes out swinging in this nonsensical gangland farce.
The rock documentary to be seen by all those who swore they would never see another.
An updated, streamlined version of the Tolstoy classic will appeal to a younger demographic while the oldsters will stick to reading the book.
Although not adding substantially to the written story, the film is an excellent screen treatment of one of the most fantastic tales ever told.
More thoroughly enjoyable performances than would fit into the Oscar slate. Sacha Gervasi smacks it over the fence.
A must see for Python disciples, this extensively produced 3D string of animations will run hot and cold with the general public.
movie_title: A Liar's Autobiography - The Untrue Story of Monty Python's Graham Chapman (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A man is born out of the ashes of defeat to act out a spectacular war story that may never end.
Steamy court intrigue, wild passion and the momentous decisions of charismatic visionaries have never had it better than this 18th Century Danish potboiler.
If the subject interests you, buy and read a couple of Iceberg's books. This film is for entertainment only, although there is substantial entertainment to be had.
movie_title: Iceberg Slim: Portrait Of A Pimp (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A walk down the seamy side of Wall Street is pulled out of the shredder by Gere's performance, but only barely.
A luscious exploration of halfway points in love, morally and freedom against the backdrop of industrial Turkey.
A major leap upward for both Baumbach and Gerwig. Disarming, funny and genuine, in spite of the New York City backdrop.
Great photography and a vibrant performance by Romain Duris barely keep this lead-footed psycho-drama afloat.

It takes actors of the caliber of Walken and Harrelson to bring the right mix of absurdity and humanity into the world of psychopathic crime. They were perfectly chosen for this film and their parts were perfectly executed.
An outrageous screenplay, disciplined direction and dedicated acting make this film a disturbing success.
A rambling assault on the visual cortex that teeters between guided meditation and guided tour.
A moderately crafted assemblage of violent rural American stereotypes. Falls far short of the high bar set by "The Proposition."
Fascinating combination of the technical and the aesthetic. The best exhibition to date of the digital revolution in filmmaking.
A hilarious, courageous and fascinating trip into the soft underbelly of back market African politics.
After seeing this film, you may never buy at a garage sale, again.
The program is secure, but are we?
The story of one of the greatest orchestras in the world, born out of one of the worst tragedies of the 20th century, the holocaust.
Total Recall won't leave you with a lot to remember, but this science fiction shoot-'em-up is as good a way as any to forget about life's cares on a summer day.

Major League smacks a solid base hit when the players decide their best revenge against the team's owner would be to win the American League pennant. It doubles when these guys begin to come together as a real team.
It has a great score of obscure '50s rock and doo-wop. It has the candy-colored look of a '50s musical. What it doesn't have is a moment of anything that seems remotely real.
Maybe Blaze is too pure, and the governor too outrageous to be true. But Shelton works their story into a romantic tall tale as beguiling as the spin of the lady's tassels.

If you like to think of every time at bat as a new hope, if you can taste a kind of poetry along with the hot dogs they serve at the ballpark, if you like to imagine that life is meant to be good, and miracles aren't out of the question... go see [it].
Dances With Wolves is flat-out the year's best movie to date.
A dismal and mean-spirited sequel to one of the best movies of the 1980s.
movie_title: Back to the Future Part II (1989)

movie_review_blurb: Along with Sicario, this has to be one of the most impressively shot movies of the year.
[This] generally cheerful, silly, and recklessly gross movie also feels paradoxically sobering.

In terms of mere spectacle, Spectre has some wonderful driving stunts, a tremendous introduction for the character played by Christophe Waltz, and a production lavish in glass architecture and supercars.
On paper, this sounds like ridiculous and fun. Perhaps it should have remained on paper.
For putting the science back into science fiction, the movie deserves to be seen. As a great popcorn experience, it will be.
It gives us a Bulger impression by Johnny Depp that is notable mainly for the uglifying hair-thinning makeup. The man is utterly impassive unless strangling people.
Alternately exhilarating, funny, and eye-rollingly corny.
Ultimately, Babylon A.D. is more of an advertisement for an extended and fixed cut, than an outright failure.
It is as monotonous and predictable as rain in November.
It left me stirred, if not shaken.
The result is fairly impressive but ultimately busy and wearying.
[Features] some of the least watchable animation since Warner Brothers reinvented Bugs Bunny and Daffy Duck as kung-fu swordsmen with laser eyes.
This high-intensity rage and the resultant property damage are not just interesting metaphors: they're boffo entertainment.

It's a profound movie, and a fine one. I've not even mentioned the visual aspect, which is miles above similar effects pictures, but we would expect that, not the excellence of filmmaking that contains it.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: My suggestion is to wait for the DVD, so that you can just skip over all the parts that don't make sense, filling in the gaps with dramatic readings from Dirt Bike.
If you don't already love costumed adventurers, this outing won't give you any fresh incentive, but fans will learn more about their heroes.
It's a well-acted, fun, and zippy time at the movies.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: In its attention to minute detail of the towers, The Walk also serves as a tribute to something lost, a new fairytale: how these buildings got their soul.
The shock and glory is seeing this loopy sensibility transferred to the screen with little softening and no apology.
It is a story rich with action and tragedy. As a movie, unfortunately, it is leaden and dispiriting to the point where I was wondering what went wrong.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: [Blends] playful spectacle with a sense of bonding among a chosen family.
Only Holtzmann thrives as a character, as the group's intensely, almost malevolently creative armourer. McKinnon is riveting, in every sense.
At worst, it is a respectful attempt to update a golden-oldie character with pop psychology, a moderate, Netflixish level of sex and violence, and current (if not exceptional) special effects.
A movie that plays like a series of trailers for expensive disaster movies.
Gunn has certainly given Marvel another successful product, with likable actors, comprehensible motivations, and clear fight staging, set at a pace that could fairly be described as rollicking.

A well-made, somewhat serious-minded adventure flick is a rare thing, even one that does not seem quite as deliciously new as J.J. Abrams's 2009 reinvention -- which is merely to say that it is not my new favourite popcorn flick of all time.
The main tension of the story is a constant vuvuzela-like interruption in the suspension of disbelief.
The best thing about Warcraft is that it is character driven and feels personal, which is an amazing quality to have in an expensive effects picture.
The problem is presenting the follies of Wall Street as an ordinary crime, the fault of one specific villain who just acted incorrectly. Catch that one guy, and I guess everything is just fine.
It also feels alive and true. Despite its grim plot hooks, the jokes mostly land.

The movie aspires to be real, groundbreaking, and important in a way that can only recall Will Arnett's Batman in The Lego Movie, a film with more wit, fewer "it was only a dream" montages of gloom, and, truth be told, more believable special effects.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Like a real family reunion, it is a somewhat exhausting experience, but good enough to make me watch Big Fat Greek Funeral or something.
It's a buddy-cop action comedy of the sort that you have seen approximately infinity times before. It is also, of course, a good Ice Cube movie.
This is corny, old-fashioned adventure stuff, down to the hero being so diffident that he seems overwhelmed by his future bride. Then again, it's January. And corn is delicious.
It's an absolutely lavish bouquet to series fans, who get to see the entire X-saga summarized and effectively reconceived through Wolverine's desperate and time-addled perceptions.
Moodily shot, this classic "old dark house" picture is played mostly for laughs.
English is the lingua franca of Brillante Mendoza's The Captive, which seems to have been directed by his younger brother, Mediocre Mendoza.
A waste of money and 140 minutes of one's time.
If one accepts the narrative simplicity and that the journey is both physical and spiritual, the film offers many rewards.
movie_title: Journey to Italy (Viaggio in Italia) (Strangers) (The Lonely Woman) (1954)

movie_review_blurb: The international success of this Italian spectacle, the longest and most expensive motion picture made up to that date, allowed DW Griffith to gain support for his large-scale projects.
It took Jacques Tati close to ten years to realise his greatest achievement, but it left him virtually broke. No wonder.
Out of the three episodes based on the macabre tales by Edgar Allan Poe, the third -- the only modern-day one, directed by Federico Fellini -- is far and away the best.
Griffith turned it into a rather maudlin and naive morality tale -- though it didn't merit the hostile reviews that it initially received.
This domestic tragicomedy with a feminist slant was [Dreyer's] seventh feature and anticipates his greatest films.
Without actual imitation, Rohmer and his cinematographer Nestor Almendros were inspired by German Romantic painters and bathe the neo-classical interiors in an unearthly light.
movie_title: Die Marquise von O... (The Marquise of O) (1976)

movie_review_blurb: The superb German actor Conrad Veidt plays the pathetic protagonist, while Mary Philbin, whose most celebrated screen role was opposite another physically damaged hero in The Phantom of the Opera, is extremely touching as his beloved.
Italy's great ringmaster of the cinema returns to the source of his inspiration -- the circus -- and skilfully absorbs it into his own personal vision.

Tender loving care abounds in the production... The casting is great, with the inexperienced giving it a naivety that is essential to the story, and the veterans a rock-solid identification with evil (Cushing) and good (Guinness).
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode IV - A New Hope (1977)

movie_review_blurb: A majestic achievement, representing a superb blending of the motion picture arts by master craftsmen.
Measures up to the promise Ballard amply provided in his first feature, The Black Stallion.
It's a warm, human, sometimes sentimental and an enjoyable experience.
Some fine vignettes of frontier life in the early southwest and a realistic presentation of the difficulties faced by the settlers in carving out a homestead in dangerous Indian country.
Building on character development and plot points from the first two films, this story manages to feel both like a complete tale in and of itself and like the successful continuation.
Rings is not a film to watch if you're looking for a scare and it doesn't really fall into the enjoyably bad or cheesy vein of horror either.
All in all, there really isn't anything new in this film. Rather, it's a very standard horror film which attempts to be modern by incorporating social media deeply into its lack-of-plot.
A corporate-sponsored, feature-length infomercial on behalf of the core entrepreneurial values of the U.S. of A., Proud American combines unabashed hokiness with relentless oversimplification.
Virtual JFK reps an extended glimpse into a bygone era of statesmanship.
movie_title: Virtual JFK: Vietnam If Kennedy Had Lived (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Brimming with energy, elan and the unpredictability of his Something Wild, Jonathan Demme's triumphant Rachel Getting Married may just lay the wedding film to rest, being such a hard act to follow.
Micah Schaffer's moving, stunningly shot docu juxtaposes the deaths of a Guinean in America and an American in Guinea.
The talky redemption element, however, ultimately feels artificially tacked on.
Hardly revelatory, sometimes downright redundant pic nevertheless covers its myriad bases succinctly, while rejecting both grandstanding indignation and self-nullifying 'fairness'.

This low-key tale of an improbable friendship between an out-of-work Italian-American and a young Mexican illegal alien in Queens maintains an engaging, even keel through bumpy tonal shifts that would derail most indie outings.
Lays out the pieces of a highly stylized noir puzzle with maddening deliberation and total lack of humor.

Stephen Dorff's powerhouse perf as an ordinary Joe trapped behind bars with warring ethnic psychopaths propels "Felon" well ahead of its expose/exploitation brethren while still avoiding the pious learning curves of Frank Darabont's prestige prison dramas
Pic looks very much like a protracted man-of-the-week spot on a local newscast.
This complex, utterly fascinating docu evolves in almost as varied and unpredictable ways as has its 96-year-old subject, famed sculptress Louise Bourgeois.
movie_title: Louise Bourgeois: The Spider, the Mistress and the Tangerine (2008)

movie_review_blurb: [A] must-see docu for theater lovers could reach wider auds.
The pic comes off as too scattershot to do anything but skim the questions it raises about the nature of the image as spiritual beacon and corporate logo.
The story of Kassim "the Dream" Ouma and his rise from Ugandan child soldier to world champion boxer combines serious human rights issues with incredible triumph-over-adversity sports lore.
A terminally lame puberty comedy about a prematurely bald 13-year-old.
We Are Together stands as a celebration of resiliency.
movie_title: We Are Together: The Children of Agape Choir (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Pic's strength lies in charting a dual process, that of a play taking shape in an incredibly short amount time and of the changes wrought in the children's behavior as they learn to listen, focus, follow directions and work as a team.
Ultimately, pic's fascination lies with the personalities and strategies of the candidates themselves.
Zero-budgeter proves uneven, its unseasoned cast unable to fully flesh out the perfunctory setups.
[An] uneven but enjoyably titillating black comedy.

Fresh out of NYU film school, Blitstein films what he knows: His tale of a young filmmaker's writer's block gleefully incorporates all manner of antic styles, from Mack Sennett-style double-takes to Felliniesque black-and-white pantomime.

While docu's claims and criticism yield nothing especially new, the form of their exposition seems singularly ingenious, stylistically falling somewhere between a 1950s educational film and some sort of Norman Rockwellian infomercial.
Among movies about fans' obsessive fixations on fictional universes, the film registers neither as bemusedly distanced as Trekkies nor as dramatically engaged as King of Kong.

When the history of the sport is allowed to unfold through the reminiscences of geriatric Yiddish pros, pic approaches the richness of its impressive archival trove. Too often, however, director David Vyorst's chauvinistic agenda intrudes.
This mostly black-and-white, dreamlike yuletide fable does possess its own dorky DIY charm.
Constitutes an irrefutable argument for classic 2-D animation as a viable, vibrant low-budget arthouse medium for adults.
Helmer/co-scripter Tan conceives of his two characters as complementing each other within a minor key.

Matthew Broderick regains his cinematic stride as a morosely wise-cracking television producer on the skids, ably abetted by Maura Tierney as his much-put-upon wife and Brittany Snow as his perky prostitute niece.
Expansively, dramatically, magnificently Russian, Nikita Mikhalkov's loose remake of 12 Angry Men plays like vintage jazz from a veteran band.
Handcuffed to a story with no internal development and without the stylistic rigor to transform its jerky stop-and-start rhythm into an aesthetic, pic jumps from one disconnected scene to another.
Sometimes strident and combative, and sometimes celebratory and encouraging, uneven pic often feels like a cobbled-together recap of '70s feminist issues, still patently unresolved.
movie_title: Who Does She Think She Is? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Whether or not one buys into pic's vision of government as irreversibly corrupt, the leap from the general to the specific registers as unconvincing at best.

Compelling docu chronicles the actions of the coalition of Christian and Muslim women who prevailed over warlords and warriors to halt the decades-long fighting that claimed their fathers, brothers, husbands and children.
movie_title: Pray the Devil Back to Hell (2008)

movie_review_blurb: As in Metzgar's Chances of the World Changing and his recent Reporter, the helmer's quiet narration and sharp focus grant his subjects a matter-of-fact dignity.

Pic loses its delicate edge when it builds to a prescribed dramatic flashpoint within an overly compressed timeframe -- a structural holdover from the pic's stage play roots that ultimately tips it into meller territory.
Spinning a wry, tall-tale version of his autobiography, the septuagenarian audaciously plays himself at every age and every stage of his improbably picaresque adventures.
In Beth Murphy's intriguing docu Beyond Belief, two Massachusetts women whose husbands were killed on 9/11 reach out to victims on the other side -- Afghan widows.
Andrew Jenkins' amateurish, half-hearted romantic comedy-cum-heist film twists itself into unconvincing knots to pull off a guilt-free bank robbery.
Arguably stronger conceptually than visually, surreal mix of the unexpected and the banal is definitely not to everybody's taste. But the music is inarguably sublime.
movie_title: The Silence Before Bach (Die Stille vor Bach) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Boys functions swimmingly as both a bigscreen inflation of smallscreen icons and a fairly hilarious stand-alone.
Hutt's straightforward presentation tends to flatten out pic's anomalies instead of highlighting them.
Fascinating, wryly distanced docu[mentary].
Pic deeply entrenches itself in the landscape, conveying both the beauty and the ravagement of the Appalachians.
movie_title: Burning the Future: Coal in America (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Morosely pretentious.
Chicken creeps up on the viewer and, by the final credits, insinuates a lot of peripheral information that somehow adds up to a very unique experience.
[Director Marion] Cajori's inventive, endlessly fascinating two-hour take draws freely from those prior studies, and from footage featuring Close and his contemporaries.
movie_title: Chuck Close: A Portrait in Progress (1997)

movie_review_blurb: Precise lensing, a strong sense of locale and vibrant, eminently likeable perfs enliven Arranged.
The script delivers a series of low blows to the intelligence from which auds will never recover.
Every bit as single-minded as its French-Canadian protagonist, pic drowns a potentially interesting story in careful literalism and elaborate period detail.
Pic's portrait of a collaborative artist whose contributions are as pervasive as they are unsung swims valiantly against the name-recognition tide.
Evident throughout is Chaiken's ability to patiently build a scene without fanfare or artifice.
Moore and Hill's script plunges [Sissy] Spacek in a mawkish stew of banality and improbability composed of bits and pieces of earlier roles.
exquisite, light-drenched tone poem
movie_title: By√¥soku 5 senchim√™toru (5 Centimeters per Second) (A Chain of Short Stories about Their Distance) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Paradoxically, the beauty and splendor of the Grand Canyon...almost belies this docu's dire ecological message
movie_title: Grand Canyon Adventure: River at Risk (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Though consistently maintaining a wryly observed interaction between the motley, convertible-bound threesome, the pic fails to get much mileage out of encounters along the way.
After the gimmicky audience-shot concert film "Awesome ... ," Beastie Boy Adam Yauch proves he can make a comprehensive, state-of-the-art docu of interest to basketball aficionados.
Frank Langella's note-perfect, tour-de-force turn as a man elegantly shaping his own demise is nicely counterpointed by a shambling Elliott Gould as a bird-watching private eye.
King fascinates on many levels as it ticks off intriguing sociological facts about this impoverished nation.
Beyond its cool, reflective surfaces and infinite plays with perspective lies nothing -- character, relationships, motives all seemingly irrelevant.
Oren Jacoby's magnificent, thought-provoking essay film Constantine's Sword examines the unholy alliance between organized religion and military power.
A convoluted bilingual thriller about a kidnapping in Colombia, Towards Darkness may be too clever for its own good.

Unfortunately, Ari Libsker's hour-plus docu on this potentially mind-boggling topic meanders disconnectedly, as various experts, collectors and storytellers kick around anecdotes and theories that tend to cancel each other out.
Somewhat schematic in its dual professional/personal focus, pic successfully demonstrates the stages of social development through the private dramas of its individual subjects.

Culturally falling somewhere between Sideways and Dumb and Dumber, this low-rent road movie similarly rides on principles of audience identification, largely minus competent helming, thesping or scripting.
A Herculean saga worthy of Werner Herzog's Fitzcarraldo (or perhaps Les Blank's Burden of Dreams).
Eric Guirado's documentary background grants a rare richness of detail and unforced humor to his seductive second feature.
movie_title: Le fils de l'√©picier (The Grocer's Son) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: DV-shot exercise in gay teen angst.
[Adam] Carolla's gangling charm and improv rhythms nicely loosen up helmer Charles Herman-Wurmfeld's studied setups without ever deviating from the story's solid underlying structure.
Subject matter definitely trumps stylistic nuance in this solid journeyman effort.
Barnz arbitrarily posits a nonsensical series of school "rules" to embody conformity, while imagination is repped by Tourette syndrome.

Despite the presence of Glen Matlock, Steve Dior and a handful of other punk rockers, plus a slew of oblique eyewitness who lurked around before and after the fact, the docu soon bogs down in tiresome minutiae.

Likable but lightweight 2007 slacker comedy Skills Like This coasts on laid-back absurdist rhythms as three twentysomething pals scramble to redefine themselves in the wake of one's self-affirming discovery of his talents as a thief.
The duo's longtime partnership imparts a palpable, lived-in intimacy, but lack of careful story construction sometimes hobbles the narrative's comic flow.
Spins experimental imagery and mystical manifestations into a gossamer-thin, ponderously off-the-wall plot.
Reznick's sound design effectively jangles nerves, and two setpieces trumpet his visual prowess: a languid lovemaking scene lit by indirect flashlight and a tour-de-force musical number.
Comes off as a painfully old-fashioned, flatly directed exercise in passionless historical reenactment.

Evocatively fleshed out with surprisingly iconic homemovies, passionate love letters and well-chosen pop tunes, Kleine's homegrown Jewish Madame Bovary escapes the navel-gazing boundaries of the personal-diary docu
David Ridgen and Nicolas Rossier's docu on Norman Finkelstein, American Radical, promises to prove as controversial as the man himself.
movie_title: American Radical: The Trials of Norman Finkelstein (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Another expertly written joyride through the confines of narrowminded provincialism to cleansing self-awareness from indie director de Felitta.
Dramatically and pictorially pulls its weight.

Murray Lerner's mesmerizing docu closely chronicles Cohen's set, only occasionally breaking away to record audience reactions or interview fellow performers, who even today profess astonishment at how Cohen turned the night around.
movie_title: Leonard Cohen Live at the Isle of Wight 1970 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Techine fashions a brilliantly complex, intimate multi-strander, held together but somewhat skewed by the central perf of Emilie Dequenne.
movie_title: The Girl on the Train (La Fille du RER) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The film's most amazing character is the fantastic garbage town of Mokattam itself, with its winding alleyways piled high with trash, its buildings half exposed, riddled with crevices stuffed with bags of refuse.
Explores beliefs as pervasive as they are largely unexamined.

Chronicling the couple's one-on-one relationship issues and roadway encounters of the eccentric and downright traumatic kind, the pic shifts tonal gears with ease, its trio of lead thesps registering realistically if not always engagingly.
Utterly engrossing dual-character study, unfolding with a serene disregard for indie quirkiness, Goodbye Solo radiates authenticity.
Likable but insubstantial.
movie_title: For My Father (Sof Shavua B'Tel Aviv) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It is the presence of Duncan as a Mike Tyson-esque, malaprop-spouting ex-champion that, at least momentarily, lifts the pic out of its mediocrity.
Thoroughly likable, it never resorts to sentimental cliches or moralistic epiphanies.
Timothy Hutton's fine, loose-limbed perf as a man adrift lifts Multiple Sarcasms, frosh scribe-helmer Brooks Branch's male menopause apologia, out of cliche-ridden territory -- at least temporarily.
Throughout, writer-director Ross displays a fine ear for slightly off-kilter conversation and dialogue that sounds deceptively impromptu.
Too scattershot to present a truly coherent picture of the burlesque experience, docu nevertheless provides a privileged front-row seat to sample several of the form's most memorable practitioners.
Ace thesps struggle to lift this dour indie out of the doldrums, but writer-director Richard Levine allows them no breathing room.
For a film about a master of minimalism, Vidal Sassoon the Movie trades in excess.

Howlingly bad films are a dime a dozen, but the evident Ed Wood-like sincerity with which writer-director James Nguyen lovingly crafted this compendium of cinematic don'ts gives it a goofy, almost surrealist charm.
Its laid-back absurdist tone and no-nonsense pacing make for an audio-visual delight.
On a plot level, few of the psychodrama elements make much sense.
Her eclectic pantheon weighs in with entertaining anecdotes and illuminating comments, illustrated with well-chosen samplings of the artists' work.

Cohesive, well-structured docu from veteran filmmakers Kate Davis and David Heilbroner boasts a panoply of found footage, graphically positioning the uprising as a flashpoint following decades of repression.
Davis sustains a steady level of soft humor throughout, thanks to her heroine's inexhaustible shockability and the palpable charm of the other thesps.
Despite its infotainment look, Burzynski ultimately proves convincing.
Hopkins rises to the occasion by refusing to make a heroic feel-good film about saving the world one life at a time.
movie_title: Living in Emergency: Stories of Doctors Without Borders (2010)

movie_review_blurb: While remaining faithful to its source, places its febrile "Moscow Hamlet" in surroundings so vibrant that tragedy seems an indulgence.
Jose Rivera and Tim Sullivan's script relentlessly piles on goopy conversation-stoppers like "Do you believe in destiny?" and "I didn't know that true love had an expiration date."
Veering wildly between paranoia and self-aggrandizement, Spector makes a fascinating subject.
movie_title: The Agony and the Ecstasy of Phil Spector (2010)

movie_review_blurb: By and large, the docu's closely reasoned case synchs up nicely with Soling's freewheeling visual approach.
Avoids preaching to the choir, though perhaps only the choir will attend.

The pic serenely unfolds at the slow and steady pace of its indomitable subjects, ultimately rewarding viewers' patience as individual personalities and stories emerge amid the threatened sale of the Catskills colony.
The pic never completely escapes a smallscreen feel, however cogent the material.
Highly entertaining docu A Wink and a Smile provides an eye-opening lesson in the theory and practice of stripping.
Despite the pic's erotic subject matter and star (vet porn diva Sasha Grey), nothing could be less sensationalistic -- or moralistic -- than this fascinating study of free enterprise in free fall.

It seems particularly perverse to take actors who helped develop the '60's thesping style of hang-loose, semi-improvisational immediacy and stick them in a creaky period piece glazed with arch gentility and ersatz quaintness.
Though stuffed with witty one-liners and wondrously convoluted tirades, this far-fetched, deliberately artificial game of musical chairs...feels forced, often losing itself in excess verbiage.
Well-crafted pic traverses the globe, interviewing a who's-who of gurus and investigating a wide range of regimens -- with Rosen as both questioner and body-contorting guinea pig.
Witty, engaging and exquisitely crafted.
Harmony and Me eschews the fits and starts, tensions and complexities of present-tense immediacy in favor of sly, absurdist one-liners, paring everything down to comic essentials.

With imaginative handling, this freewheeling juggernaut of a head-trip, its assorted visual treatments rendered in relative degrees of awkwardness and artfulness, could catch on with hip auds worldwide.
The provocative pic, often disturbingly absorbing from moment to moment, registers as considerably less than the sum of its parts.
With a few notable exceptions, pic relies on O. Henry-esque twists, simplistic surprise endings and "aha!" epiphanies to gets its points across.
Proves too slight to encompass the innovative artistry of its celebrated subjects...could still wow cognoscenti and philistines alike.
A drearily pretentious, ultra-stagy exercise in middle-age self-loathing.

The New York law professor's obsessive relationship to death-row inmate Daryl Holton, self-confessed slayer of his own four children, assumes enough bizarre twists to lay bare the myriad contradictions and prejudices.
[A] brilliant, audacious indie.
Fortunately, musicvideo vet Rhein's competent helming skills counterbalance her off-putting dialogue and flat acting style so that the pic...doesn't come off strictly amateur.
Ambitious three-hour-plus documentary.
movie_title: Being Jewish in France (Comme un Juif en France) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Docu splendidly focuses on the artist but gives shorter shrift to the art itself.
movie_title: Milton Glaser: To Inform and Delight (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Neither filtered through nor structured around another artist's work, and suffers from the lack of a unifying vision, its parts greater than the whole.
Sentimental and a bit too cute in evoking a child's-eye view.
Sweetgrass showcases an elemental intimacy between man and animal.
Simultaneously insightful and idiotic, the minimalist pic features a succession of experts providing their two cents on Why We Write, the pitfalls of friendship and the need for outside validation.

Distinguishes itself from such last-fling-before-the-wedding comedies as The Hangover with the grittiness of its Texas locales and the smug intelligence of its unapologetically narcissistic protagonist.
movie_title: I Hope They Serve Beer in Hell (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A radiant perf by Annie Parisse and a virtuoso turn by Eli Wallach are insufficient to lift this male intergenerational angst-fest out of the ghetto.
The potentially thought-provoking concept of historical reconciliation is ill served by a half-baked script that reduces every cliched plot point to jaw-dropping levels of preachiness.
[A] gloriously flamboyant comedic extravaganza.
Ponyo possesses an almost demonic childish energy and a delight in form stronger than reason or narrative.
Unfortunately, aside from the glimpses of the couple's nightmarish crossing, Brand never commands an aesthetic that galvanizes the pic's rather conventional moral oppositions.
Competent but unimaginative.

Unsentimental, almost antiheroic snapshot of a disaffected lost generation never billboards its end-of-a-civilization vibe, though that vibe does color its bittersweet nostalgia over youth wasted on the young.
Yoo-Hoo, Mrs. Goldberg does an exemplary job of celebrating the seminal achievements of Gertrude Berg and reaffirming her status as a broadcasting pioneer.
An amiable stroll through biblical times featuring Jack Black and Michael Cera as exiled Neanderthals, Year One lacks seismic guffaws but elicits many mild smiles.
The pic climaxes in absurdism worthy of Herzog's doomed mad geniuses.
Its extremely narrow focus on the death throes of an art form, rather than the art itself, limits its appeal.

Helmer-scripter Casper Andreas, whose previous credits (Slutty Summer, A Four Letter Word) adhered firmly and flamboyantly to the comedic, seems to have hit his stride with the operatic excesses of melodrama.
We get a distractingly vapid couple who tend to drain the emotional resonance of these extraordinary, ever-shifting tableaux.
movie_title: Trilogia: To livadi pou dakryzei (The Weeping Meadow) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Les Claypool's laid-back mockumentary about a fictional jam band generates enough mild humor to keep the spoof rolling...
movie_title: National Lampoon Presents Electric Apricot: Quest for Festeroo (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Intriguing take on the Frankenstein myth.

Fascinating glimpse into wholly different body of laws, engrossingly evolving script and standout perfs, including Taraneh Alidoosti's ... make City more accessible to arthouse auds than more stylistically challenging Farsi fare.

Lack of perspective and shaky comic tone plague Tollbooth -- Debra Kirschner's DV-shot saga of a Brooklyn Jewish girl trying to make it in Manhattan as an artist -- sinking it in a morass of whiny cliches.
Our Brand Is Crisis proves as entertaining as the earlier The War Room, which also featured Carville, but is more somber.
The tribe's unfailing politeness outside of activities specifically designed to arouse testosterone underlines the suspiciously benign nature of the entire endeavor.

With a real-life athlete as talented and charismatic as Coney Island hoop prodigy Sebastian Telfair, almost any outcome would probably have made for good drama, but Hock lucked out when life provided a happy ending.
Mermin achieves an easy intimacy with students and instructors alike.
Scores simultaneously as romantic, tragic, grotesque and screamingly funny.
... a heartfelt tribute to a couple of robots.
As fascinating as it is frustrating, docu raises a raft of nicely unresolved questions about parenting and parentage.
The Sandler-patented mix of the deliberately offensive and the blatantly sentimental loses something in the maestro's absence.
Taking full advantage of the formidable archive materials preserved by the Truth Commission, docudocu sets out to trace two decades of Peru's history that claimed 70,000 lives.
The intertwining of separate story strands is solidly structured, and the different mini-narratives resolved in unsurprising yet satisfying ways.
Strong thesping and solid staging, atmospherically accompanied by disorienting, darkly folksy Ramsay Midwood songs make Wake surprisingly watchable.
[The Tenants] keeps grimly glued to its one-note premise, relieved by nary a glimmer of humor, surprise or personality.
Both richly complex and immediately accessible.
movie_title: Who Gets to Call It Art? (2006)

movie_review_blurb: [A] stilted, somewhat pretentious Southern Gothic tale.
Material is uneven, but rhythm and pacing keep action moving smartly.
Rain strives for a Magnolia-type tapestry of quiet desperation. But after 90 unremitting minutes of badly acted, atrociously written histrionic misery, pic leaves one praying for frogs.

Though Franti covers little ground in Israel that has not already been well mined by countless documentarians, the context of Iraq and how American forces will be perceived for the indefinite future, puts an entirely new perspective on the situation.
movie_title: Human Cost of War: Michael Franti: I Know I'm Not Alone (2005)

movie_review_blurb: As time goes by, the supposedly everyday middleclass lifestyles effortlessly enjoyed by his regular Joes begin to seem suspiciously like the province of the idle rich.
Enjoyable, daffily improbable escapist romp further expands Bollywood's pop genre repertoire.
A strong cast, formal visual style and cynical voiceover that propels the action help elevate this Seattle-set gay romp from the ranks of the stereotypical.
Pic's power lies not in postmodernism but in its take on how rural youths relate to the contemporary scene.
The execution fails to entirely flesh out the conceit.
A 72-minute non-stop gagfest.
A sure-fire audience-pleaser.
Proves an uneasy fit for mature leads Gershon and Matthew Modine, who struggle valiantly to appear clueless enough to make their characters' goofy behavior credible.
An unflashy, straightforward account of Jim Jones and his great social experiment -- which notoriously culminated in the largest mass murder/suicide in modern memory.
A riveting thriller that contrasts the sleazy elegance of Hayek and Jared Leto's lethal duo with the lumbering, beefy persistence of cops John Travolta and James Gandolfini.

Briskly paced humor and/or pathos flow organically from situation and characters, with age providing less an occasion for one-liners than a now-or-never excuse to wallow in unfettered personality expression.
The viewer is never completely swept up into the spiraling fascination of the forbidden, most likely held back by the pic's lurking conventionality.
Thoughtful, incisive, controversial docu.
movie_title: The Cult of the Suicide Bomber (2006)

movie_review_blurb: ... Yule's docu sheds light neither on the convoluted codependency of marriage nor upon the commodification of art.
movie_title: The Photographer, His Wife, Her Lover (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Beauchamp expertly excerpts long stretches from the extensive television coverage of the 1955 events, juxtaposing them with present-day interviews with the people who lived though these traumatic happenings.
movie_title: Untold Story of Emmett Louis Till (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Comes off as lame and unfocused as its draggy dramatis personae.
Executes its clever premise with journeyman competence instead of true wit.
Pic's dubious brand of heroism, half-baked historical sense, simplistic dialogue, flat staging and barely formed characters make for sluggish sledding.
A lively, cogent docu.
This pretentiously titled, zero-budget N.Y. indie airily pulls off what Hollywood mightily strives for -- a believable romantic comedy.

Though Kitamura wades into blood-and-guts spectacle with panache and infinite death-dispensing ingenuity, the wraparound moral tale feels weak, igniting dramatically only when oddball villains appear.
Even the impudently mesmerizing star presence (and songs) of gamine Cynthia Hopkins cannot elevate this surprisingly staid slice of surrealism beyond the realm of the curious.
Rare film-clips of what passed for Nazi normality do not materialize every day, and pic is decidedly worth a look-see.
A marvel of passionate succinctness, Robert Kane Pappas' docu critically examines the Fourth Estate, once the bastion of American democracy.
Will appeal primarily to those who like their armchair adventures picture-postcard pristine and sprinkled with touches of proud self-sufficiency.
Its unvarnished look at life in the slow lane exerts a hypnotic fascination.
The events themselves, captured in vital newsreel footage of the period, speak volumes, as perhaps does their unfinished legacy.
movie_title: With All Deliberate Speed: The Legacy of Brown vs. Board (2004)

movie_review_blurb: What makes Highberger's docu so rewarding is the wealth of material available.
Fascinating subject and rousing wall-to-wall Klezmer music strongly sell an otherwise rather questionably structured film.
Maps an evocative history of the underground dance music culture of the '70s and '80s.
Pic lacks density and spontaneity necessary to lift it out of its carefully posed and plotted set-ups and onto a bigscreen.
An oddly juiceless older woman-younger man romance.
Finally breaks down under the weight of its twists and turns, but mostly maintains a creepy fascination with its scuzzy characters.
Confusing lack of historical set-up considerably dims the potential luster of a great true story.
movie_title: Perlasca: The Courage of a Just Man (Perlasca. Un eroe italiano) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Auds might do better having this one delivered.
[Its] gutsy, madly ambiguous unleashing of a mixed bag of religious reactions attests to a genuine sense of regionalism.
Ultimately, biodoc is less about Eggleston living in the 'real world' than about Almereyda filming there.
movie_title: William Eggleston in the Real World (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Despite pic's earnestness and obvious good intentions, narrative elements, carefully set forth though they may be, fall back on overfamiliar, underdeveloped tropes.
Affably ambling pic is particularly strong in examining the economics of rap.
Exquisite, self-contained curio.
Slicker, funnier and more professional than its predecessor.
Whether or not one buys his alternate theory of cosmic recycling, Dobson's colorful language and passionate beliefs transcend particulars.
Astute use of 3-D effects, accomplished insect wrangling and studious avoidance of gross-out elements make this acceptable for target family auds.

First-time helmer Chris Browne's sense of humor captures perfectly the contradictions, absurdities and drama at the intersection of class, media, money and sports without dissing any of his player/subjects.

In its reliance on emotionally loaded voiceover and its disconcertingly direct appeals for support, Len Morris' old-fashioned docu seems more designed for fund-raising pitches than theatrical release.
An undeniably inventive, visually stunning sci-fier.
Exposes the systematic despoiling of Argentina -- not by a dictator or military junta but by an elected democracy.
Fascinating in its reticence, pic's honest, well-intentioned exploration involving two families fearlessly emerges with a far different picture than was originally envisioned.
Young's small-scale, effortlessly cosmopolitan grasp of marginal lifestyles and alternative sexuality is comforting by dint of its occasional clumsiness.
[This] atmospheric pic positively vibrates with authenticity.
Standout thesping by stars Dorian Missick and Zoe Saldana, along with fully fleshed-out secondary roles, distinguish Pete Chatmon's gentle comedy.
Like the filmmakers' award-winning Boys of Baraka, Jesus Camp examines the relationship between education and social context.
Aside from Sage, the most compelling presence in the film is the neighborhood real estate.

Ullman isn't particularly interested in the angst of human interaction or the difficulty of knowing truth; she seems fascinated by the pathos of feelings that are all the more intense for being of questionable integrity.
[A] celebratory, family-friendly fable.
An unremarkable talking-head docu nudged nearer to must-see status by the remarkable timeliness of its antiwar subject matter.
For better or worse, this relaxed docu successfully captures the experience of summer camp,
Disarmingly casual.
Any opportunity to witness the improvisatory skills of Sarah Silverman, Bonnie Hunt and Amy Sedaris should not be missed.
movie_title: I Want Someone to Eat Cheese With (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Sharp dialogue, idiosyncratic characters and a wickedly brilliant structure that subtly derails expectation make Laura Smiles a rarity among mellers.
Uneven thesping...assorted inanities...and a narrow focus turn the potentially fascinating tale into a bland, perverse round-robin of teen angst.
[A] flat, post-feminist cocktail of remixed cliches.
[An] extraordinary 74-minute tone poem.
Haar's handheld camera rawly captures the breathless scrambles and nocturnal disorientation of the fleeing Palestinians.

Hollywood may find it difficult to cast two big-name stars willing to play it as broadly as the real-life hero and villain of this tale. Nor would many self-respecting scriptwriters dare to match the sheer improbability of these actual happenings.
movie_title: The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Rollicking story of a rich kid whose wildly successful bid for popularity has him playing drug-distributing shrink to an entire high school boasts pitch-perfect faceoffs between Anton Yelchin and Robert Downey Jr. could fuel a chemistry lab.

With an eclectic mix of strong-minded thesps all pulling in slightly different directions, this shape-shifting genre hybrid successfully commingles 12-step therapy, romantic comedy and hit-man thriller.

Strained dialogue, awkward mise-en-scene and weirdly uncomfortable thesping from superlative players contribute to a drearily self-reflective conceit.
movie_title: The Inner Life of Martin Frost (2007)

movie_review_blurb: German helmer Angelina Maccarone's latest film, Vivere, piles heavy emotional baggage on a slender story frame.

Filmed over a two-year period during production of David Lynch's Inland Empire, Lynch, like the feature it loosely chronicles, has no immediately discernable throughline and a wide variety of video-image densities.
Knockout performances by John Cusack and child actor Bobby Coleman help legitimize a whimsical but sententiously moralizing script.

Penetrating Burmese jungles with legendary young activist Ka Hsaw Wa as he gathers evidence of widespread forced relocations, murder, rape and slave labor, Total Denial shuttles between outrage and justice.

Offers a rare glimpse into the hearts and minds of those who have dedicated themselves to ridding Iraq of its invaders, captured by intrepid reporters who risked their lives at a time when fragile trust was still possible.
A feast for Petty fans and a joyous confirmation of the vitality of the collective creative process.
movie_title: Runnin' Down a Dream: Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Despite its visually compelling style and two magnificently dysfunctional perfs, pic finally fails to ring enough variations on its father-fixation theme.
A hilarious movie about a surprisingly funny man.
movie_title: Mr. Warmth: The Don Rickles Project (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Jeremy Kagan's green-screen filmization, in its over-busy editing, ever-changing angles and constantly shifting backdrops, strips the play of its starkness, leaving disproportionate schmaltz and propaganda.
Pic's fantastic third act more than makes up for such occasional slogging.
As shot by the incomparable Ellen Kuras, the concert retains a rich organic feel, complementing the music without over-determining it.
Slight but nuanced, charming debut bodes well for Gallic helmer Frederic Fisbach.
Pitch-perfect Francophone pic deserves wider distribution than its subtitles may allow.
The story that emerges, illustrated with footage from the time, delivers a surprising lesson in the importance of small details and the ultimate power of negotiation.
Despite the improbable ease of pic's genteel psychoanalysis, the characters are thesped with enough depth and emotional investment to make their problems feel legit.

This offbeat charmer succumbs to the same airless artificiality that has claimed many recent efforts in the genre.

[The] film is undeniably topical but the lack of emotional investment in its characters renders it more intelligent than engaging.

The story of Walsch's travails never strains credulity, though helmer Simon's predilection for spiritual vistas with light breaking through clouds, arrested close-ups and endless long dissolves often skirts kitsch.
[Exit] makes a strong implicit case for a cause supported by a growing number of Americans.
movie_title: Exit: The Right to Die (Exit: Le Droit de Mourir) (2006)

Somehow, El Cortez is stronger than its component parts.

Death blurs the frontier between reality and dream, though never dimming the pic's startling beauty, raucous humor or indomitable ethos.
Visually comanding but tonally uneven.

Perhaps most unforgivably, pic lacks suspense. The action scenes are directed credibly enough, but the nail-biting buildups and awful aftermaths are laid out mechanically and drained of emotional effect.
What begins as a straightforward docu on an elderly homeless artist in New York City winds up as an indictment of U.S. internment of Japanese-Americans during WWII.
Lively and amusing.

[Pic] does a superb job of condensing an overwhelming mass of documentation, archival imagery and artistic representation into a concise yet passionate history lesson whose relevance could not be timelier.

A fascinating reflection on Germany's ongoing attempts to come to terms with its past.

Mesmerizing morality play, rich in rare archival footage and complete with heroic Allied saviors.
Extravagantly [expends] elaborate sets, special-effects, music, costumes and actor look-alikes for the sake of a few lame gags and a legion of crotch-kicks.
Leadenly scripted and blandly overliteral and therefore never capitalizes on the provocativeness of its premise.

Aside from Zahn, thesping is uneven.

Sparks' oddball, self-deprecatory charm and Ireland's uncertainties play off each other nicely as their eclectic tastes mesh; both characters are thrilled at finding someone who accepts and even welcomes the other's peculiarities.

movie_review_blurb: Nothing really coheres in this unimaginative mishmash.
This lyrical meditation on crows in the Japanese capital offers a rewarding wide for viewers who can go with the flow.
Cute to the point of blandness, tyro French helmer Clement Michel's vaguely amiable laffer scrupulously avoids all ambiguity, innovation or flashes of wit.

This change-affirming docu's minimalist lack of polish or stylistic affect almost becomes a plus, its stark, bare-bones presentation somehow befitting the tales of abuse and incarceration so baldly proclaimed within.

Robert Greenwald's docu paints a sobering picture of a national security state.

movie_review_blurb: Well structured and dynamically edited, Deceptive Practice: The Mysteries and Mentors of Ricky Jay relies on the famed magician himself to wax autobiographical with his usual charm, humor and panache.

movie_review_blurb: A low-key, fairly evenhanded look at industrial vs. organic methods of raising livestock.
Jeremy Frindel's workmanlike docu proceeds in a matter-of-fact manner that neither ignores nor belabors the inspirational aspect of its story.
movie_title: One Track Heart: The Story of Krishna Das (2013)

movie_review_blurb: While Bert Stern: Original Madman mines its subject's work for a steady stream of striking visuals, his self-narration proves to be of little interest, offering little variation on a single theme: his love/lust for women.

movie_review_blurb: Jason Osder's riveting documentary chronicles the escalating confrontations between the Philadelphia police and the radical group Move.
Suliman ("Paradise Now," "The Attack") dominates the screen as Khaled, utterly compelling in and out of jail, his magnificent perf tying up cinematic loose ends.
Alexandre Rockwell plunges directly into the wildly unpredictable logic of childhood with this black-and-white gem.
The film is hamstrung by its fidelity to real-life inspirational models.

Throwing in sweeping vistas of virgin snow and orphaned moose as proof of nature's greatness, and recruiting a motley bunch of believers along the way, the film won't convert anyone but the already holistically minded.
