Michel Gondry doodles while Noam Chomsky philosophizes in an inspired meeting of idiosyncratic minds.
movie_title: Is the Man Who Is Tall Happy?: An Animated Conversation with Noam Chomsky (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Incandescent performances and an unerring grasp of milieu distinguish this latest feature from Sherrybaby helmer Laurie Collyer.
Maxine Trump's feature loses focus as it progresses, though its insights into guitar making, forestry harvesting and environmental shortages resonate strongly.
The more the action hews to a Hammer horror template, the less congruent it feels with historical revelation.

If Dalsgaard's advocacy of Gehl's utopian vision largely ignores the socioeconomic forces arrayed against it, the film should nevertheless enthuse pedestrians, bike riders and public-space proponents everywhere.
Dan Eberle pushes film noir to its subjective extreme with this well-acted, unpretentious story of a fatalistic ex-cop.
Deeply shocking and continually surprising.
The improvisational zeal with which Cusack approaches his role is particularly fun to watch.
Cindy Kleine pays tribute to her famed theater-director hubby in Andre Gregory: Before and After Dinner, with thoroughly delightful results.
movie_title: Andr√© Gregory: Before and After Dinner (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The dramatic goings-on... lack dynamism. The seascapes, however, continually astound.
movie_title: The Other Side of the Ice (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Connolly and Carpenter both strongly impress in their complementary roles, all the more believable for being seen largely through Graham's eyes.
This engaging character study functions best as a two-hander: The male leads build a wholly believable, offbeat co-dependency, while their interactions with others tend toward the more generic.
The explosively provocative film progressively and aggressively blurs distinctions between documentary and fiction.
The film, produced by Cherney, makes a clear and cogent case (later upheld by a court verdict) that police and FBI falsified evidence in order to discredit Bari's cause.
R.H. Greene's docu succeeds admirably thanks to the charismatic oncamera presence of a 74-year-old Nurmi in an extended 1997 interview.
Somewhere in her switch from documaking to fiction filmmaking, Shundell Prasad seems to have lost touch with clarity.
A couple attends a Pre-Cana retreat to test the Certainty of their commitment in Peter Askin's none-too-subtle Catholic cautionary tale.
This fascinating docu should easily attract crossover auds, and merits arthouse exposure.
Unevenly structured, the segments differ greatly in length and relevance.

One could, however, wish that this endless encomium played less like a PowerPoint sales pitch, illustrated with clip-art imagery, scored with generic music and narrated in mellifluous tones by Annette Bening.
Whatever clarity can be gained by the film's analysis of endemic Islamic hatred of Jews is fatally compromised by equally irrational, overreaching claims.

Nowadays, when the very notion of impartiality seems quixotic at best, few issue-driven docus even pay lip service to the other side. Fox and Nubile's observational fly-on-the-wall approach proves relatively objective.
Though it retains the narrative complexity of the Swedish bestseller on which it's based, WWII saga Simon and the Oaks never creates an emotional or intellectual throughline of its own.
The docu ties itself too tightly to its subject, mimicking forms and rhythms it never fully makes its own.
The kinetically shot concert footage captures the volatile dynamic between performers and audience, as Mick Jagger's provocative posturing is followed by fans storming the stage.
movie_title: The Rolling Stones: Charlie Is My Darling - Ireland 1965 (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Rather than invoking sympathy or shared outrage, the filmmaker creates a kind of complicity with her audience, particularly as she explores the depressingly similar, sterile apartments of the high-rises steadily surrounding her.
A by-the-numbers romantic comedy.
A curiously warm-and-fuzzy hindsight interpretation of artistic aggression, delivered by the artists themselves.

The film's effectiveness largely stems from the flat-out lameness of the opposition arguments, the lack of scientific credentials of those making them, and the self-interest of their corporate bosses.
Karpovsky's pic seldom surprises, its strengths lying in a leisurely journey toward a clearly predestined denouement.
Vittoria avoids discussing the crime for which Abu-Jamal spent 29 years in solitary confinement on death row, instead tracing the path of a brilliant journalist whose message cannot be silenced.
Frans Weisz's fascinating docu juxtaposes wildly disparate texts and textures, including Salomon's haunting artwork and excerpts from Weisz's own 1980 biopic, "Charlotte."
With dispassionate precision, Scheffner's quietly shocking docu, evoking German ghosts of Gypsy genocide, confronts global questions of illegal immigration.
Thrusts a forgotten pioneer back into the limelight while illuminating a part of rock history.
Even those impervious to Wagner's music will find it difficult to resist Fry's charm.
Overly one-note in its singular p.o.v., the pic nevertheless offers a welcome variation on the conquering frat boy or Ferris Bueller-type adolescent.
The docu's relatively uninflected tone rarely participates in either the excitement or irony it chronicles.

High Tech, Low Life ostensibly examines censorship of the Internet and news media in China. But the pic is driven less by its subject matter than by its two very different and utterly fascinating bloggers.
[The film will be] of interest to faithful followers and easily accessible to newcomers.
Striking a fine balance between personal journal and political expose, Kelly Anderson's docu examines the unnatural causes of changes wrought in Brooklyn neighborhoods due to gentrification.

Not Fade Away injects the past with the nervous energy and exciting uncertainty of the present, devoid of nostalgia or biopic baggage, and infused with all the wicked wit that characterized Chase's The Sopranos.

Clear and concise, with insightful, impassioned interviewees and well-chosen epithets from statesmen past and present, it cogently analyzes looming catastrophes, with wistful stabs at possible solutions.
Birders vividly captures the distinctive colors and markings of a vast number of bird species and the equally individualized personalities of those watching them within the confines of Central Park.
It may prove too bland even for its target audience.

Laid-back yet incisive, "The New Black" examines the complexity of black attitudes toward same-sex marriage, which the mainstream media tend to oversimplify as church-dominated and uniformly negative.
Maurice Linnane chronicles an important, atypically tranquil moment in Amy Winehouse's tumultuous career.
movie_title: Amy Winehouse: The Day She Came to Dingle (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Throughout the film, the beauty of the landscapes and the totally natural insertion of human, animal and insect movement within the frame lend "The Creation of Meaning" a particular grace.
movie_title: La creazione di significato (The Creation of Meaning) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: An amorphous, superficial but sporadically very funny recap of 40 years of 'SNL' and American history in a surprisingly conventional form.

The pleasures of well-observed characters and small epiphanies are undeniable, and Alex of Venice, actor Chris Messina's directing debut, is amply supplied with both, thanks to Mary Elizabeth Winstead's extraordinary performance.
This giant-screen rhapsody on the power of airplanes to revolutionize the world winds up offering little more than an endorsement of the tourism and shopping industries.
movie_title: Living in the Age of Airplanes (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A magnificent tapestry of sounds and images, this documentary interweaves multiple leitmotifs that flow through the film like familiar old friends, surging to the forefront only to be reabsorbed and casually encountered farther on.
Ronah's loss of control brings neither catharsis nor liberation, either to the character or to the film.
Filmmaker Eugene Kotlyareno and his real-life ex Kate Lyn Sheil play out a dysfunctional L.A. reunion in this raucous, freewheeling comedy.
Jody Lee Lipes' delightful ballet documentary delves into the intricacies of the creative process.
The film offers surprisingly cogent, lived-in evocations of a period too often glossed over in impersonal, by-the-book montages.
Superlatively acted culture-clash indie chillingly evokes primal dread and sexual transgression as a gay Californian teen meets his Nebraskan farm relatives.

Vikram delivers a knockout three-pronged performance, but this cinematic bravura is offset by underdeveloped scripting, flatly one-dimensional villains and overdone lone-hero-vs.-swarms-of-murderous-attackers setpieces.
Definitely not for the narrative-minded, "Joy of Man's Desiring" will please if not swell the ranks of Cote admirers.
An affecting look at those battling the Taliban's murderous anti-vaccination campaign in Pakistan.
All this uncertainty and the constant casting changes gift the production with an antic spontaneity and madcap giddiness that belie the age of the performers and intensify the atmosphere of the play.
The film veers toward oversimplified selectivity, too intent on its feel-good, back-patting agenda.
Perhaps the most amazing aspect of Dowd's confession -- and Russell's documentary -- is the total ease with which Dowd reconciles his twin careers as all-out gangster and dedicated cop.

This thoroughly engrossing, highly anticipated pic boasts assured direction by sophomore helmer Reema Kagti, a well-constructed script by Kagti and... Zoya Akhtar, and strong thesping by familiar Bollywood luminaries.
Schmaltz continually threatens to overcome genius in this super-sentimental account of gifted puppeteer Caroll Spinney.
movie_title: I Am Big Bird: The Caroll Spinney Story (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Chris Collins' serene lensing highlights the family's closeness and its connection to the environment, while Jay Wadley's African harp score adds to the pic's authenticity.
movie_title: Grand comme le Baobab (Tall as the Baobab Tree) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Intensely stylized, highly original and utterly mesmerizing.
The filmmakers skillfully orchestrate the various levels of their exploration, from the intimate details of Talha and Zarina's lives to the workings of the big national picture.

Working in small, skillfully nuanced, always surprising increments, Kari, enabled by Gunnar Jonsson's extraordinary performance, charts a moving, totally believable flowering of untapped potential as Fusi falls in love.

Applesauce, Onur Tukel's latest and most accomplished microbudget exercise in cynical absurdism, throws dismembered body parts into a couple of amicable marriages and charts the resultant explosions as paranoia runs rampant.
A triumph of minor-key storytelling.

Sampling snippets and snatches of lives and conversations, Maysles and his fellow filmmakers undertake a folk odyssey through northern landscapes that proves a fitting farewell to an American ethnographer.
A fascinating study in cross-cultural pollination, Song positively sings.
Gabriel's dilemma, though suitably heartbreaking, and goosed along by Patrick Higgins' tension-stringed score, ultimately becomes as wearisome to viewers as it is to his exhausted clan.
Cramming a lot of anecdotes, urban lore and frenzied movement into a mere 71 minutes, Nicholson's docu imperceptibly builds to an unexpected, revelatory climax.
Triet brilliantly orchestrates the intersection of documentary and fiction.
movie_title: Age of Panic (La Bataille de Solf√©rino) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A career-stalled rock musician, leaving Paris for his small hometown of Tonnerre, falls in love and falls apart in Guillaume Brac's engrossingly nuanced character study.
[The acting] is technically accomplished, but never quite transcends their scripted traits, rendering the film's tonal shifts more matter of fact than emotionally wrenching.
As exasperating as it is weirdly compelling.

Beginning as a colorful documentary about the Puerto Rican transgender community... Mala Mala slowly morphs into a celebration of solidarity and collective activism without ever losing sight of its likable protagonists.
While there are several possible good reasons to remake the Depression-set musical "Annie" in 2014, none of them seem to have informed Will Gluck's overblown yet undernourished treatment.
The most shocking aspect of Berg's documentary is what it presents as the abusers' utter lack of accountability.

A joyous celebration of creativity and razor-sharp wit sustained into old age, as evinced by outspoken nonagenarian fashion icon Iris Apfel, "Iris"also offers proof of Albert Maysles' continued vitality as a documentarian.
Israeli helmer Eytan Fox's candy-colored musical is an endearingly goofy celebration of the right to be yourself.
Terrifically conceived and executed.
movie_title: Stand Clear Of The Closing Doors (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A surprising, well-crafted look at a ballroom-dancing program aimed at bridging gaps between Jewish and Palestinian children in Israel.
Jeunet has succeeded at drawing us inside his head; the question is, do we want to be there?
A poetic, mesmerizing fusion of fairy tale and cultural commentary from director Jessica Oreck.
movie_title: The Vanquishing Of The Witch Baba Yaga (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Unfortunately, pic's concept doesn't stretch to 74 minutes.
The film's emotional center rings coldly hollow, its star-crossed lovers coming off more like projected figures than flesh-and-blood players.
Alves ultimately unites his large cast in festive unity, with comic reversals redeeming the seemingly irredeemable in farcical fashion, and with large doses of ethnic warming.
As fascinating as it is off-putting.
Meyer and lenser Tom Richmond capture an intersection of high-school and natural spheres that highlights New England's serenity and beauty without undue pictorial fussiness.
Though the gruesome plot fills the bill, genre-wise, "Flesh" often seems like an empty stylistic exercise instead of a horror film.
Antonio de la Torre is brilliant as a killer and eater of young women in Manuel Martin Cuenca's sumptuously lensed psychological drama.
Thanks to Saville's tightly controlled direction and a superlative cast, the mere exchange of glances builds as much suspense as the kinetic action sequence that opens the pic.
A documentary about science for professionals and laypeople alike, Particle Fever celebrates an event of earth-shattering importance, though what far-ranging transformations it heralds remain unknown
With its wry humor and fantastic mix of music and images, this seemingly odd choice for Tribeca's opening-nighter could carve out a solid theatrical niche.
Schwarz lacks the writing chops to adequately embed the character's predictable learning curve into a richer narrative fabric, but Dunne's perf is pitch-perfect.
Another exquisite, snail-paced cinematic perambulation from Tsai Ming-liang and Lee Kang-sheng.
Alain Gsponer's well-crafted romantic comedy... glides along on the sheer power of rising German star Daniel Bruhl's boyish charm.
The helmer's fans will not be disappointed.
Deftly sidestepping both melodrama and family-values messaging, Poppe imbues the film with enormous emotional resonance, brilliantly grounded by his leading lady.
Adapting the cold language of data encryption to recount a dramatic saga of abuse of power and justified paranoia, Poitras brilliantly demonstrates that information is a weapon that cuts both ways.
A well-scripted, intriguingly-acted effort to mine the theme of prolonged adolescent best-buddyism through two women.
This curiously intimate documentary about artist Altina Schinasi, as told through her myriad marriages, engrosses in its own fittingly slapdash way.
A loving tribute for those well versed in the Fuller canon, the doc may prove less revelatory than entertaining for neophytes.
After a seductively moody intro, Michael Walker's domestic thriller devolves into a cartoonish attack on the filthy rich.
This chilling war-is-hell expose [is] must-see viewing.

Stooped at almost 90 but feisty and humor-filled as ever, Hentoff presides over a film rich in the sounds and occasional sights of legendary cultural figures, from Lenny Bruce and Malcolm X to Bob Dylan and Coleman Hawkins.
movie_title: The Pleasures Of Being Out Of Step (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A curiously likable, entertainingly laid-back Asian-American take on all-too-familiar dysfunctional family tropes, this Kickstarter-enabled effort boldly mines farce along with sentiment.
Rather than adapting the pieces to conform to his paper-thin narrative, Brown explores the tensions and contortions of dancers expressing fresh emotion through a pre-existing art form.
There may be multiple look-alikes, but they don't exactly double the fun in this tedious, witless outing from director Sajid Khan.
Dual focus on the need to end the ineffective, destructive "war on drugs" and broader questions of political compromise gives director Riley Morton's film particular resonance.
movie_title: Evergreen: The Road to Legalization in Washington (2014)

movie_review_blurb: [A] clear-eyed snapshot of sports hope struggling against socioeconomic stagnation.
[An] engrossing documentary.
Hopping nimbly among three distinct timeframes, helmer Basu deconstructs the film's sentimental thrust to stress his hero's in-the-moment ingenuity.

Hachmeister jumps from chef to chef, country to country, sampling little soundbites or chronicling the meticulous building of a blini on an asparagus stalk, with no clear structure to give the docu momentum.
movie_title: Drei Sterne - Die K√∂che und die Sterne (Three Stars) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: This engaging if somewhat underwhelming tale of unlikely redemption builds a funny-sad web of intersecting interactions around its strong central perfs.
Result boasts some excellent action sequences, most performed by megastar Salman Khan, and indeed is generally more effective in fight scenes than in hearts-and-flowers mode.
Ambitious if airlessly microcosmic.
The edge achieved by director-editor-producer-scribe Garth Donovan is jeopardized by overreaching for topical relevance.
A curiously effective musical docu that captures the raw dynamics of collective creativity.
Though initially fascinating, this two-hour travelogue soon becomes repetitive as it forsakes stark desert isolation for icon-festooned churches and overcrowded ceremonies.
Within the confines of its stagy artificiality, the thesping mostly rings true.
After countless mumblecore and slacker indies, the sense of newness is gone.
Real-life siblings Tucker and Savanna Sears deliver concentrated, totally unself-conscious perfs.
Bagnall successfully exploits the seriocomic disparity between the supercharged relationship offscreen and the desultory one onscreen.
Though stylistically incoherent at times, pic benefits from the percussionist's plainspokenness.
Often feels as inchoate as the phenomenon under discussion.
Blithely ignoring socioeconomic factors, Cross places responsibility for good nutrition squarely on human willpower.
Mia and the Migoo boasts a handsome, folkloric look that is often undermined by a ham-handed script.
movie_title: Mia et le Migou (Mia and the Migoo) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Chalk suffers overall from a lack of subtlety, as problems abruptly get thrust into the foreground with little buildup or internal consistency.
This spectacular orchestration of visual elements seems wasted on a threadbare, inanely repetitive plotline.
The Fosters vary their presentation according to the geographic and ethnographic lay of the land.
Dave Boyle's pic is fueled by no overriding visual style, relying completely on its actors' chemistry for momentum. Unfortunately, the two strike no sparks.

The uncompromising power of Ingrid Jonker's poetry runs like a pulsing vein through Black Butterflies, a 1960s-set drama whose several strong points include the angry intensity of Carice van Houten's fearless perf.

Daly deftly creates a disturbing, Chabrol-like tension that plays on immediate identification with the handsome medico's lonely, shy vulnerability and slow-building horror at the depths to which his self-delusion can sink.
Bowl offers few transcendental revelations; there's nothing at stake here other than frozen poultry.
Stylishly reinvents juvenile pulp with flashy pyrotechnics.
Brody is brilliant, but can't save the Book of Job proceedings from tilting over into the ludicrous.
Woefully amateurish.
Working from a fact-based script, tyro helmers Adam and Mark Kassen fashion an impassioned expose on the health-care industry full of strange-but-true incongruities in Puncture.
An unremarkable docu.
movie_title: Hey, Boo: Harper Lee and 'To Kill a Mockingbird' (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The film, like the album, winds up far more Sir Elton's project, conceived as a musical tribute to John's idol and mentor Russell -- an acknowledgment of a worthy musician only recently rediscovered, in large part thanks to John.
Pic's many satisfyingly kinetic action sequences and strong thesping (particularly by femme lead Zhou Xun) outweigh its uneven scripting and occasional ill-advised forays into CGI.
Shepard delivers in spades, his character weary but just crackpot enough to survive.
A dynamite Kathleen Turner desperately strives to be named "Catholic Woman of the Year" in tyro helmer Anne Renton's feel-good religious laffer The Perfect Family.
Without true tension, the docu feels as slickly manufactured as its va-va-voom subject.

Character actor John Hawkes, his rural demeanor tailor-made for hick pics, breaks through typecasting stereotypes in his nuanced portrayal of crop artist Stan Herd in Chris Ordal's ambitious Earthwork.
As long as the pic remains rooted in a specific locale's rhythms, it imparts a sense of discovery; but when local color wears thin, bald ideological small-town/big-city oppositions intrude.
It follows, over the course of a year, five sobering case histories of unrelenting schoolyard persecution.
Vagueness is the hallmark of Marc Meyers' sophomore outing.
Despite the fine thesping seen in this innocuous piece of fluff, the whole amounts to less than the sum of its parts.
An oddball hybrid of porn film and message movie.
Loveless exerts a low-energy, dread-tinged fascination that intrigues rather than wows.
A sparkling coming-of-ager about a 17-year-old virgin who imperfectly juggles academic challenges and off-campus liaisons, somehow emerging able to walk on water.
[An] information-packed report, which weds elements of the diary film with newsmagazine-style profiles of people coping with different categories of sight loss.
With its contemplative pauses and subtle angle changes, the pic provides a full appreciation of Lifton's analysis and the impact that this study personally had on the man, himself a physician.

Walter Doty III and John Clafin's hackneyed script depicts Mexico as one vast, interconnected conspiracy engaged in the underground organ trade, whose highest-ranked traffickers are -- gasp! -- Americans.
The filmmakers over-edit potentially fascinating material, and even the concert footage is arbitrarily curtailed.
Swoony [and] ill-digested.
Pic pulses with the same rhythmic mastery achieved in the filmmakers' earlier Favela Rising.

Visually, Speed-Dating seldom strays far from brightly colored, head-on sketch comedy; many of its goofier conceits, such as Elliott's recurring appearance as a blue-bodied liquor-license inspector, fail to read as anything but willfully weird.

Afterlight proceeds without much discernible plot or character development, its objects and places exuding more backstory than its people, though Rip Torn as the father of the sole male protagonist lends a certain woodsy authenticity.
Better thesped and helmed than its schmaltzy premise probably warrants.
Rene Feret's lively, fascinating costumer about Mozart's talented older sister Nannerl smartly incorporates just enough fiction to bring history into sharp focus.
The film invests in spacey horror tropes one moment, plunges into absurdist adolescent angst the next and begs questions every step of the way, but just about holds together.
Though commendably attentive to Chaplin-esque pantomime on the part of lead villain Jackie Earle Haley, this cinematic anomaly falls flat as a stand-alone.
David H. Hickey's Lone Star comedy never really develops, stalling this culture-clash clambake at the merely likable stage.
This mumblecore entry sometimes sacrifices ambiguity for the sake of broader, telegraphed, one-note laughs.
Mo Rocca's faux-disingenuous tone and nonstop jocularity dominate the docu to quickly grating effect.

To its credit, and perhaps to the disappointment of some, docu never deviates from its central focus; its treatment of the Holocaust is always secondary to its portrait of an unquestionably great statesman.
Unfortunately, despite Snyder's quietly commanding presence, the docu's setup, a series of staged, would-be Socratic dialogues, feels forced and artificial -- everything Snyder's poetry is not.
A sprightly, pedestrian, Miami-set romantic comedy whose utter predictability -- trumpet fanfares couldn't announce plot twists more blatantly -- feels more cozy than disappointing.

Presumably there's an audience out there for old-fashioned, poorly written, unevenly thesped, family-friendly tales of redemption starring beefy wrestlers and a bunch of kids, but it's difficult to imagine who.
Stretches 30 minutes of material to 79 through sheer repetition, both verbal (endlessly redundant talking heads) and visual (flashy montages replete with tangential catwalk imagery).
Winters deserves better.
Informative, amusing, expertly crafted and well-laureled.
The docu's work-in-progress glimpses possess a compelling strangeness as deep emotion is painstakingly deconstructed into tiny, manipulated movements.
Remarkably, the film gradually, effectively coheres, building to a climax at once unexpected yet integral to what has transpired before.
movie_title: Gabi on the Roof in July (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Strictly for fans of free-form, DIY hit-or-miss humor (and those who prefer a miss to a hit), pic complacently parades its alienated amateurism in the mistaken belief that half a gag is better than none.
Alien Girl delivers wearisome brutality but little finesse.
Throughout, the drivers are framed against the various cityscapes they traverse, though their philosophical views on what is unfolding around them differs with age and temperament.
Cunningly fashioning found footage into a rabbit's-eye view of events, Polish helmer Bartek Konopka creates a chillingly apt political allegory in Rabbit a la Berlin.
movie_title: Rabbit a la Berlin (Kr√≥lik po berlinsku) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Vet British helmer John Irvin's mannered, bloodless and appallingly thesped filmization of Hemingway's posthumous novel, though unlikely to set the author rolling in his grave, may still have viewers rolling in the aisles.
Aatmospherics notwithstanding, the narrative unfolds unconvincingly in jerky fits and starts.
A case study in the limitations of raw.
Docu offers family-friendly holiday fare.
An exquisite study of a rapidly expanding cemetery at the center of Mexico's drug wars.
A morbidly fascinating topic that receives regrettably clumsy treatment.
A highly cinematic restaging of a jazzy 1958 Jerome Robbins "ballet in sneakers," Jody Lee Lipes and Henry Joost's NY Export: Opus Jazz thoroughly revitalizes the piece's once timely choreography.
Tedious enough to serve as a cautionary example of the pitfalls of DYI filmmaking.
A dynamite ensemble cast of young actors invests the Bard's poetry with energetic immediacy.
Audley, a helmer in his own right, somehow infuses Eddie with a compelling presence that exerts an offbeat authenticity.
Rather likable.
Spearheaded by phenomenal pint-sized lead Sydney Aguirre, this challenging third feature from the Zellner Brothers retains much of their provocative trademark idiocy but navigates darker waters.
The resolution of its conflicting truths proves so bizarre and idiotically off-the-wall that it mitigates all that precedes it.

The conversations feel artificial, overly concerned with re-creating period detail or interjecting relevant philosophical life concepts, like a constantly rehashed theory of alternate universes built on different "what if?" scenarios.
movie_title: Watching TV with the Red Chinese (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Just when Jeffrey Katzenberg had loudly declared the death of 2-D animation, along came this sly, inventively drawn cartoon that blew the cumbrous studio leviathans out of the water.
A must-see for stargazers of all ages.
movie_title: Richard Garriott: Man on a Mission (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Facinelli's transformation from feckless charmer to committed caretaker seems contrived, leaving the film feeling like a series of stitched-together scenes with little internal drive.
A lightweight, unambitious three-way romantic comedy whose utter predictability may be its greatest asset.

Pic forges a clear storyline through a sea of scientific reports, doublespeak denials and personal anecdotes (the docu snagged Tribeca's docu editing award), and a consistent picture emerges of a stonewalling military agency.
Numerous celluloid experiments have fudged reality and fiction lately, but few are as formally inventive or socially revelatory as The Arbor.
Whatever this Times-produced, TV-ready tribute lacks in tension is amply compensated by the pleasure of watching an enthusiast ply the craft he loves.
Luckily, the music trumps the indifferently shot concert footage and lends shape to the evocatively lensed recording sessions in iconic locations.
As [Burns'] characters grow older and more entrenched in borrowed luxury (Buzzy is a physical trainer who married into money), their charm wears increasingly thin.
While there is a great deal of weeping and wailing going on in the town of Angels Crest, little of it is connected to a comprehensible or cohesive plot.
Andreas, working from Jesse Archer's reductive script, knows how to pump energy into tired ideas and turn twinkly stereotypes into high-camp icons.

As the sightless heroine investigates her best friend's suicide, subtly detailed, moodily stylish pic flashes back to the girls as teens. But when the truth is revealed, nuance is drowned in horrified righteousness.
Swell never really gathers momentum, remaining a collection of moments, some more privileged than others.

One need not fully subscribe to Peter Navarro's demonization to appreciate his lucid wake-up call to the imminent dangers of the huge U.S.-China trade imbalance and its disastrous impact on the American economy.
A racy, thoroughly enjoyable docu about a pair of 69-year-old identical-twin hookers in Amsterdam, Meet the Fokkens bounces along with defiant joie de vivre.
The jazz-scored pic relies heavily on quirkiness to round out shaky characterizations and inject interest into otherwise forgettable pairings.
What gives Pelotero its edge is a nexus of corruption, exploitation and betrayal that transforms this well-shot, cannily edited item into an engrossing expose.

Bol Bachchan carries off its rapidly thinning, virtually villain-free plot thanks to its fast-paced presentation of a storyline that hinges on a succession of double identities and escalating fabrications.
Shirin offers a feast for the bedazzled eye and a crash course in narrative obsession for the benumbed mind.
[A] moving, engagingly low-key curio.
Tension flows organically from every phase of this dangerous endeavor, making for a highly entertaining outing for operaphiles and operaphobes alike.
This deconstructive pic never wields Sebald's subversive power but follows evocatively in his wake.
[A] fascinating, must-see docu.

The titular subjects display an amazing openness toward helmer Jeff Silva (obviously a good friend) and toward the camera as witness, granting viewers an unfiltered look at the U.S. economic meltdown.
Every member of the three-person family has found aesthetic fulfillment uniquely suited to the ancient retreat, as does helmer Alterman, who revels in serene vistas teeming with hybrid creations.
A master at sustaining his characters' likability even under grotesque circumstances, Estrada maintains an absurdist irony throughout.
Hard to swallow but impossible to ignore.
As written and directed by Akhtar and thesped by Khan, Don takes such devilish delight in confounding his enemies' expectations that the viewer cannot help but revel in his cleverness.
A millennial brace of lacrosse action propels Crooked Arrows through a thicket of cliches liberally planted in its path.
The characters are wearisomely one-dimensional and their situations and motives almost indecipherable due to poor exposition, weirdly pretentious dialogue and amateurish thesping.

Deftly avoiding both the haphazardness of mumblecore and the fakery of studio romantic comedies, Khoury deploys a light directorial touch marked by assured thesping and a genuine appreciation for neurotic angst.
Reminiscences about Goodman and readings of his poetry are played over old pictures that capture his singularly seductive appeal and lively sense of humor.

While its questions of affirmative action and charter schools could theoretically resonate with American auds, the pic's corny theatrics, talky, preachy approach and taxing 164-minute running time will not translate.
This curious blend of documentary and narrative, held together less by any plot device than by a rigorous aesthetic, proves all the more effective for being in service of casual naturalism.
Unfortunately, the unconvincing fictional storyline Rosenbaum weaves around this solid musical base hits every meller cliche in the "self-destructive rock star" playbook.
movie_title: The Perfect Age of Rock 'n' Roll (2011)

movie_review_blurb: [A] clever feel-good lark.
Lacks the delicate tonal control and subtle smarts required for such an intended half-surreal exercise.

The film opens with style, promise & top notch cinematography/direction. Sadly, after an hour of intrigue, thrill, & chase, the script sharply strays from earlier smarts.
Martin's first Pink Panther actually tickled me. Sadly, this time, flat gags & off-color innuendoes double in quantity, while sincerely funny bits wane to a mere handful.
A fairly entertaining mess, though the ending becomes a rather tedious mess. Also, hydrochlorothiazide is more likely to make you pee than to slow your heart rate.
There's certainly some very good direction, editing and acting - especially by the kids. But the adult actors just didn't seem to carry the weight of the harrowing back story.
Beautiful cinematography, good direction, solid supporting actors, interestingly enough story, despite its predictability, but the main character was absent.
A very sweet film. A freak of nature story, a love story, a surreal drama; Button is at its best reminding us the beauty, miracle, and impermanence of real life.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: An uneven, unfulfilling film, that hosts two or three really good dramatic scenes.
Swells of emotion & panoramic stampedes fill the screen; however, meandering scenes in between have been cut out at the seams so often, you'll be wandering what it all means.
The doc gets up-close and personal. It shows one injured vet's reality after war.
A sincere heartfelt documentary about life, death and murder.
movie_title: Dear Zachary: A Letter to a Son About His Father (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Stylish direction, powerful sound editing, stunning cinematography, vistas, action, and Daniel Craig's impenetrable demeanor.
I'm usually not crazy about thrillers, but this one had me engaged from start to finish.
N&N goes for the tone of Juno, but never quite finds the heart, nor does it enjoy the edgy sense of humor of "Superbad" -- though it tries.
A tad clunky and sappy and yes, even hokey. But, the picture still works. I was always engaged, I was always interested in what happened next, and I was always entertained.
The film grabs you immediately and never lets you go.
Despite an intriguing story, the picture falls from Art to the realm of kiddy-film fare. I'd have loved to see Pixar limit the dialogue to two words: Eva and Wall-E.
Despite the "smoking pot" refrain, PE finds a way to charm. These guys really seem to enjoy each others' company and are happy to welcome you into their little group.
Unlikely premise, yet script offers dialogue, heart-tugs, actual intelligent thought and a fair and necessary reflection on the State elections in the Union. A pleasant film.
Anne is okay, much stronger performances by Rosemary Dewitt, Tunde Adembimpe & Bill Irwin. Lush, rich, cultural music spices already fresh, alive family gathering scenes.
A fiery dynamo. Big action, snappy direction, good acting, respect for the past. This is the summer blockbuster to see.
A film entitled Angels & Demons, touting a challenge between religion & science in the name of the "Illuminati" should be more illuminating than a simple puzzle.
Nice performance by Sam Worthington. However, the film whole heartedly invests in action, leaving the story and character elements a bit slim.

The film is complex, intricate, interesting and almost hypnotizing, till Charlie gets stuck (the screenplay he's writing is the one you're watching). Glad he had the gonads to do what he did then, but it subtracts from the overall entertainment value.
Though not perfect, this is yet another beautiful documentary from the folks that brought us Queen of the Sun and The Real Dirt on Farmer John.
The documentary is well edited, well paced, and feels genuine. It's educational, important and enjoyable independent of the Kerry campaign.
As the film rounds to the third act, its colors dim.
One of the most beautifully filmed documentaries that I've ever seen.
movie_title: Queen Of The Sun: What are the Bees Telling Us? (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A must see for anyone with a script or an intention to write one. It's also likely inspiring, in a tough love sort of way, for anyone with any kind of ambition. I enjoyed it.
It's a warm, fuzzy, fluffy, entertaining film.
Action, splendid visuals, romance, and even relevance. Energized pace outshines even the juicy special effects, which seamlessly integrate live action and cgi.
Slow, and subtle, smiling brightly, the picture wins audiences with the charm of Mandela, but descends into a bland film about rugby.
A Hollywoody realization of a great real life triumph. Has its faults, but nicely directed, acted and edited, on the whole.
Stark, unforgiving, brutally honest, and yet... precious.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Hokey happenstance, big special effects, some are pretty cool. It's no masterpiece, makes embarrassing mistakes, but I must admit - I really enjoyed the raw excitement.
Uneven documentary brings to the surface important points about the quality of our food products. All of us (this non-organic, cola-drinker included) should be apprised.
movie_title: Nos enfants nous accuseront (Food Beware: The French Organic Revolution) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: I'm a music lover, but can't say I'm an MJ fan. Still, I enjoyed this behind-the-scenes/almost-concert film.
Like little Max's internal struggles, my feelings (about this film) aren't so easily understood, even to me.
A mixed bag. Moments of beauty and passion, but also moments that drag. Environmentalist gone Reality TV.
movie_title: At the Edge of the World (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's fun, ballsy, edited with color, humor & hopefully will bring some awareness to the price of greed, and inject some ethics into discussions among the rich and powerful.
movie_title: The Yes Men Fix the World (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Nestles nicely into a sweet rocking motion between humor and heart. The leads are warm, fuzzy, funny and very likeable. The few faults may very well go unnoticed.
A near masterpiece. 1st half is absolutely brilliant -- a beautiful compelling work of art. I laughed, I cried, I ogled at the rich visuals. Sweet and touching theme.
I'm probably not the first to say it's a train wreck. Starts out good enough, shows ability to the 1/2way mark, but the last 30 mins are just a scripting mess.
First 1.5 hours are slow, preposterously scripted, and short of powerful dialogue. I liked the ending though.
The first half is magical, captivating, inviting, great cinema. Second half disappoints.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A beautiful, affecting documentary with an appropriately sweet original sound track.
Powerful acting, powerful action, huge IMAX sequences give this Batman a great big commanding feel. However, story is held hostage to action, especially in the second half.
Despite the ages of the leads, plays to younger audiences, goes for the Judd Apatow crowd. It's unapologetically brash, crass, and ugly in its truth, but still funny.

Love and food, the basics of life, two passions common to nearly everyone on the planet, the film offers them up like hors d'oeuvres never ceasing to circle the room. It's gentle, tender, warm, and sprinkled generously with tasty bits of humor.
Overall, an imperfect gem. In its successful attempt to go for the heart, "Lars and the Real Girl" stumbles a bit. I would have cast Michael Cera in the lead role.
It's a compelling story with a deathly serious topic, treated in a near sideshow manner. I like it. Less factual than a doc, less fiction than a drama. Faction
Monty Python-esque. Reminded me a bit of the Stormtrooper spoof on TV's "Cops." Sharlto Copley sells it to us with grit, charm, naivety, and humor. He's absolutely brilliant.
A dirt bike motorcycle enthusiast as well as a 3D aficionado, I had a great time overall, despite the film's imperfections.
Honestly, I enjoyed the ever-amusing Ricky Gervais, and there is an oddly emotional moving mom/son scene, but the film, sadly, isn't so amusing.
Gangly, long, somewhat disjointed, but still very funny, I found "Funny People" surprisingly emotional, and even poignant.
Surprisingly rich entertainment, even takes on well known series: Star Wars, LOTR, & Die Hard; framed squarely within a sub-par opening and weak ending. Still, I liked it!
Perhaps destined to follow the same emotional arc as the true story it portrays, the film starts with great promise, passion, and inspiration only to quietly wane.
Clocks in several minutes short of a feature. A wise decision, the pattern was on the verge of repetition. Overall, interesting & worthwhile, but not a must see.
A pleasant enough film, but I simply didn't see what all the awards talk is about.
Many charming elements, but they don't quite add up to a fulfilling whole. Enjoyed the bit about souls scampering alongside people in the form of animals.
Some good performances. But, the overall disturbing atmosphere of the film is more than I prefer. That said, I appreciate the effort to raise awareness of PTSD.
A sweet little film for anyone that enjoys blurring the lines between fantasy and reality. Climaxes strongly. Has moments of greatness and moments of not-so-greatness.
Flawed, yet, does what I, as a musician, find difficult to do. It conveys in words&pictures that wonderful feeling of being caught in a much grander current of rhythm&melody.
Not only surpassed the lame promises of its advertisements, it proved to be one of the best films I've seen all year. Has that rare wonderful mix of warmth, depth, and funny.
Dazzling underwater photography. Compromises story/entertainment for message.
What a pleasure. After a cackle of serious dramas and actual letter grade B movies, this silly insect film was just the ticket to put a little honey in my tea.
Plot undermines otherwise solid performances and high quality production.
Solid, but not daring IMAX cinematography. Has its moments, but fails to wow.
Wonderful cinematography, great music by Queen, pace suffers a bit near the end.
A solid documentary; unfortunately, the picture suffers from rickety 3-D.
Impressively filmed with good action, a compellingly dramatic story line with simply great lion shots, Roar is improved with the added dimension.
Acting is strong (I like these stars), the direction passionate, but the film is bleak and laborious with unbelievable and-or undeveloped progressions in the telling.
While in the theatre seat -- I had a great time -- didn't want the film to end. But, when it did end, the aftertaste wasn't as sweet.
Children of Heaven won me over with its slow gentle build and big sweet heart. I was expecting more of the same with Willow Tree. Unfortunately, I was disappointed.
High quality production. The dialogue in this film sings with poetry, grit, spit, and the ring of rural America circa 1880's. Not an action picture, long with a relaxed pace.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Why PAY for something you can see on TV for FREE? Homer asks. As one of the dolts who shelled out the DO'H, I answer, Because the Simpsons make me laugh.
Like the other two, Ultimatum has little problem working up a frantic pace & maintaining it. However, Ultimatum has other problems that make it the least effective Bourne.
Fails for 1 full hour, then pivoting on De Niro's flamboyant appearance, ascends to clouds. Too many cut up furry creatures & risque adult situations for kids & animal lovers.
Imagine American Pie and South Park blending into one film.
As warped and blatantly anecdotal as it is, it does make strongly a point well in need of making - namely, health care in the states needs an overhaul.
At its heart, this is actually an excellent film. But, as filmmakers seek to escalate the big action, believability suffers severely.
An SNL sketch may have been a better vehicle for such a spoof. On the big screen, it ends up having a film life of its own becoming a music bio pic in order to sustain.
movie_title: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Cackles & guffaws are sparse amidst much meandering. Willem Dafoe at Cannes, however, is quite funny.
Opens without a pulse, fires intermittent blanks throughout, musters up momentum with a silly sense of humor that eventually, just barely, wins over its audience.
Stumbles away from its smart thriller open, completely immerses itself in a one-man vs. gang-of-thugs, love-of-guns flick with Bacon more like Bourne than corp VP.
Though refreshingly reluctant to take sides regarding geography of the matter, the film has a subtle slant toward peace.
movie_title: Blood and Tears: The Arab-Israeli Conflict (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Myself a "Curb your Enthusiasm" enthusiast, I welcomed a work by Jeff Garlin who plays Larry's best friend and manager on "Curb."
movie_title: I Want Someone to Eat Cheese With (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A lush, interesting mix of media - song, old-school psychedelic effects, acting & dance. It's a musical tribute to Rock's most loved British band that plays out in America.
Didn't I just see this film two weeks ago with Kevin Bacon in Death Sentence? Terrance Howard is strong, though. Funny lines from Nicky Katt.
Limited to three couples and their real estate agents and a handful of property locations, this indie never ceases to entertain.
Bursts onto the screen with robust energy, youth, and vigor. Tongue-in-cheek humor, subtle visual jokes, high octane tunes and dancing. 1st half excellent, second less so.
Engaging, moving, and even has a good message, but it's also a film that slips in the follow through.
movie_title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (2007)

movie_review_blurb: This rickety empty-feeling production has a script & stars that deliver lots of edgy little subtle jokes. The dialogue is crisp and crunchy, but the romance is nearly absent.
With so much information coming at us from all channels, it's odd, but we often forget about our own progress, development as humans worthy of our time on Earth.
"Hancock" is two films jammed together. The first part, deserves an "A" (Kudos to Jason Bateman), but the second part is clearly a B movie. I'll average only to a B .
I kept wanting something more from this pleasant enough flick.
I'm shaking my head now like a caring teacher grading a poor assignment written by a bright student.
The grand acting chops of Norton and Roth fall prey to action which is more noisy than memorable and fails to carry a script lacking in impact, depth and originality.
Oh heck, this is my favorite film of the year so far -- A ! Action, depth, fun, comedy, profound messages and it's visually gorgeous.
An amusement park ride. Kind of fun, but we know there's no real danger. The film never has an edge (save for a great hotrod scene).
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Surprisingly good filmmaking, but a kid's film? Could it be that any important lessons here get lost in all the warring?
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Simply a funky mess. Bold and beautiful at times, complete stall at others. I'll round up to a Bplus because I respect the effort, but with serious reservations.
The film is well directed, edited, and paced, but it's really Downey Jr. that adds the spark, the flair, the heavy metal.
Overall, rather disorganized and uneven as a documentary, but always passionate, intriguing and certainly pertinent.
Scenes spoofing TV's CSI incarnations are very funny and welcome. While mildly awkward moments abound, so do the belly busting, laugh out loud hits.
George Clooney has directed a couple of very fine films- Confessions of a Dangerous Mind and Good Night & Good Luck. Unfortunately, Leatherheads cannot be added to that list.
Despite its lack of fair balance, the piece is absolutely compelling and makes a point that is far more universal than any one country.
While some moments rely solely on Pegg's natural on-screen goofiness, he & M. I. Black have simply written a very funny script that spreads the fun evenly throughout.
This is easily my favorite Seuss story (written in 1954, animated as a 30 minute TV special in 1970). New feature version enjoys great animation, but not so magical voicing.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' Horton Hears a Who! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Dialogue focuses only on how characters relate to each other. A game of love, lust, power, manipulation. Nothing more aside from their rather single-minded aims.
A very cute movie with a great soundtrack. Though, imho, not the award winner for which it's been receiving so much buzz. Michael Cera (Bleaker) nails every scene he's in.
This initially hokey 70's-TV-style production determinedly matures into a motion picture with cinematic impact. Happily, climax/resolution detour from others in the genre.
Yes it's a bit syrupy - but you only live once and I like lots of syrup with my pancakes. May you all live like you were dyin' and laugh so hard you cry.
It's as if you can feel the oil flowing under the ground, bubbling, seeking a weak patch of earth from which to spew. But, the climactic emotional equivalent never occurs.
The 3D is less than rock solid, but the experience and sound mix are a pleasure.
I'm a big fan of the Coens. But, I've got to say, I'm not much appreciating this picture.
Sale of the love story is hampered by the sheer number of impossible coincidences that mount on the first day of events. Great Sound direction. Good Cinematography.
It's great for kids to see that Miley doesn't just wake up polished. She makes mistakes, she practices - there's a learning curve and work involved. Fans are sure to enjoy.
movie_title: Hannah Montana/Miley Cyrus: Best of Both Worlds Concert Tour (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Abigail Breslin's role is limited despite ads. Don't expect a family film, rather be ready for something more akin to the TV show Friends.
10 Short (5 Live Action, 5 Animated). I screened these with three friends - our four subjective grades are included with each title. We loved Tanghi Argentini.
Cool game plan on paper, unfortunately, the execution lacks. Further, this is not the subject matter with which to play games.
Opens as a study on a teen with some social/behavioral issues. The film makes sure never to label, then gently tangents from the study into a sweet spontaneous love story.
Nice crisp images, gives a rather realistic taste of one face of world travel - opportunity missed to display meaningful interactions with locals & larger spiritual aspects.
Surprising, Insightful, Informative. We are reminded that an "atmosphere" of fear may be much more dangerous than the threat.
Cool concept, good acting, respectable cinematography; but the depth is sadly missing. Jumps away from any kind of in-depth dialogue and headlong into the same type of action.
Impressive start, strong acting, but goes long. A bit tedious to watch Joaquin Cash stumble all over his personal life. Maybe that's because we saw Ray not so long ago.
With such high quality production, I kept expecting some meat - or at least a sense of humor. Just an empty night at the movies
The direction is phenomenal! Seldom does even a 90-min production come along with such a vibrant pace (this is 150!). A strong film overall, though the climax is a bit weak.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The film engages generally average.
Strong B+. I suppose the film is true to Rock 'n' Roll by being both fun and irresponsible.

When people tell you it's bloody, they're not exaggerating. Unfortunately, there isn't a whole lot more. (And I loved Pulp Fiction)
Taut suspense, keen twists and a smart, careful disclosure of the plot.

Warm and a little syrupy like old school films.
Denzel has made better pictures.

Not terribly exciting, but somewhat amusing nonetheless. Dull first act.
Stylish, lip-stick-slick, these flicks' opening schticks are like a short-wick cracker brick.
Beautiful film, sweetly filmed in flight in formation with the birds, as if we're one of the flock.
Before it becomes redundant, the action is truly fun and classically swashbuckling.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Weak climax, but overall, the film is quite enjoyable, never too serious about itself, always in it for the fun and adventure.

movie_review_blurb: Eye-candy, but fun. No down time, but had some trouble with the 3-D.
Pretty darned funny.

Rather sprawling in its portrayal of several love stories, the film strikes some appeal at times, and misses the mark at others.

One of the most important films I've seen in the last year or so. A matter of life and death, required viewing for those sincerely interested in a better understanding of war.
movie_title: The Fog of War: Eleven Lessons from the Life of Robert S. McNamara (2003)

movie_review_blurb: an inspiring film, no matter what your faith.

Clever, in a rather implausible sort of way, this unevenly constructed picture is still entertaining.
Could have been stronger, but it's still fun and has good heart. Ditto to what Steve Rhodes said.

Very Funny. Apparently this film is a remake, but it feels more like a sequel to the 1994 "True Lies." It's playful & good spirited "Last one to the plane gets to take one hundred and seventy million through customs!"
Rather bland through the first third, the second third picks up only a little bit, but that third third is sweet.
Not bad, but could have been something smashing.
Here's a sweet film to rent for Father's Day or Christmas. It's a heart-warmer, charming, and shot with a sugary cinematic eye.
Eerie, good-hearted, compelling.
While the first "Legally Blonde" quite impressed me as a fun and funny solid film, "Red White & Blonde" doesn't fill the high-heeled shoes.
A wonderfully organic film that flows on the inherently human actions of its detailed and well-rounded characters.
I'm a fan of both Murphy and Fanning; but this film might be one they'll leave off their resumes.
The film over all is uneven, stale at the outset, with all the sugar at the bottom of the glass. Arrive late.
Yes, there's action, fun, and even some well-earned tension. But X2 is simply lacking the gel, the magic, the super-power of that strong first film "X-Men."
Whether you get 20% or 100% of the intellectualizing, & even if there's no sense in fighting software with military hardware & Kung Fu; it's simply a marvel to watch.

Forget about deadlines, taxes and politics: the most important things in the world are mom, cookies, crayons, and good friends. And the only thing that can hinder a day full of directionless play and bouncing around is a bath.
Though it starts out with a quirky sense of promise, this film about an ambitious stewardess never gets off the ground.
Well acted and fun, makes a great springboard for conversation in any science class and a good old-fashioned night out at the movies.
Carrey forces it early on, stiff, awkward. But becomes comfortable once he gets those God Powers. He's funny, but it's Steve Carell who garnishes the film's belly laughs.
Rock keeps the film hoppin', punching along at a strong pace. And, as soon as Bernie Mac pops his head into the picture, the belly laughs start to roll.
What his expedition finds is less interesting to me than how he finds it. The tiny submarines, the 6 foot model, the video robots - these are all innovative, curious.
Oh, this is a good film. Fun curious dialogue rolls across the tongues of rich likable characters to create a strong thumping pace that never lulls.

If this were a student piece, I would have told the makers that they had something here, but it needed further fine-tuning. I'd have handed it back for revisions with the comment, "Make the whole film sparkle like the bridge scene or the bar scene."
Having really enjoyed "Undercover Brother," I went out of my way to catch this film and ended up laughing so hard, I cried at times.
A mildly pleasant film with two charming leads.
Seems like such a long time since I've seen a film with a classically powerful story. "Holes" pays off!
Sabotages itself.
Two hours is a long time for a film to keep its tongue in cheek.
Omar Epps, sporting a great physique and aggressive acting chops, opens up the ring bringing heart and drama to an intro that hadn't much more to offer than big names.
If you could roll up all the things that concern a 13-year-old (from the 1980's) and put them into a 30-year-old, well then you'd pretty much have this film.
An endearing story that will keep you at the edge of your seat, the edge of a cheer, the edge of a tear.
Plagued with product placement.
Great pace, strong dialogue, and a fun fresh angle on the life of a hit man.
A fall-out-of-the-chair, funny movie!
This film breaks the icy barriers of traditional repression, cold communication. Offers up a series of sometimes charming scenes, but seldom breaks deeper into the surface.

A flawed masterpiece.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: If you want a more realistic safari than this, you're going to have to catch a flight (unless you live in Africa).
movie_title: Wild Safari: A South African Adventure (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Rafting action/adventure meets education along the Nile.
A beautiful production.
movie_title: IMAX - Grand Canyon: The Hidden Secrets (1984)

movie_review_blurb: Some great shots of some odd (alien) deep sea fish and a good tie into space exploration, but other than that, the 3D isn't that great and reaction shots go too long.
Good music, good camera work, big screen. Keith Richards is in heaven.
movie_title: Rolling Stones: Live at the Max (1996)

movie_review_blurb: Decodes the Enron scandal, ties it in with California energy crisis.
movie_title: Enron: The Smartest Guys in the Room (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Fun and amusing, but somehow not quite quenching. Alas, I fear that I'm biased.
movie_title: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Though, at times a bit incomplete, this documentary is still quite endearing, engaging and extremely educational in matters of politics and heart.
A lush piece of entertainment! Wow! Big action. Big comedy. Big heart. You'll laugh, you'll cry, you'll laugh and cry at the same time.
Some great lines, some great performances, some very very interesting relational topics, but un-quenching, seldom moving and simply not funny enough to be a comedy.
Beautiful craftsmanship, at times, even magnificent, but weakens, repeats, can't keep itself together.
Pleasant enough, yet it seldom sparks hearty laughter or tugs too strongly on a heartstring.
It does have some sex, some apple pie and some God, but it's more often in the verbal or implication, even the apple pie, if you let it be a symbol of growing up in America.
While Akira's blood splattering is over the top for me, I did enjoy the surreal, and the interesting complicated departure from the often-oversimplified good vs. evil.
Steve Zahn rocks! Though at times the film certainly stretches the believability factor, it is always engaging, always fun.
1st third is sharp, funny, well edited & directed. But, contrivances accumulate one after the other.
I laughed, I cried, I'm recommending!
A good Movie of the Week. Engaging, a bit soapy, but with real circumstance & intelligent/plausable chat. However, tidies up too neatly in the end.
Captures hope and compassion in a shady part of humanity most probably unaccustomed to such things.
Same theme as Million Dollar Baby which fancies itself both realistic and inspirational. Dust to Glory is not only more realistic, but also more inspirational.
A slow even pressure cooker -- very nicely done.
A sweet magical music box. Warm, slightly surreal, sincere.
Wonderfully entertaining! Visually tantalizing! Musically upbeat! A modern animation with the spirit of The Wizard of Oz and Willy Wonka.
Low on action/suspense, in fact, slow and dull at times. Sean Penn and strong dialogue keep it alive.
Paced well for kids, heavy on puns, and plants a few "thought-proking" seeds, but never commits to more than surface depth.
movie_title: The Adventures of Sharkboy and Lavagirl in 3-D (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Magical send off, but overstays and over-resolves just a bit. That said, some gorgeous imagery, charming to look at, and a cast of endearingly animated characters.
Finishes well and Vince Vaughn rocks. However, runs rather slow, save for the last half hour.
Not without its flaws, but overall surreal fun. Slightly above average. (Might be a bit too scary for little kids.)
A crisp impressionistic look at stardom while pointing out the allure of being common. Very strong in direction, script and acting, but struggles to finish.
An interesting piece. Not the old silly Steve Martin, and not without faults, but nice in his new way.
It's not a bad movie, really. The elements are all there, they just feel somehow not terribly inspired.

A comedy? A wake up call? I'm not sure.
This is a beautiful film. On the surface, a rolling ball, a silly comedy, a farce even. But a closer look, a closer look, reveals a beauty easily not seen.
I have mixed feelings. Cool, engaging, well acted (William Hurt is brilliant). But could have used a bit more shaving in the editing room and a bit messy on point.
A nice film for a father to take his daughter to. Others may find it so by-the-numbers that even high-powered actors (+ a horse) have a hard time breathing life into it.
movie_title: Dreamer: Inspired by a True Story (2005)

movie_review_blurb: This may be a great film for people out of touch with how their negative behaviors effect those they love.
It's simply great! Go see it.
movie_title: Wallace & Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Absolutely a formula feel good sport's film - a natural to succeed at its goal (much like its main character) as long as it doesn't choke on a stroke. You'll feel good.
I was laughing &/or crying the whole time (aside from the first & last ten minutes). I liked it!
Makes a pretty good date film, really, it's quite romantic.
The film is engaging, still it never connects with much more than a curiosity. The emotions run, but not deep.
First half is flat and unfunny, second half picks up and ends well.

Strong writing, acting, directing. A surprisingly very strong film. You'll get your money's worth.
A good cry feels good.
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants (2005)

Very likeable and enjoyable for the most part, even endearing; the film stumbles a bit in the telling. Hitch just barely swings into a B+ on charm.
Squarely a kids' film, but mom and dad will have some fun too.
A high quality production, with strong direction, great acting, but ultimately not much crawling beneath the surface.
Except for the Chocolate factory and Willie Wonka, this is an excellent film. Depp misses. Freddie Highmore scores!

Delivers its fair share of laughs & guffaws. Always amusing, fairly engaging. That said, there is no real emotional arc, no grand build to climax.

Serious moments have softened edges, the film rarely feels heavy. Always interesting and entertaining, but never especially deep and certainly not dark.

movie_title: A Love Song for Bobby Long (2004)

Somewhat of a "Harold and Maude" updated. We could use more films with this kind of spirit.
Oh, I like this film! Formulaic, but good direction, great pace, strong dialogue, strong acting, big giant helium-filled warm heart.
This film has probably got the best action you'll ever see in a stupid comedy. Surprisingly refreshing.

Surprise surprise, the movie outplays its trailer. Picks up big well-deserved laughs in between ever decreasing non-funny moments.
movie_title: Anchorman - The Legend Of Ron Burgundy (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Does what it promises -- gives great tense drama and action. However, jerky camera work is somewhat annoying.

Historically interesting, surprisingly humorous, and at times, sad.

It's worth twice the ticket price!

movie_title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)

movie_title: Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow (2004)

movie_review_blurb: While teens are at the age of self discovery, Igby is doing his best work at self-destruction.

movie_title: What the Bleep Do We Know!? (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Wholesome for the most part, this rich robust family film (with the flair of yesteryear) clips along fast. It plants a smile on your face that lasts for the duration.

This is clearly one of the decade's cleverest, most original pictures.

Not the supernatural thriller you might be hoping for.
Powerfully inspirational, laden with tough love, and on occasion a tad hokey. It's the "Coach Carter" of H.S. Math class.
Inspirational, laden with tough love, and on occasion a tad hokey. Stand and Deliver on the basketball court.
Keeps itself welcoming, like a good family, but not preachy, not too kind. The acting and direction top notch, you'll get your money's worth.
Clearly contrived, yet at times undeniably funny. Still, from this cast, you may be expecting more substance and less sophomore.
Indulges in a set-up that bleeds far into the film. Scattered, the production lacks build. Hopes that oddity will be enough to entertain and sometimes it does.
Lush, vibrant, well-paced.
The film could have been much richer had it given equal screen time to the emotive. Also, character aging problems (they don't). Otherwise slightly above ave.

An inconsistently entertaining film, just a small notch above average.

I heart this film! Do you like quirky comedies? Existential philosophy? Or at least, do you like (or need) to spend a little time reflecting on meaning in your life?

movie_review_blurb: It's essentially TV for the big screen, but shot well, paced well, directed well, and nailed by Zellweger.

movie_review_blurb: Fast-paced and fascinating, but a little too frenetic for its own good.

Cory Finley is as calculated and smart as his central characters, an exciting new talent that has made one of 2018's finest debuts.

movie_title: How to Lose a Guy in 10 Days (2003)

Cemetery of Crosses spares few words and relies instead on stylish action sequences and elegant, atmospheric cinematography to achieve its ends.
movie_title: The Rope and the Colt (Cemetery Without Crosses)(Une corde, un Colt...) (1969)

movie_review_blurb: Channing Tatum plays a flying wolfman from space, and yet this film is, somehow, boring.
The film captures the alienated state of homelessness so completely that by the end the average citizens strolling by seem foreign.
Thief wears its genre as a badge of honour from the very first scene.
Director Liv Corfixen stays conspicuously absent throughout, hiding behind the lens as Refn oscillates wildly between moods.
movie_title: My Life Directed By Nicolas Winding Refn (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The camera is never an intrusion and the fly-on-the-wall perspective never hints at voyeurism - but it's also never played to, just left to its own devices while everybody else goes about their lives.
A stark, harsh murder mystery interspersed with Wong Kar-wai-esque moments of odd urban beauty.
movie_title: Bai ri yan huo (Black Coal, Thin Ice) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Simply watchable, never becoming either entirely offputting or genuinely entertaining.
An enchanting anime overflowing with imaginative energy and visual panache.
movie_title: The Boy And The Beast (Bakemono No Ko) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Spencer cleverly deconstructs the genre by playing it out in a lo-fi, naturalistic way that highlights their absurdity.
Bridgend portrays a group of lost young people tearing madly at life, veering between wild ecstasy and violent nihilism.
Powered by three strong, naturalistic performances, some of Dheepan's best scenes are the quietest ones.
Some characters' stories end happily, many sadly, some we don't know yet. All of them are beautifully told.
Bloodlight... leaves Jones' mystique undiminished, but its naturalistic style means that most questions about her extraordinary life and career go unanswered.
In Karen Gillan's Inverness-set directorial debut, the script, the camera, and the actor all move in perfect time with one another.
James Erskine's uncomplicated approach is the reverse of the complex life it documents, but the film's simplicity matches its spirit.
Harry Dean Stanton saw the road to Hollywood stardom, shrugged, lit another cigarette, and kept walking. Lucky is his perfect valediction.
... Iron Heart takes an excellent, eclectic cast and gives each member space to shine, even if the film around them fails to quite match their lustre.
movie_title: The Man with the Iron Heart (2017)

movie_review_blurb: An accomplished debut from the Coen brothers, and a slick, despairingly funny piece of noir.
Wielding language like a precise and delicate instrument, James Baldwin's words slice intricately through race, oppression and ignorance with clinical elegance.
The camera is the star of Headshot, converting what could have been a blur of blood and battery into something visceral, intense and gripping.
An excellent piece of cinema.
Even Michael Keaton's eye-popping energy can't shock a heartbeat into a script that turned up dead on arrival.
The movie is littered with small details of lore that should make Apple fanatics happy.
Upstream Color is a trippy and enjoyable exploration of connections both direct and indirect.

This is the perfect movie for David Fincher. The intentions of the characters, good or bad, are never judged -- Fincher never takes a side. The consequences are determined by what's presented, not what's honest or even fair.
The twists are compelling enough to propel the movie from one action set-piece to the next.
Can Mission: Impossible stay relevant in today's era of popcorn film? The answer is decidedly maybe. Definitely maybe.
Disney found a true "Star Wars" champion in Johnson and I'm eager to see what he does when he's able to craft the next trilogy from scratch.
The overall tone is one of light drama, and it's only through its situations that it becomes a sly, witty statement on society, politics and pop culture.
The film's photography is pretty slick and the stuff in the Bahamas in particular has aged very well.
Time Bandits remains Fantasy 101, and a must-see for people who enjoy this kind of fare.
The real star is Bridges, who plays not so much a layered character, but a man whom we instantly identify with and understand and want to watch.
These folks -- both in front of and behind the camera -- really threw themselves into their work, and, provided you have an open mind, it shows.
What's probably most amazing about Santa Sangre is that most of it works, and almost never does it feel like it's being unsettling just for the sake of it.
In our celebrity-obsessed culture, it's possible that All About Eve is more important than ever. Scratch that. How about it's more entertaining than ever?
From a plot standpoint, there isn't much that's remarkable about it, yet its two central figures are so honestly drawn that they make up for any predictability along the way.
There are times when the movie, through both image and sound, approaches an almost Lynchian type of unsettling nightmare.
The sort of Gilliam ideas that at one time were perceived as fanciful or witty are now the horror outside your front door or inside your computer monitor.

Pretty much across the board the characters are more interesting in the remake, but that's really only because they actually are characters to some degree, as opposed to the caricatures presented in the '78 version.
Nearly perfect.
There's never a dull moment.
Non-stop fun.
May vary well be the best comic book film made yet.
A film that adults could have fun watching too.
A fun, charming little film.
If you allow it, the film will bring you from the cheers of victory to the heartbreak of lost love.
The performances are there, the dialogue feels real and Van Sant's direction is spot-on.
A very smartly put together little film, beautifully shot and brilliantly edited together with footage from the original Nosferatu.
Really enjoyable because of the three leads.
An amazing film that should be seen by everyone.
Fast moving, the characters are never without something to do, or something to run from.
Weighed down in it's own schlockyness.
A film for people who enjoy actors, acting.
A mediocre movie.
A nicely told family drama.
This is a competently made film, with some wonderfully subdued camera work and very effective editing.
Mostly the film creates an infectious feeling of apprehension that slowly crawls up your spine.
Despite being a little clich√©, Ping Pong is a hell of a lot of fun.
Despite the problems this plays as one of the better ones of the past couple years.
A well crafted and thoughtful film.
Every performance in the film is perfect, from the leads to the smaller characters.
None of the characters or plot-lines are fleshed-out enough to build any interest.
A movie to get lost in.
I'm ecstatic to report that American Pie 2 did not disappoint.
It will give you the kind of feeling that you wish you could bottle up and carry with you for the rest of your days.
Allen's latest is a comedy of refreshing depth that finds the 72-year-old filmmaker invigorated by the picturesque backdrop of the Mediterranean coast and a perfectly matched cast.
The outcome is never in question, but for fans of the game, even simulated action is preferable to perfunctory drama.

If you can forgive its stale dialogue, which at times seems so egregiously leaden that it might have been better suited to a Mad magazine parody, 'Street Kings' is a tense, aggressively absurd thriller.
Anderson - not to be confused with Paul Thomas Anderson, the fearlessly ambitious director of 'Magnolia' and 'There Will Be Blood' - has created a movie worthy of its own video game.
Faris' ability to turn an otherwise mediocre exercise into a charming farce may not earn her any awards, but it gives us something to look forward to - namely, her next movie.
'Babylon A.D.' has ideas, but they are hopelessly lost in a story with no interior logic.

Mamet's dialogue is crisp, invigorated by supporting players (particularly Mantegna and Jay) who relish his acerbic wordplay. But for a movie that aims to do for jujitsu what 'Rocky' did for boxing, 'Redbelt' taps out before the final bell.

Here, the brothers weave an elaborate, misanthropic web of desperation and betrayal around a group of characters so jaded they take no real pleasure from their artless deceptions and sordid affairs. Imagine how we feel.
'Righteous Kill' is a tired pastiche of genre clich√©s and ideas borrowed from other D-grade thrillers, a story without style, energy or any discernible respect for narrative logic.
The good news: I Want to Believe plays like a solid, albeit unexceptional stand-alone episode, broad enough to ensnare the uninitiated without alienating the show's loyal base.
movie_title: The X-Files: I Want to Believe (The X Files 2) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Wilson's amiably wild-eyed performance hits all the scripted notes in a comedy that is mostly tone-deaf.
Does everyone fall in love after the third date? In his world, they do.
It's not pretty, and the humor is sometimes embarrassingly puerile, but for those with a passion for subversive trash, Troma Entertainment is still serving it on a bile-covered platter.
movie_title: Poultrygeist: Night of the Chicken Dead (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Why would Frank drop everything to embark on this lunatic mission? Well, the answer is simple. If he didn't, there would be no movie - and perhaps that wouldn't have been such a bad thing.
movie_title: Marilyn Hotchkiss Ballroom Dancing & Charm School (2006)

movie_review_blurb: At no time does director Stephen Hopkins give us reason to care.
Loach delivers a moving and often beautiful story that captures the essence of the conflict, with all its unintended consequences and personal tragedies.
movie_title: The Wind That Shakes the Barley (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Aattou plays his role with the supreme self-confidence of a man in control, his deep blue eyes radiating calm, but Argento seems to know better. She is a wild, physical force, a primal fury who could only be resisted if she were to allow it.
movie_title: Une Vieille Ma√Ætresse (The Last Mistress) (An Old Mistress) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Rockwell, who brought a sense of desperate unease to his roles in 'The Assassination of Jesse James' and 'Confessions of a Dangerous Mind,' does the same here, with results that are at once frightening and pathetically sad.

From the start, it drags us down to the fiery pits of Gotham's anarchic hell and never lets us up for air; it is a bruising, unrelenting slice of sensory overload, a captivating spectacle as likely to dazzle the eyes as fray the nerves.

Acting is hardly of great consequence in a movie where everyone involved seems a little too in on the joke, as if distancing themselves from material that would simply be vile if it weren't so outrageously over the top.

It is an artfully crafted exercise in high-octane style, bolstered by a stronger cast than most horror films could ever hope to assemble, but it's a bitter, sleazy little pill that leaves an ugly aftertaste.
